column2: A large part of the talks of President Truman and General MacArthur will naturally be devoted to plans for the rehabilitation of Korea.
A pension program tailored to meet the needs of an industry that went through a long period of inactivity in the prohibition years was approved yesterday by 7,000 New York brewery workers.

TORQUAY, England, Oct. 12-- The Torquay tariff conference has bumped roughly, though apparently successfully, over the first major threat to its ultimate success.
From the Seventh Annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference came these consumer-news bulletins yesterday:
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 12 (AP) --Cordon S. Seagrave, United States doctor who became world famous as the "Burma Surgeon," went on trial for his life today before a special Burmese tribunal.

Three of the major candidates for Mayor recalled with pride last night their Italian heritage as they made non-political speeches at a Columbus Day dinner arranged by the Italian-American Professional and Businessmen's Association.

Meyer Lansky, close associate of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and Frank Costello, refused yesterday to answer "pertinent" questions on the New York-New Jersey gambling situation before the Senate Crime Investigation Committee. The committee will recommend that he be cited for contempt.
Meat prices are generally lower this week-end than in many months. Several beef cuts are down from 4 to 5 cents a pound, pork and lamb have declined further and only veal remains unchanged.

The latest report of the United Nations observers in the Balkans is a warning to the complacent. They find that Communist guerrillas are again infiltrating into Greece from Albania and Poland. Evidence that Greek guerrillas ...

Benjamin G. Browdy, president of the Zionist Organization of America, urged the United States Government yesterday to extend a grant-in-aid of $500,000,000 over a period of three to four years to Israel. Such a grant, he added, would be in accordance with the Government's program of helping democratic nations.

TOKYO, Oct. 12--With the destruction of the North Korean Army near completion, a final stand appeared to be planned in defense of Pyongyang, the Communist capital, as remnants of Red units strove yesterday to move ...
Five little girls from The Dalton School, 108 East Eightyninth Street, who enjoyed the distinction of having enjoyed the distinction of having their own art show on Fifty-seventh Street ...

The State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance won a first-round victory yesterday in its fight to bar unemployment payments to summer resort workers who fail to make any serious effort to find other work when the resort season ends.
Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss H. Marim Pew, daughter of Mrs. Donaldson L. Lambert of Haverford, Pa., and Walter C. Pew of Bryn ...
The Medical Society of Virginia, at its Roanoke convention this week, came within five votes of the two-thirds majority necessary to admit Negro physicians to full membership.

MOSCOW. There are no queues today in front of food stores in Moscow. The price of butter has not risen. There is no hoarding of sugar. There are more shoes for sale in Moscow stores than there were last spring. Prices are lower and quality has been somewhat improved.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12--Moving with unexpected speed, the United Nations Interim Committee on Korea approved today an Australian resolution stating that the government of President Syngman Rhee had authority only over the southern half of Korea.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12--Count Leonardo Vitetti, Italian observer before the United Nations Special Political Committee debating the future of Libya, charged today that a British proposal for settlement of economic and financial matters was a "juridical monstrosity."
Strikes rather than defense demands have brought about steel shortages, Harold S. Vance, president and chairman of the board of the Studebaker Corporation, said yesterday.

MIAMI, Oct, 12 (UP)--George Patton, former sheriff's deputy in charge of raids on handbooks, who was in Office of Strategic Services agent during the war, was put under twenty-four-hour guard in a secret hiding place today after testifying about Florida gambling before a grand jury.

Family buying of meat to store in home freezers, refrigerators and freezer lockers already has begun to affect supplies and prices at retail meat counters and can be expected to have more effect in the future, according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, of the Department of Agriculture.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12--President Truman made a plea for the continued growth of tolerance in the United States today shortly before he took off on another leg of his flying journey to a meeting in the Pacific with Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 12--The Conservative party, opening its annual conference here today, dealt with the Communist problem in a typically British way. It pledged the party to "employ every legitimate means to combat the insidious advance of communism."
ATHENS, Oct. 12--A cable sent today by the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans, from its headquarters here to Nasrollah Entezam, President of the United Nations General Assembly, ...

Dr. Frederick C. McLaughlin, educational director of the Public Education Association since 1946, has been appointed director of the association, it was announced yesterday with the release of the organization's annual report.

DETROIT, Oct. 12(UP)--Regulation W has reduced buying of new and used automobiles across the country, a survey showed today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12--The Midwest Stock Exchange in the first nine months of this year had the largest percentage gains over last year in both share trading volume and dollar volume of any Exchange ...
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 12 (AP)--A former policeman once acquitted of a murder charge in the death of a young Negro prisoner admitted today that he had beaten the Negro with a rubber hose and a stick.

YONKERS, Oct. 12--The Gotham Trot, scheduled for the Yonkers Raceway tonight, was postponed until tomorrow night because of adverse track conditions. The event is worth $25,000 and is scheduled over a distance of a mile and a half.

BRUGES, Belgium, Oct. 12--An important step in the movement for European unity was taken today with the inauguration in this medieval city of the first academic year of the College of Europe.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 12--Coach Senny Howarth, the Wesleyan fleet-footed back of some twenty-five years ago, peered through the windows of the faculty room of St. Mark's School today, perturbed about the damp conditions outside. It had rained all ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--Current and imminent wage demands by 1,250,000 railroad workers would require an increase of 11 to 15 per cent in freight and passenger rates, railroad sources said today.

LONDON, Oct. 12--The stock markets unaccountably improved today. British Government securities recovered from their early dullness, industrial shares rose slightly and mining issues, especially South African gold mines, became more cheerful.

NEWARK, Oct. 12--Riding a horse while under the influence of liquor will be the charge Harold B. Wilder, 47 years old, a junk dealer of 208 Prince Street, will answer to before Magistrate Victor D'Aloia tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12--An old disease with a new name was reported today as developing into a rival of the common cold.

Eddie Arcaro and Mrs. Louis Lazare's Sheilas Reward had plenty of wet dirt kicked their way in the first half-mile of the $17,225 Interborough Handicap at Jamaica yesterday, but they found an opening at the top of the stretch and slammed through it for a late ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized the Alabama Power Company, Birmingham, to issue 100,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $100 par.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 12 (AP) --J.D. Hill, president of the C.I.O.-United Auto Workers local at the Studebaker Corporation plant, said today its members had authorized a strike vote to be taken Wednesday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 12-- The engagement of Miss Margaret Anne Paton to Everett Leslie Bayha, son of Charles Leslie Bayha of St. Louis and the late Mrs. Bayha, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Paton.

Registration in New York City took an unusually sharp drop yesterday, according to the official tabulations made public early today at Manhattan Police Headquarters.

Despite intermittent showers and temperatures not conducive to cold weather clothing sales, women's apparel volume in stores yesterday showed an increase over Columbus Day of a year ago.
Rabbi Gabriel Schulman of Congregation B'rith Sholom, former spiritual leader of the Park Avenue Synagogue, died on Wednesday night. His health had been ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--A statement of the French Government's rearmament position calling for "outside aid" of nearly $1,000,000,000 to equip and maintain twenty active divisions on the continent was before the United States Government officially today.

Intermittent squalls riding fortymile winds from the West deluged the metropolitan area yesterday in an outburst of freakish weather that brought explosive lightning, and in some areas marble-sized hail.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 12-- Michael Williams of Westport, Catholic editor and writer, who founded The Commonweal, Roman Catholic weekly journal of opinion, died here today in a hospital after a long illness. His age was 73.
Dwellings for one and two families dominated trading in Brooklyn in transactions reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Oct. 12 (Reuters)-- The Korean Republic and Japan will give each other reciprocal shipping facilities under an agreement announced today.

TORONTO, Oct. 12--The National defense program has had very little direct effect on machine tool orders so far, experts told more than 350 members of the National Machine Tool Builders Association here today, but more defense orders are expected soon.
The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra opened its 1950-51 season last night in Carnegie Hall, with its numerous and faithful audience assembled. Dimitri Mitropoulos had selected for ...

People who watch television can be thankful that many years ago George Burns and Gracie Allen traded places. As a vaudeville team, Gracie was pulling more laughs than George the comedian, so George switched to the role of a straight man.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--The Department of Justice struck back today at the eleven Communists who recently petitioned the Supreme Court to review their conviction in New York for conspiracy to teach violent overthrow of the Government.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 12-- India "fully subscribes" to United Nations objectives for the establishment of a united and independent Korea under a government chosen by the Korean people, the Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.
Autumn foliage, which is reaching the peak of its color from New England to Virginia, is tempting to pick for bouquets. The branches of crimson sweet gum and dogwood, golden tulip trees and scar- ...

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13 --The Yugoslav Government has decided to request a grant-in-aid from the United States Government for the purchase of foodstuffs to avert a crisis this winter. This decision was communicated by Premier Marshal Tito to Unit- ...

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 13--On the eve of his Far East policy conference with Gen. Douglas MacArthur, President Truman said today he was sure the people behind the Iron Curtain were as anxious for peace as he was and that he intended to get the truth to them without guns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--In a proclamation issued from the White House today, President Truman opened the way for importation of an additional 7,500,000 pounds of long-staple cotton (Egyptian type) during the quota year ending Jan. 31.
The cotton futures market was active again yesterday, and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 32 points lower to 4 points higher than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave the Public Service Commission of New York sixty days in which to let the New Haven Railroad increase commutation fares between New York City and nine points in Westchester County to the same level as interstate commutation fares.

Laymen in Protestant churches over the nation will lead and take part in religious services tomorrow in the ninth annual observance of such concerted participation under the auspices of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 13-- Intensification of efforts to enlarge and develop the Vietnamese National Army under the Bao Dai regime was indicated in an announcement here today that Gen. Boyer de la Tour du Moulin had been appointed military adviser to the Vietnamese Government.

Although the producing auspices for Sidney Kingsley's new work, "Darkness at Noon," will not be settled for a week, the Pulitzer Prize playwright sends word through his publicist, William Fields, that the attraction will have a mid-December opening on Broadway.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 13--Jules G. Evens, sales representative of Nation's Business, New York, who served with the Ranger Battalion and was a prisoner of war for fourteen months, died early today of injuries received in a fall in his garage. He was 31 years old.

Despite the last-minute pleas of the major party leaders, registration continued to fall off on the fifth day of exrollment as compared with totals for the same period last year, according to tabulations made public early today at Manhattan Police Headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--The nip-and-tuck returns received so far from Tuesday's election of Alaska's Legislature drew increasing interest here today in both Democratic and Republican camps.

James Maratta, sales promotion manager of the Alarm division of graph and Fire Alarm divisions of Dictograph Products, Inc., has been made a vice president and a director, Stanley Osserman, chairman, announced yesterday.

A refreshing note of hope and encouragement has come these last few days from the International Refugee Organization in Geneva. It is not even unduly optimistic to say that an end to the problem which I.R.O. was established to solve is hovering into sight.

WASHINGTON, Oct.13--Tighter curbs on installment buying will go into effect Monday under an amendment voted today by the Federal Reserve Board to its Regulation W. Revival of Regu lation W, used to curb inflationary spending during the war and post-war periods, was announced Sept. 8, effective Sept. 18.

The No. 1 ranking college football team of the country, Army, and Michigan's co-champions of the Western Conference come into the Yankee Stadium today for the blue-ribbon game of the season in New York.
The children's game of cops and robbers can get one into trouble if carried into adult life--even if, as in this case, one plays the game alone and is equally proficient in either role.
The Farrell Lines' vessel African Enterprise yesterday became the 194th craft sailing under the United States flag to receive the Merchant Marine Naval Reserve Pennant.
The appeal of Alger Hiss from his perjury conviction last January was taken under advisement yesterday by the three-member United States Court of Appeals after three hours of argument.
Whatever troubles Melvin Ritter experienced in his violin recital last night in Town Hall came from his program. When he played Corelli's "La Folia" or the unaccompanied.
"YES, now you too are taking a noble line," a victim of totalitarianism says to an other victim late in Mark Aldanov's new novel, "The Escape," "but you should have thought about all this earlier."

Aid of the Export-Import Bank in helping finance the emergency requirements of Brazil is urged in a resolution just adopted by the board of directors of the AmericanBrazilian Trade Council, it was made known here yesterday.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 13-- John and Sam Kinder of Plainfield shot a 35, 33--68 today to win the qualifying medal in the New Jersey Professional Golfers four-ball championship at the Montclair Golf Club.

Business loans in the New York City area have increased to another record in spite of continued attempts of Washington to curb new borrowings as an anti-inflation measure. Reports of member banks in the Federal Reserve System in New York City for the week ended Wednesday showed the out-standing ...
YONKERS, Oct. 13--Bostwick Farm's Chris Spencer, a 14-1 shot, furnished one of the biggest upsets of the current harness racing season by capturing the $25,000 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
The launching of the second of three new municipal ferryboats, which was delayed by a wildcat walkout of shipyard workers, has been set for Monday afternoon.

NEWARK, Oct. 13--Serious threats to human freedom throughout the world have arisen as a result of the capitalizing by politicians upon the popular demand for economic security, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, declared toinght.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--A new program of hospital and disability benefits for soft-coal miners and their families was announced today by the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--The National Labor Relations Board made several rulings today, all "firsts" on the subject, involving the discharge of an employs at the request of a union.

Brooklyn College and New York University each will be seeking its first victory when they meet on the Ebbets Field gridiron tonight. Kick-off time is slated for 8:30, with a crowd of about 15,000 expected.
The Thrifty-graph may become to budget-flustered housewives what Harvard University's "mechanical brain" is to scientists.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 14-- United Nations forces, in advances all along the Korean front yesterday, pushed the North Korean Communist Army back into a narrowing perimeter around the capital city of Pyongyang.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 13 (AP) --A Kachin colonel in the Burmese Army provoked laughter at the treason trial of Dr. Gordon S. Seagrave today when he said he had considered the surgeon a rebel sympathizer because the doctor never smiled at him.

Those earnestly eating ladies of the press wound up their Seventh Annual Newspaper Food Editors' Conference yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on the fifth day of meals and meetings with food manufacturers.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 13-- Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association, with a 2 over women's par 38, 40--78, over the Forest Hill Field Club course today.

Nick Barone, middleweight battler from Syracuse, defeated Jimmy Beau of New Canaan, Conn., in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas arena last night. The fight was a savage one with the crowd of 1,715 fans absorbing the action down to the final punch.

LUCKNOW, India, Oct. 13--Indian misgivings about the effectiveness of the United Nations and suspicions that the organization was a "United States stooge" and "indifferent to Asia" were apparent today in the final roundtable meeting of the eleventh International Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 13-- The Republican party in this traditionally Republican state has the edge, according to most observers, in its campaign to re-elect Senator Alexander Wiley to a third term and to put Walter J. Kohler, ...
Three new strategic links in the city's $232,000,000 arterial system will be opened formally today with ceremonies at which Governor Dewey and Acting Mayor Impellitteri will speak.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct 13--Colombia will negotiate final details of a technical assistance contract with the United Nations next week that will launch her $2,500,000,000 five-year development program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--France asked the United States today to furnish her a total of $3,170,000,000 in military assistance during the next year.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP) --The most ambitious advertising campaign in the history of the Florida citrus industry will be waged this season, W.F. Robinson of Lessburg, Florida Citrus Commission chairman, said today.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 13--The American Prison Association voted today to avoid holding future meetings in cities where racial discrimination was practiced. The new policy resulted from the refusal of the Statler Hotel, where meetings ...

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13-- Yale rules a slight favorite to defeat Columbia in a clash of unbeaten Ivy League teams tomorrow. The kick-off in the Bowl contest is scheduled for 2 P.M. A crowd of more than 35,000 is expected.
The Congress of Industrial Organizations is contemplating the formation of a department store workers' organizing committee to unionize New York clerks.

Wreckers have started razing the old Knickerbocker Ice Company's plant in Pelham, N.Y., to make way for an office building for the Esso Standard Oil Company. The property, assessed at $99,400, was purchased from the Knickerbocker concern by Esso Standard through Harry D. Cole, broker.

CHICAGO Oct. 13--Soybeans showed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today end closed about at the bottom with losses of 1 to 3 cents, due in large part to hedging sales. November sold at a new low since late last June.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13-- James P. Warburg of New York, former Deputy Director of the Office of War Information, warned here tonight that world peace could not be achieved without a "drastic hangs in American foreign policy."
CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 13--In contrast to the tranquility in Vermont over the outcome of the November election, Republican leaders in this state are worried by lingering bitterness from the primaries.

The Brooklyn Dodgers yesterday announced the sale of shortstop Clarence (Buddy) Hicks to the Phillies for an undisclosed amount of cash. The Brooks also made outright assignment of the contract of outfielder Jim Russell to their Montreal farm.

In a measure to protect freedom of the press in the Western Hemisphere, the Inter-American Press Conference voted yesterday to set up a tribunal to investigate any complaints made by its members on suppression of press freedom.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct 13 (UP) --Ernest Haycox, one of the nation's foremost Western story writers, died at his home today after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP)-- Agriculture Dgpartment planners said today that farmers were continuing to produce record-breaking egg surpluses and had failed to reduce their hen flocks even though the Government has slashed support prices.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 13 (AP)-- The Michigan Supreme Court has ruled that an interstate pipeline company may not sell natural gas direct to large industrial customers without the approval of the State Public Service Commission.
Eight hundred twenty-seven young men--of this city took physical examinations yesterday for the Army and Air Force at the induction center, 39 Whitehall Street.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 13--The Century team of Willie Goggin and Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer combined for a bestball card of 32, 34--66 at the Ardsley Country Club course today to win by two strokes in the final pro-woman tournament of the ...

At the end of last season, Coach Charley Avedisian of Horace Mann School looked forward to 1950. His team had fared moderately well in 1949, with three triumphs, a pair of setbacks and a tie, and he felt that better things were in store for his all-senior team this year.

Two hold-up men stole a $3,500 payroll yesterday from the Industrial Home for the Blind, 1000 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, and escaped in an automobile after they had been chased a block and a half by forty of the home's employes--a few of them partly sighted, the others totally blind.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 13--The impression gained from many conversations with political sources in the industrial area of northwest Ohio is that Gov. Frank J. Lausche, Democrat, and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, will be re-elected on Nov. 7.

Xavier's T-formation football team, operating behind a powerful line, overwhelmed Brooklyn Prep, 46--7, before 5,000 at Ebbets Field last night. The victory was the second for the Xavierians, whop have been tied once.

NEWARK, Oct. 13--Testimony that James Rutkin, former bootlegger, had threatened Joseph H. Reinfeld with death before the latter paid him $250,000 in biay, 1943, was corroborated in Rutkin's Federal Court trial here for income tax evasion today before Judge Thomas F. Meaney.

An astonishingly brilliant and high-spirited performance of Wagner's "Meistersinger" was given by the New York City Opera Company last night in the City Center of Opera and Drama. The achievement was the more astonishing be- ...

The Philco Corporation, one of the "big three" concerns in television-set manufacture, announced last night that it would make receivers for the Columbia Broadcasting System's color transmission method if there should be a public demand for such devices.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13 (AP)--Post-war communistic Yugoslavia has ships now building and ships afloat as a vital part of her ambitious program to modernize her economy through trade pacts with most of the western countries of the world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board hereafter will seek "discretionary" injunctions "only upon approval of the board." This is the principal change in a new delegation of board authority to be pubished tomorrow in The Federal Register.

A Republican net gain of three seats in the State Senate was predicted yesterday by Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston, Senate majority leader, despite what he described as a Democratic willingness to sacrifice their candidate for Governor to win Senate control.
BOSTON, Oct. 13--Never in danger; Fordham's football team downed Boston College, 26--6, before 10,884 persons at Braves Field tonight.

The Soviet veto on a second term for Mr. Trygve Lie might have the paradoxical effect of making him Secretary General of the United Nations for life. For if the Security Council cannot agree on Mr. Lie, it is most unlikely that they will ever reach agreement on his successor.

Aboard U.S.S. Helena, off Northeast Korea: In a fivepronged foray yesterday this heavy bombardment task group hit coastal ports of Northern Korea's East coast with their largecaliber shells exploding on prime military targets.

The pattern of military operations in Korea from here on will necessarily be dictated by the relative importance of various objectives. It now seems unlikely that there will be direct intervention by either the Chinese Communists or the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, Oct. 13--State Controlley Frank C. Moore announced today the start of a survey, ordared by Governor Dewey, to determine the need for higher teacher salaries throughout the state.

BERLIN, Oct. 13--All tremendous forces of the "cold war," ambitions and jealousies of nations, clash of ideology, restless anger of disinherited youth, met tonight as they do every night on the Potsdamerplatz, a five-sided square in the center of Berlin, which is a microcosm of the "cold war."
GENEVA, Oct. 13--Switzerland agreed today, one day before the deadline, to accept modifications requested by the United States in the 1946 trade agreement between the two countries.

LONDON, Oct. 14--The critics tried hard to be kind to "Dear Miss Phoebe," but generally could summon up only a lukewarm commendation for this setting to music of the late Sir James Barrie's play, "Quality Street."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13--The United States outlined today an occupation program for North Korea that emphasized the swiftest possible transfer of control from the military to the civilian and retained for the time being the Communist Government's land reform and socialization policies.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 (AP)--The players themselves "divvied" up their money to such an extent that their shares from the 1950 world series receipts turned out to be "a little on the low side."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--Sweeping internal reforms by the country's two major political parties to avert their possible disintegration and other "grave consequences" were recommended in a report published today.

If Governor Dewey's campaign this year has projected him in a "homey and likeable and lovable atmosphere" not apparent in his bid for the Presidency two years ago, it is because he has been talking most of the time extemporeneously.
Sixty-five years of service ended last night for the Lexington Avenue elevated line, whose eight stations cut through the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP)-- The price tag may go up on imported Chinese vases, straw rugs, embroidered handkerchiefs and gloves as a result of a proclamation signed by President Truman. So may the price of Chinese firecrackers, dried fruit and pickled duck's eggs.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13--Two conflicting trends affecting the future of Libya developed today here and in Tripoli.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13--Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, urged the United States today to give up its "new tough policy" toward the Soviet Union and return to the wartime policy of cooperation that it had followed under President Roosevelt.

VIENNA, Oct. 13--The Soviet authorities denied at today's meeting of the Allied Council that they had assisted Austrian Communists against the police in last week's disturbances and said that in any case this was no business of the Council's.
WONSAN, Korea, Oct. 13 (AP)-- North Korean Communist police killed at least 500 political prisoners in the last days of Red rule in Wonsan, some of those who escaped the slaughter said today.

A dividend of 75 cents and an extra dividend of $1 on the common stock were announced yesterday by directors of Hiram Walker, Gooderham Worts, Ltd. Both dividends will be paid on Dec. 15, to holders of record of Nov. 17.

HONG KONG, Oct. 13--The Roman Catholic Fujen University in Peiping, which has been operated by the American Fathers of the Divine Word for the last twentysix years, has been taken over by Chinese Communist authorities. Fujen is the first missionarysupported university to be appropriated by the Communists.
Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, said yesterday that the election of Justice Ferdinand Pecora, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Mayor, was a certainty.

A conference of representative newspaper editors from five continents has just been concluded in New York with a decision that could eventually have a large effect upon the relationships of the peoples of the world.

A small but lively fox outquarterbacked half a hundred opponents in the Yankee Stadium yesterday and escaped into the vast interior of the empty structure. The wily one-fox team gave, in fact, a preview of the rushing ...

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13--Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, announced today he would carry the fight against the re-election of Secretary General Trygve Lie to the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP)-- President Truman has been asked to clear the way for the drawing up of a broad new universal service program under which all youths would be trained to meet the twin threats of war and atomic attack.

Columbia's football team worked late under the lights at Baker Field yesterday as Coach Lou Little sought to come up with a defense against the new and more diversified single-wing attack of Pennsylvania, whom the Lions encounter Saturday on Columbia Homecoming Day.

The days he was freed in $75,000 bail pending the appeal of a counterfeiting conviction a former bootlegger returned to his "old profession" to become the leader of an illicit alcohol ring, the Government charged yesterday.

Unwarranted expenses imposed on motorists by "whimsical" passenger car designs were described yesterday at a national transportation meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers at the Statler Hotel.
New issues of public utility obligations amounting to $9,750,000 were sold at competitive bidding yesterday to investment banking syndicates. The awards were as follows:

Chock Full O'Nuts, operator of a chain of food shops, has leased a branch store, including a basement, in the Herald Square Building at 1350 Broadway, between West Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets.

Plans for a national advertising and merchandising program by the State of Maine's sardine industry will be advanced early in January with proposed legislation to finance the campaign with a tax on each case of sardines packed in the state, it was announced yesterday by the Maine Development Commission. The decision to seek a tax

CHICAGO, Oct. 17--The American Academy of Pediatrics announced tonight formation of a special committee on child accident prevention as the first step in a drive to cut down the death rate among youngsters.
Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for Mayor, charged last night that the Corridor Sewer System in Queens, which was originally estimated to cost $3,000,000, would cost in excess of $18,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--An order will be issued within the next few days placing specific limits on the amounts of natural and of synthetic rubber that manufacturers will be permitted to use during November and December, according to the National Production Authority.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 17--Senator Robert A. Taft, fighting for reelection, continued tonight to ignore the developments in Gov. Thomas A. Dewey's campaign in New York.

Faced with the necessity of paring seven men from the Fordham football roster he employed against Boston College, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday staged an hour-long contact drill closed to spectators in preparation for the Rams' contest Saturday with West Virginia at Morgantown. Thirty-five Rams will make the trip.
No one would be more surprised than the Swedish to discover that the new collection of modern furniture just arrived at the Urban Showroom, 524 East Fotty-third Street, is labeled "Made in Sweden."

Justice Ferdinand Pecora, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Mayor, demanded last night that his Republican rival, Edward Corsi, repudiate "the revelation of political corruption" in the letter Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley wrote Sept. 5 to W. Kingsland Macy.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 17--Organized labor and veterans organizations are joining the nation's home builders in the growing fight against credit controls on home purchases, the board of directors of the National Association of Home Builders was informed here today.
The United Nations victory in Korea was not as "easy" as it looks now, Hugh Baillie, president of The United Press, said yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 17--One of the deepest war scars on the face of London was finally healed today. Nearly nine and a half years after its destruction by German bombs the House of Commons, redesigned and reconstructed on its pre-war site, was opened for inspections.

Yankee Hill showed himself thoroughly acclimated to the New York racing atmosphere by winning the Kew Gardens Classified Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Opposing six others, the 6-year-old son of Bahram made a front-running job of it to register by a length and a half over Ted M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--The United States agreed today to give France up to $2,400,000,000 in arms and equipment during 1951 to support her rearmament effort in Western Europe and her military operations in Indo-China.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Oct. l7--Governors of the League of Red Cross Societies voted, 40 to 5, today to reject Soviet-sponsored amendments to the organization's constitution that would have had the effect of identifying the league with the World Congress of Partisans of Peace.

For the first time the Buitoni Macaroni Company is offering three of its most popular products in frozen form. Introduced to the press yesterday at a luncheon at the Buitoni Restaurant, 1562 Broadway, these newcomers are: lasagne, shell macaroni and spaghetti with meat balls.

LONDON, Oct. 17--Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin hinted today that as the strength of the West increased, an atmosphere favorable for the settlement of world problems by direct negotiation among the great powers might return.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--Alan Valentine went to work as Economic Stabilization Administrator today, believing that this country's economy was "close to danger, if not already there."

The Presidential emergency board holding fact-finding hearings on the Railway Express Agency dispute with teamsters heard union officials demand yesterday five additional holidays and premium pay at double time that could in some instances mean four days' pay for one day of work.
The oil industry yesterday joined with the city's secondary school system to close the "gap of at lease three years between the latest textbook and the practices of modern industry."

JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Oct 18--Premier David Ben-Gurion failed to create an interim Government pending national elections when early this morning the Knesset (Parliament) voted 57 to 43 against his proposed all-Mapai (Labor) party Government.
The only justification for existing shipping subsidies is the commercial and military defense of this country, Robert C. Lee, executive vice-president of Moore-McCormack Line, declared yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 17-- Delaware Democrats, who captured the State House and a United States Senate seat two years ago, are optimistic of winning the state's only seat in the House of Representatives next month.

Governor Dewey sat in his suite at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday morning and, facing a battery of newspaper men primed with questions about the letter written by Joe R. Hanley to W. Kingsland Macy, denied steadfastly that he had offered Mr. Hanley anthing to get him to withdraw as a candidate for Governor.
"Feelings of Depression," produced by the National Film Board of Canada for the mental health division of the Canadian Department of National Health and Welfare, was shown here last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 17--Proposals that capital-exporting countries aid in stimulating private capital investment in underdeveloped countries by offering tax incentives and long term raw materials' contracts were resurrected today before the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee.

The Federal Communications Commission has decided that television images in color must be transmitted by what is technically known as a "noncompatible system," meaning a system that will make it impossible for some eight million owners of television sets to receive even black-and-white from a ...

Financial circles continue to hear reports that the Federal Reserve Board will increase the reserve requirements of member banks, just as rumors flooded Wall Street recently that margin requirements would be raised on the securities markets. Neither of the reports has yet jelled, but observers agree that an increase in reserve requirements would be the next logical step in Washington's fight against inflation.

The General Assembly of the World Medical Association voted at its opening session at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday to permit its council to take action that would admit doctors in West Germany and Japan to full membership.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic and Liberal party candidate for re-election, last night told audiences of union members that their choice in the November election lay "between Republican reaction and Democratic social progress along the path charted by Franklin Roosevelt and Harry Truman."

HONG KONG, Oct. 17--Chinese Communist Premier Chou En-lai has sent a telegram to the president of the United Nations General Assembly challenging the Assembly's right to discuss the United States resolution on the "Formosa question," the Peiping radio announced today.

The stock market yesterday made up considerable ground lost in the three preceding sessions, the composite rate rising 1.02. Best gains were recorded by the rails, steels and motors, with trading emphasis also on these sections as well as on the oils.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17--The International Air Transport Association today opposed any revision of the Warsaw Convention, an international agreement limiting airlines' liability to passengers and shippers of goods.
The four mayoralty candidates will have a chance next week to see city planning as the City Planning Commission and the Citizens Budget Commission see it.

Protests against exclusion of aliens from this country under the Internal Security Act were sent yesterday to Secretary of State Dean Acheson and other Government officials by two organizations devoted to the furthering of better relations and trade between the United States and Italy.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 17 (AP)--The Port of New York Authority reported today that it had doubled the cargo load on the Newark docks in two years and said it hoped to do the same for Jersey City.
Strongly pointing up cut and line rather than detail, the furs shown yesterday at Gunther Jaeckel flowed in unbroken elegance from smoothly curved shoulders to hem.

Twenty-six New York City candidates for judicial office last night won endorsement and seventeen others, including the entire independent American Labor party slate, were termed "not qualified" by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17 --The refusal of the Greek Gov ernment to re-establish railroad communications with Yugoslavia will prove a considerable handicap to the United States Government should it decide to assist the Yugoslay people with large-scale shipments of food to offset the effects of severe drought.
BOSTON, Oct. 17--Retail trade will be good for the rest of the year, ease in the first quarter of 1951 and pick up in the second.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17-- President Truman declared tonight in this birthplace of the United Nations that the United States would continue to use its increasing strength to defeat aggression,

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 17-- Encouraged by a heavy registration and the lack of formidable Democratic candidates for local offices Republican leaders are counting on Governor Dewey to run almost as well this year in the twelve counties on the Pennsylvania border as he did four years ago.

Principal responsibility for the crash of the liner Excalibur and the Danish freighter Colombia on June 27 is charged to the passenger ship, her captain and her harbor pilot in an official Coast Guard decision made public yesterday.

James Livingston Freeborn of 21 East Tenth Street, former president of the insurance firm of Freeborn Co., 90 John Street, which he established in 1915, died yesterday at his country home, Chiddingstone, Germantown, N. Y., after a brief illness at the age of 79.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17-- "Cherchez la Frame," a detective story by Craig Rice and Stuart Palmer, has been acquired by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and assigned to William H. Wright for production as a sequel to the recently completed "Mrs. O'Malley and Mr. Malone," with James Whitmore and Marjorie Main.

Wanda Krasoff, San Francisco pianist, who gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall, proved to be a miniaturist. She often played very charmingly and she has undeniable gifts, but her emotional scope is limited.

Radiant heat "may eventually make icy pavements a thing of the past, Frederick W. Crane, Public Works Commissioner of Buffalo, said yesterday at the Public Works Congress and equipment show at the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.
UNITED STATES AIRBASE, in Japan, Wednesday, Oct. 18-- The Far East Air Forces flew 230 tons of supplies to a rapidly advancing column of the United States First Cavalry moving toward Pyongyang today.

The average Christian home is producing college students who "know nothing about the gospel of Christ," the Rev. Robert N. Rodenmayer, Protestant Episcopal chaplain of Smith College and rector of St. John's Church in Northampton, Mass., said yesterday.

The formidable task of writing a uniform contract for silk fiber purchases on an international basis was undertaken yesterday by the Second International Silk Congress in its sessions here. Each of the fifteen nations represented in the Congress, holding fifteen technical and marketing sections in New York this week, has been given three months to name a delegate for a special committee to work out such a contract.

DETROIT, Oct. 17--The entire Federal public housing program is in danger of being killed by city officials who persist in making public housing projects too elaborate, John Taylor Egan, Federal Public Housihg Administration Commissioner, told the seventeenth annual conference of the National Association of Housing Officials here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--The Navy announced today that two additional minesweepers had been sunk by mines off Korea with a toll of one crewman killed, twelve listed as missing and seventy-nine injured.
I have just returned from Wake Island, where I had a very satisfactory conference with General Douglas MacArthur.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 17 (AP)-A greater demand for cherry wood was reported today at the Jamestown Fall Furniture Market. Its unexpected popularity is causing production problems as not much cherry is on hand.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)--A $100,000-a-year bank president testified today that a showing of "calloused hands" has frequently been all his institution required to grant a borrower a loan.

Arturo Toscanini will not conduct the first three concerts of the N. B. C. Symphony's regular winter season. The 83-year-old maestro has invited Fritz Reiner to take his place on the podium for the programs of Oct. 23, 30 and Nov. 6.
Operations of the Libbey-OwensFord Glass Company in the first nine months of this year resulted in net earnings of $22,057,172, according to the report yesterday of John D. Biggers, president.

MIAMI, Wednesday, Oct. 18 (UP)--A hurricane smashed into the Miami winter playground early today with winds of up to 125 miles an hour. The storm's center moved inland over the metropolis soon after midnight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17-- A few weeks ago Herman Hickman, Yale's rotund football coach, received an ominous telegram from Watkins Glen, N. Y., where the team manager, Charles Murphy, had gone to secure hotel accommodations for the Elis' trip this week-end to oppose Cornell.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17-- A few weeks ago Herman Hickman, Yale's rotund football coach, received an ominous telegram from Watkins Glen, N. Y., where the team manager, Charles Murphy, had gone to secure hotel accommodations for the Elis' trip this week-end to oppose Cornell.

The novelist is never a "mere' story-teller, but always, consciously or not, a critic besides, Somerset Maugham told fifty members of the National Institute of Arts and Letters at a private dinner last night in the Knickerbocker Club, 2 East Sixty-second Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17--Aggressive buying, of soybean futures featured trading on the Board of Trade here today, with closing prices up 2 to 2 cents a bushel. The upturn in soybeans helped to sustain other grains with wheat 1/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel lower; corn unchanged to cent a bushel lower; oats cent a bushel higher to cent Lower, and rye 1/8 to 3/8 cent a bushel higher.

LAURELL, Md., Oct. 17 (AP)--Sylvester W. Labrot's Arcave defeated Bobanet Stable's Attention Mark, the even-money favorite, by a half length in the $4,000 Pentagon Purse, opening-day feature here today.

Six thousand American artists, both here and abroad, responded to the invitation of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to enter its national competition offering $8,500 in prizes, the museum announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17--Capt. Dan Gilbert, chief investigator for the Cook County state's attorney's office since 1932 and Democratic candidate for county sheriff, told the Senate Crime Investigating committee today that he amassed his $360,000 fortune by speculating in stocks and grains, and promised to submit his books to the Chicago Crime Commission.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 17-- South Korean Foreign Minister Ben C. Limb today told a closed meeting of the United Nations Interim Committee on Korea that his Government was alarmed over reports that the United Nations favored elections for all Korea.

Dedicated to the laudable proposition of purveying palatable entertainment (the guise doesn't matter), the managerial team of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d will introduce "Burning Bright" at 8 o'clock this evening at the Broadhurst.
PUSAN, Wednesday, Oct. 18-- The first elements of a Turkish brigade of 5,190 men began landing here this morning.

A thoroughly worthwhile and encouraging example of educational television, about which so much has been heard and so little done, can be seen now at 8:30 Tuesday nights in a program originating from the campus of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.

Abraham Feingold, the third of eight public school teachers to be tried for insubordination, took the witness stand yesterday but refused to say whether he was or ever had been a member of the Communist party. He was the first accused teacher to testify in his own defense.

STRANGE things have been happening in football, as any one can readily see by noting where Notre Dame is currently ranked. It isn't only that so many of the big fellows have been getting their come-uppance, and getting it in many cases from teams that weren't supposed to amount to a tuppence.
MADRID, Oct. 17--Students of the Spanish Government engineering schools are on strike, and student sources said today that they had voted to remain out until the Government met their demands.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 17--"The nation's superb food production 'les out any need at this time for a system of food controls," Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan told members of the National Association of Food Chains at a luncheon here today in the Netherland Plaza, Hotel at the organization's seventeenth annual meeting. Mr. Brannan spoke on "Food in the Nation's Mobilization."

TORONTO, Oct. 17 (AP)--For the second time in four days a major Canadian newsprint producer increased prices $10 a ton today and publishing sources believed an industry-wide price boost is in the making. Abitibi Power and Paper Company announced a $10 increase effective Nov. 1, on the heels of similar action by Powell River Paper Company at Vancouver. Other big Canadian producers had no comment.
Television manufacturers took two positive steps yesterday to upset the Federal Communications Commission's order approving the Columbia Broadcasting System color method.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 17-- An intensive study of the military and political situation in IndoChina faced Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin, French Resident General in Morocco, and Jean Letourneau, French Minister for the Far Eastern Associated States, following their arrival here this afternoon by plane from Paris.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 17--The Netherlands will be represented at the coming Washington meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty defense ministers by Hendrick L.'s Jacob, 44-year-old financial expert, whose appointment has stilled the storm over defense policy that finally blew his predecessor, William F. Schokking, out of office.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 17--The United States today proposed a "United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency" to direct longrange relief and rehabilitation in Korea. It would be headed by a "United Nations Agent General."

Market prices for United States Government securities receded further yesterday in adjustment to a move of the Federal Reserve Bank to restrict its open market purchases through the expedient of lowering its bids.
The Organization for Rehabilitation and Training is the "Point Four Program of Jewish life," Dr. William Haber, acting president of the American O.R.T. Federation, declared yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 17--City Commissioners here adopted today an ordinance calling for the registration of all Communists and members of "other subversive organizations" who live or work here, or who pass through the city regularly.

Negotiations for an international bout between Roland La Starza, promising Bronx heavyweight, and either Jack Gardner, top contender for Bruce Woodcock's English crown, or the veteran Tommy Farr, were launched yesterday.

An East Side property that once was part of the Peter Stuyvesant farm passed to new control yesterday when the Petersfield Realty Corporation sold 93, 95 and 97 Third Avenue consisting of three five-story store and apartment buildings on plot 52 by 100 feet between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets.
LONDON, Oct. 18--The new bookkeeping account opened cheerfully on the stock markets here today with rises in nearly all sections.

PARIS, Oct. 18--Without a formal demand, a vote of confidence will be implicit in the motion that the Government will support at the close of the National Assembly debate expected to last through three full sittings tomorrow on the situation in Indo-China.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 18 (UP) --Calling a person a Communist is libelous per se and is subject to action in court, the Ohio Supreme Court held in effect today.

The New York Life Insurance Company is preparing to enter the field of personal accident and health insurance, it was announced yesterday by George L. Harrison, chairman of the board.

The Dionne quintuplets--now "grown-up" girls of 16--came to New York last night for the first time, and the noisy acclaim they received from 2,500 welcomers at the Grand Central Terminal was in the best Manhattan tradition.
The playing of Frank Glazer, pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall was of absorbing interest and communicative power. This was the third recital that Mr. Glazer has given here within as many seasons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--A new-type loan designed to help private enterprises, large or small, in various parts of the world, has been approved by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, it was announced today.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs registered their first National Hockey League victory of the new season with a third-period attack that gave them a 2-0 shutout over the Boston Bruins tonight before 9,039 fans at Boston Garden.

For more than three years the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund has been working miracles in saving the lives of some five or six million children, mostly in Europe, because that is where the war-born emergency existed.

HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Long Island's top entrant, Al Brosch, captured the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Willows Country Club today with a 36-hole score of 136, six under par.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18--A budget of $1,413,400 was adopted here today by 1,000 delegates at the closing session of the silver jubilee convention of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America to carry on the forty-nine activities sponsored in Israel by the religious Zionist group.
Joe Louis, former world heavyweight champion, will make his second start back up the fistic trail when he fights Cesar Brion of Argentina in a ten-round bout Nov. 29 in Chicago Stadium.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 18 (AP) --A military source said today that two Egyptians, one Iraqi and a Palestinian had been arrested in connection with an abortive attempt last week on the life of Syria's Assistant Chief of Staff, Col. Adib Shishekly.

Five passenger liners, carrying 1,005 aliens who were cleared for entry into this country before the Government order freezing visas was issued last Thursday are scheduled to arrive here between today and Sunday, according to the steamship companies involved.
With continued heavy trading, the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 45 to 99 points net lower than on Tuesday, reversing the performance of the previous day.

Eva Likova replaced an indisposed Dorothy MacNeil in the role of Liu in last night's performance of "Turandot" at the City Center. The St. Regis Paper Company yesterday reported a net profit of $7,003,924, equal to $1.24 a common share, for the nine months ended on Sept. 30.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 18--Immediate steps should be taken to increase the water supply of the northern metropolitan area of New Jersey by 100,000,000 gallons daily, a group of engineers and water agency officials reported today to the State Water Policy and Supply Council.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18--The United States today gave to the United Nations a preliminary estimate that $200,000,000 would be needed in 1951 for relief and rehabilitation in Korea.
Vice President Alben W. Barkley will be the main speaker at a Tammany Hall rally to be held at Cooper Union on the night of Oct. 28.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP)-- The Government will re-examine 700 applications for non-Federal public works projects to see if they contribute to national defense or are essential civilian programs.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Oct. 18-- Chief Justice Oswald Bancroft presided this morning at a hearing on the application by fifty-one creditors to wind up the affairs of Butlin's Bahamas, Ltd. Butlin's counsel said the company is still trying to raise money to pay creditors.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 18-- Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hall have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Rose, to Lawrence Hugh Kelly of New Rochelle, N.Y., son of Henry J. Kelly of Dun Laoghaire, County Dublin, Ireland, and the late Mrs. Kelly.

The Brooklyn Young Women's Christian Association residence at 221 Ashland Place, Brooklyn, will close today. The property, which served as a Negro branch and since 1942 has housed thirty-two girls, has been sold for hotel purposes. Accommodations for all occupants have been found in other Y.W. C.A. residences or through the Y.W.C.A. room registry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--Members of Congress from cotton-producing areas launched a movement today to set the minimum price of American cotton at the world market level.

Long Island College Hospital has named Hugh H. Cuthrell a member of its board of regents, which is responsible for the administration of the hospital. Mr. Cuthrell is vice president of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.

ROME, Oct. 18 (AP)--Pope Pius has composed a special prayer to be said after he proclaims the dogma of the bodily assumption into heaven of the Virgin Mary. The proclamation will be made Nov. 1 at what probably will be the most colorful ceremony of the 1950 Holy Year.
A 28-year-old former Army sergeant pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to passing vital defense information to a Russian atom spy ring in wartime.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 18--German military planning is concentrating on an eventual Government contribution to the European defense force, if and when German rearmament is permitted.

Earnings of Rheem Manufacturing Company for the first nine months of 1950 were $3,468,722, equal to $3.39 a common share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with earnings of $1,821, 237, or $1.73 a share for the corresponding nine months of 1949.

Possibility of a Senate investigation of the charges that Governor Dewey is involved in a promise of a state job for Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley and financial pressure to get him to retire as a candidate for Governor and accept the Republican nomination for Senator was seen yesterday.

A raid on a one-family Bronx house yesterday afternoon led to the smashing of an estimated $2,500,000-a-year policy ring whose members were said to have "muscled in" on the Harlem numbers racket a month ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The Treasury announced today it will permit life insurance companies to put into reserves, tax free, 93.55 per cent of their income from investments.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 18 (AP) --The first-round matches in the sixth annual Hardscrabble women's open golf tournament closely followed form today.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 18 --H. Gardiner Symonds of Houston, Tex., president of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, has been elected to the board of trustees of Smith College. He will take office at a meeting Friday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18--India moved today to open the whole question of the next Secretary General of the United Nations by suggesting to the Security Council that each of its eleven members submit new candidates for the Big Five countries to examine and weed out in secret ballot.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (Reuters)-- The British Government today rejected a proposal that it should ban all future exports of rubber to the Soviet Union and Communist-controlled countries until Communist guerrilla activities in Malaya cease. Sir Jocelyn Lucas, Conservative, made the proposal in Parliament but the Colonial Secretary, James Griffiths, said that he could not accept it.
Bernard Shaw's "Arms and the Man" will be revived this evening at the Arena in the Hotel Edison as the fourth attraction of the team of David Heilweil and Derrick Lynn-Thomas.

Mr. and Mrs. Van Vechten Burger of 21 East Eighty-seventh Street, and Cedarhurst, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beverly, to Lawrence Alexandre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Alexandre of Cedarhurst.
The First Boston Corporation and Salomon Brothers Hutzler will offer to investors today $3,750,000 of new twenty-five-year notes of the New Bedford Gas and Edison Light Company.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 18 (Reuters)--Indonesian troops have begun an offensive against guerillas in the south Celebes, west of the Moluccas, where as rebel group has set up an "idependent republic," a communique said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18-- James K. Knudson, newly appointed director of the Defense Transportation Administration, said here today that the rationing soon of steel for civilian automobiles is "almost certain."

GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa, Oct. 18 (Reuters)--Fortune Gordien of San Francisco, holder of the world record, broke the South African discus mark for the eighth time today. The touring American track and field team beat Grahamstown by nine events to two. Gordien had a throw of 162 feet 9 5/8 inches. His previous best in South Africa was 161 feet 8 inches.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 (AP)--The Maryland Drydock Company reopened today after employes ratified a new contract and ended a strike that had kept the ship repair yard closed sixty-nine days.

The National Finance Council of the Jewish Welfare Board, at its annual meeting in the Stevens Hotel, Chicago, will be addressed tomorrow by Frank L. Weil, chairman of the President's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Forces.
Sales and billings of the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., for the nine months ended Aug. 31 were $7,000,000 above those a year before but earnings were down $406,736, the concern reported yesterday.

"A courageous church of broad vision" is essential to determine "if we are to have a Christian era or a pagan era," the Right Rev. Henry K. Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, said yesterday.

Real estate sales in the Bronx for the third quarter of this year averaged 99 per cent of valuations, showing an increase of four points above the second quarter, according to the Taxpayers Service Company.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 18 (AP)--Screened by typhoon weather, French troops menaced by Vietminh forces have abandoned the frontier post of Dongdang, on a major route from Communist China.

Plans for the first bridge to link Italy with Sicily across the Strait of Messina have been completed and forwarded to Italian authorities. This was announced yesterday by D.B. Steinman, bridge engineer of 117 Liberty Street, who prepared the plans.
The unaudited report of the American Woolen Company revealed yesterday a substantial improvement in sales and earnings for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30.

Johnny Johnson established a new St. John's record of 26:32 for five miles in leading the Redmen's cross-country team to victory, 18-- 39, over Montclair State Teachers at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, St. John's also beat Montclair in the freshman event, 15--49.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has sent $6,682,774 for patient care to fortyfour states and Alaska so far this year.

Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley resumed the offensive in his campaign for the Senate last night with a charge that the Democratic National Administration had fostered higher living costs by "manufacturing" a "phony" devalued dollar to avoid economizing in Washington.

Eugene Pearsall has sold the two-story one-family house at 604 East Thirty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, to James V. Surace. The Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association made a purchase money mortgage of $8,000 in connection with the transaction.

AFTER many years of observation, covering just about every phase of hunting on the continent, we are convinced that the average hunter is willing to undergo considerable discomfort provided he can look like a hunter.

Edward W. Ernst, 57 years old, of 2092 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, an unemployed bookkeeper, was booked last night at the Bathgate Avenue police station on a grand larceny charge in the theft of $16,250 in jewelry from a traveler in Grand Central Terminal a week ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The announcement by the Navy League yesterday that Navy Day would be revived as a national celebration on Oct. 27 was news to the Navy.

Col. Miles H. Knowles has been appointed vice president of the United States Radiator Corporation in charge of its defense production activities, Wesley J. Peoples, chairman and president, announced yesterday. During World War II Colonel Knowles was assigned to the Secretary of War's office and handled Congressional investigations. He will make his office in Washington.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Four carloads of police were called today to Government rent control offices as a crowd of some 100 landlords demonstrated, protesting delay in decontrolling rents here. Police were called when three of the group forced their way into the office of Ben Koepke, area director.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 19 (AP)--Mrs. Yvette Madsen served notice today that she would ask the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals to set aside her murder conviction.

For the first time on record a book by a celebrated author is being published in the same week as the production of a play derived from it. Net income of the Consolidated Railroads of Cuba and subsidiaries for the year ended June 30 was $1,563,767, compared with $1,500,854 in the previous fiscal year. Cuba Northern Railways Company,...
PARIS, Oct. 19--By a vote of 349 to 218, the French National Assembly tonight gave its confidence to the Government's policy in Indo-China.

Miss Mary Katherine Bail, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest B. Bail of Albuquerque, N.M., was married to Herbert Wilson Hoskins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoskins of Fairfield, Conn., yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Columbia University. The Rev. Frederick T. Schumacher, instructor in religion at Columbia, performed the ceremony.
The November election will help determine the fate of the world, Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for reelection, asserted last night.

Three new appointments in the carbide and carbon chemicals division of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation at South Charleston, W.Va., were announced yesterday. Dr. Edward W. Rugeley has been named technical director...
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 19-- Eastern Oregon and Reed Colleges agreed today to a postseason football game early in December if both preserve their record of not winning.
SEGUIN, Texas, Oct. 19 (UP)-- An Air Force B-29 Superfortress, afire in the air, crashed in a pasture near here today and exploded. All of the eight men aboard were killed.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19--The Budget Committee of the United Nations General Assembly gave its approval today to an $800,000 loan from the working capital fund to the Food and Agriculture Organization to help defray in part the expenses of moving the organization's headquarters from Washington to Rome.

The State of New Jersey announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Oct. 31 on an issue of $25,000,000 of state institutional construction bonds. Dated Nov. 1, 1950, the bonds will be due on Nov. 1, 1952 to 1965. They are callable Nov. 1, 1962.

OTTAWA, Oct. 19 (UP)--More than 1,000 Canadians had incomes exceeding $50,000' in 1948, the National Revenue Department showed today in its annual tax statistics report. At the other end of the income scale, 28,140 persons earned less than $800.

United Paramount Theatres, Inc., in its third quarter report issued yesterday by Leonard H. Goldenson, president, disclosed consolidated earnings of $2,528,000 and share of undistributed earnings of partially owned non-consolidated companies of $569,000, for a total of $3,097,000.

LONDON, Oct. 19--Sir Stafford Cripps resigned today as British Chancellor of the Exchequer. His health, he told Prime Minister Clement Attlee, no longer could stand the strain of directing Britain's financial and economic affairs.
Senator Eduardo Frei, Chilean delegate to the United Nations, is scheduled to speak at a luncheon of the Pan American Women's Association tomorrow at the Town Hall.

The election of Allin B. Crouch to the office of vice president and controller of the Irving Trust Company, New York, was announced yesterday. Mr. Crouch, now assistant controller of General Electric Company, will take over his new post on Nov. 15.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP) --Ernest L. Owen, president and publisher of The Post-Standard, tonight announced his resignation effective Jan. 1.
Sidney Rubin has purchased the one-family dwelling at 249 Bay Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, from Charles Landwehr. Slomka Brothers were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP)-- The Federal Communications Commission today scheduled an investigation of charges that the Amercican Telephone Telegraph Co. unduly favored two large Television networks in allocating its cross-country television transmission facilities.

Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, has followed the lead of Madison Square Garden in denying use of its facilities to organizations listed as subversive by the Attorney General.

Mrs. Sinclair Hatch is chairman of the committee in charge of the arrangements for the annual harvest bazaar in behalf of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity to be held on Nov. 9 and 10 in the parish house of the church at 316 East Eighty-eighth Street.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 (UP)--A Federal Communications Commission hearing into charges that news broadcasts over Los Angeles radio station KMPC were slanted came to a close here today but will resume next month in Detroit.

Vice President Alben W. Barkley arrived just before noon yesterday at LaGuardia Airport from Indianapolis on a chartered United Air Lines DC 6. In an interview, he predicted that the Democrats in the coming election would register gains in both Houses of Congress.
Bank clearings for the twentyfive leading cities of the nation for the holiday week ended on Wednesday amounted to $15,430,837,000 according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The turnover was 3.6 ...
RIO DE JANIRO, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Congress moved today to break the juicy racket on imports of United States cars by which speculators have been netting huge profits for months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--A Senate investigating subcommittee learned today that about 500,000 gallons of motor lubricating oil had been shipped from Japan to Communist China since the outbreak of the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--This is the classic period in political battles when imprudent letters or those written in a context which has changed embarrassingly fall into hands unfriendly to the authors and are made public in the hope of taking from them votes they otherwise might have counted on.

Explosive on the attack and opportunistic on defense, the New York Yanks scored in every period last night to whip the Green Bay Packers, 35--17, before 13,661 paying spectators at Yankee Stadium. It was the fourth straight triumph for Red Strader's squad, which...

NEWARK, Oct. 19--Eleven thousand telephone operators in New Jersey, members of Division 55 of the Communication Workers of America, C.I.O., have voted by a ratio of 20 to 1 to approve the eighteen months' contract agreed to between officials of the union and the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company on Oct. 6.

Brig. Gen. Ephraim F. Jeffe will retire as a vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company on Oct. 31. He joined the former Brooklyn Edison Company as an assistant power engineer in 1916. In the first World War he served with the American Expeditionary Force.

CORINTH, Miss., Oct. 19 (UP)-- Mrs. Ima Barkley Denker, sister of Vice President Barkley, was married here today to Edgar Ruffin Brown of Tuscumbia and Sheffield, Ala., in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. James Irion of Jackson, Tenn., the bride's nephew.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The Government's inability to get qualified men to take necessary posts, and not political considerations, is holding back work on wage and price controls, President. Truman told his news conference today.

Plans for a $75,000 shopping center to serve the 322 homes in their Hillside Terrace-at-Albertson development in Albertson, L.I., were announced yesterday by Joseph Carillo, Joseph Wanes and Samuel Levin.
Former President Herbert Hoover appeared in excellent health as he gave a firm and vigorous delivery of his prepared address.

Prof. Sumner Slichter of Harvard is one of our most prolific and stimulating writers and speakers in the general field of economics. But Professor Slichter is no exception to the rule that the more stimulating the teacher the more likely it is that every so often his ingenuity will outrun his good sense.

Directors of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company increased the dividend on the common stock yesterday with the declaration of $1 a share for payment on Nov. 15. The company had been paying 75 cents quarterly since February, 1946.
Official word came from the Playwrights Company yesterday that "Darkness at Noon," Sidney Kingsley's adaptation of Arthur Koestler's book of the same name, would be produced by them right away.

New York is suffering from a serious shortage of nurses who have had training in psychiatric work or experience in caring for the mentally ill, Miss Adele Poston, director of the Psychiatric Nurses Bureau, 145 East Thirtyfifth Street, declared yesterday. Miss Poston urged nurses with such training to call the bureau at MUrray Hill 3-1077.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19-- Grover Loening, veteran aviation engineer and aeronautical consultant, today was named the 1950 winner of the Wright Brothers Memorial Trophy.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, asserted yesterday that the political difficulties of the Israeli Government would not alter "the basic democratic policies of the Jewish state, and particularly the all-important open-door policy for immigrants."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The United States charged Rumania today with following a "deliberate policy" of insulting and harassing United States officials in that Country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--A radio station must maintain "a continuous and positive control" over its programs, the Federal Communications Commission ruled today.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 19 (AP)--A new storm began to develop in the Gulf of Mexico today while Florida took another look at damage created by Wednesday's hurricane and revised loss estimates upward to $15,000,000.

Since 1920 the number of clerical workers required to handle the same amount of production throughout the country has increased 125 per cent. On this basis, office administration costs are too high, compared with factory production costs, it was pointed out...

Prices of most commodity futures on the exchanges here yesterday turned higher, with crude rubber and the non-ferrous metals leading the way. Rubber futures reversed their trend of Wednesday and shot forward the permissible limit of 200 points, or 2 cents a pound, in active trading of 800 tons.

The recent charge by Republican Mayoralty candidate Edward Corsi that assessments for the Queens corridor sewer were being held up until after election brought a denial yesterday from Borough President Maurice A. Fitzgerald of Queens.

The United Lutheran Synod of New York and its 400 churches will commemorate the birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler that fell yesterday by seeking to raise additional funds for the fellowship fund he established.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 19 (AP) --An arbitration court today boosted minimum wages in Australia effective the first pay day in November. This will mean an increase of four shillings (44 cents)...

Fred Zinneman, the Hollywood director who made "The Search," an American film produced in Europe about the plight of displaced children, yesterday was presented with the British Film Academy award for the best film embodying the principles of the United Nations Charter.
MONTE CARLO, Oct. 19-- Justice Emil Sandstroem, president of the Swedish Red Cross, was elected chairman of the League of Red Cross Societies today for the next two years.

Mainly because of the increase in purchases of family income plans and other special protection policies, term insurance ownership in the United States has nearly trebled in the last seven years to the record level of $15,000,000,000, exclusive of group insurance.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 19-- Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission and coordinator of New York City's Public Works, issued today a blistering reply to Nassau County Democratic critics of the new $8,000,000 Atlantic Beach Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Weekly earnings of 13,000,000 factory production workers continued at the record average of $60.53 in September, preliminary estimates of the Bureau of Labor Statistics indicated today.

Eugene Lilly yesterday was elected vice president of Bellows Co., Inc., wholesale food and liquor distributor. He has been in charge of Bellows operations in Colorado and adjoining states since 1934 and will continue to make his headquarters in Colorado Springs.
Ten states in this area will receive a total of $1,126,000 more this fiscal year from the Federal Government than they received last year for special services for children.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--President Truman said today that the Department of Defense and the White House were trying to work out a policy on military reservists that would be equitable and fair to all. The Chief Executive also expressed his scorn of employers who discriminated against reservists, and said with great sarcasm that that was a patriotic thing to do.
The waterfront of Boston was idle yesterday afternoon while 1,000 longshoremen voted on a reported "ultimatum" from employing stevedores, it was learned here last night.
A good deal of defensive football was stressed to the N.Y.U. squad yesterday as Coach Hugh Devore began the last stages of preparation for the clash with Rutgers tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The first project under the Point Four program for aiding underdeveloped countries will start in Iran with a $500,000 allotment for improving health, agriculture and education.
A taxicab driver was robbed not only of his money but also of all his clothes by two hold-up men, who ousted him naked from his cab yesterday about 4 A.M., the police reported.
BOSTON, Oct. 19--Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, president of Boston University, anounced tonight his retirement, after twenty-five years in office, on Feb. 1, 1951, the anniversary of his presidency.
Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley told a group of Harlem ministers yesterday that were it not for his "Unshakable faith" in God's mercy he would be "a miserable creature."
