Reversing the downward trend of the last few weeks, pork prices are pushing upward again with advances of 4 cents on two cuts. Most other meats are unchanged but at wholesale increases occurred on beef, veal and lamb as well as pork, indicating that higher retail rates may be expected shortly.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19--Production of canned meats under Federal inspection during the first nine months of this year was about 20 per cent greater than in the same period last year, the American Meat Institute announced today.

The fourth annual General Assembly of the World Medical Association, composed of thirty-nine national medical associations with a membership of nearly 500,000 physicians, ended its sesssions at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday with the election of Dr. Dag Knutson of Djursholm, Sweden, as its president-elect for 1950-1951.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP) --Three attendants at Canandaigua Veterans Hospital who were among nine accused of assaulting hospital patients pleaded guilty today as their trials were ready to open in Federal court.

Henry Epstein, former Solicitor General, in a radio address over WJZ in which he urged the election of Justice Ferdinand Pecora as Mayor, attacked the candidacy of Acting Mayor Impellitteri as one sponsored "by the old cast-off leaders of Tammany."

ALEXANDRIA, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Egypt's cotton market has replaced the American exchanges as regulator of world cotton prices, Ahmed Hilmy Bey, Government Cotton Commissioner, asserted today. In an address to brokers and traders on the Alexandria Cotton Exchange floor he said:

PARIS, Oct. 19--Two Communist sailors were sentenced today to five years in prison and dishonorable discharge from the French Navy by a military tribunal in Toulon, one for having demoralized members of the armed forces and the other for having tried to sabotage the aircraft carrier Dixmude.

Dr. W.E.B. DuBois, American Labor party candidate for United States Senator, charged last night in a broadcast over station WMCA that the record of both the Democratic-controlled Eighty-first Congress and the Republican-controlled Eightieth proved that neither major party was willing to enact civil rights leeislation.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19-- Governor Dewey today denounced Democratic state administrations for failing to provide higher education facilities.

Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, retired head of the atomic bomb project, told the Systems and Procedures Association here last night that the start of war depended solely on Joseph Stalin's conviction that he could win if he struck, with or without the atomic bomb.

A group of sixty-five mothers, accompanied by children of grade school age, converged yesterday on City Hall to protest against the transfer of 200 pupils from Public School 188, East Houston and Lewis Streets, to P.S. 4 at Pitt and Rivington Streets.
Bernard M. Kapell has been named a field consultant of the American Heart Association. He was formerly assistant national director of the military welfare service of the American Red Cross.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 19 (UP)-- The name of a Newark soldier accused of being absent without leave was cleared today in a tragic vindication.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The Justice Department has ordered members of the Spanish Falangist party barred from the United States, ruling that they are "totalitarians" inadmissible under the terms of the new Internal Security Act.

The swift penetration of the North Korean Communist capital of Pyongyang marks another important development of the campaign for the freedom of Korea. The defense of the ground between the old Thirty-eighth Parallel and the capital and the defense of the capital itself was less determined than had been expected or feared.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19 (AP)--Yugoslavia's official press charged Bulgaria today with new tactics of aggression and sabotage --by fire. The newspaper Politika said a Bulgarian soldier in Macedonia touched off a grass fire, expecting a gale to sweep it into a Yugoslav forest. It added that residents limited the damage.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19-- Deputy Foreign Minister Jacob A. Malik of the Soviet Union said some optimistic words about the future today in the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19--Chicago's record-breaking autumn heat wave today forced postponement of a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--President Truman upheld today the Department of Agriculture's new cotton export curbs. Cotton state growers and legislators had attempted to bring about relaxation of the ruling which would hold exports through March of next year down to 4,000,000 bales.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19--The Albanian Government submitted today another protest to United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie, accusing Greece of six more border violations. The protest charged that in one instance a Greek plane crossed the frontier.

ALBANY, Oct. 19--Counsel for Acting Mayor Impellitteri of New York City contended before the Court of Appeals today that the winner of the Mayoralty election should not be "flung headlong into the office" without time to "prepare for taking over his onerous duties."
The gambling spotlight shifted yesterday from Brooklyn to New Jersey, where State Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons ordered an investigation of organized betting in Bergen County.

Eddie Arcaro rode off with jockey-of-the-day honors yesterday at old Jamaica, where the Empire City Racing Association teed off on the four-week meeting that will bring the New York turf campaign to a close. The maestro had five mounts, four winners.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19 (UP) --Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, urged today that the United Nations Charter be revised to incorporate a definite code of international law and justice.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Oct. 19 (AP) --A search party today found the body of Q.E. Hooks, 29-yearold tourist-court operator who drowned while on a hunting trip with three companions. Winds capsized their boat yesterday.
Big industries in the New York area are seeking two new kinds of priorities from the Government to remove two gaps in the present national defense materials control program.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 (Reuters)-- The West Berlin City Assembly decided today to abolish the death penalty in the three Western sectors. Its action brings West Berlin in line with West Germany, where the death penalty was abolished under the Federal Constitution adopted more than a year ago.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, will be the principal speaker at the seventieth annual dinner of the City College Alumni Association. The dinner will be held at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel on Nov. 4.
Tom Bienemann of Drake nabbed nine forward passes last Saturday to wrest national pass-catching honors from Denver's Gordon Cooper, the Associated Press reported yesterday.

The amount of manganese imported in the first half of this year was equal to 80 per cent of the 1949 total, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Imports from Russia have been negligible so far this year. However, in six months India nearly equaled...
A duplex apartment in the cooperative at 7 Gracie Square has been sold by the Madison Realty Company to William A. Smith, through Cross Brown, Inc., brokers.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 20--The Soviet Government today accused the Big Three Western powers of contemplating the revival of the regular German Army and warned that Russia "will not tolerate such measures."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)-- L.M. Giannini denied today that his family controls the Bank of America or the Transamerica Corporation, West Coast financial institutions founded by his father, the late A.P. Giannini.

ALBANY, Oct. 19--Representative W. Kingsland Macy said tonight he did not know what effect publication of the Hanley letter would have on Republican chances in this state, but felt it would not affect the large Republican majorities piled up each year in his county.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 19--The Navy has developed the first completely mobile underwater motion picture camera that is entirely independent of surface assistance, a naval spokesman said today.

General Eisenhower's imaginative plan for an "American Assembly" should meet a warm response from all who are concerned with the future course of the nation's political and economic policy. It should appeal to every citizen who seeks an honest answer to the formidable problems, domestic and foreign, that are piling up in front of our democracy.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 20--United States and South Korean troops fought their way today into the heart of Pyongyang, Communist capital of North Korea, against lessening resistance of enemy rear guards.

The stock market made several feeble attempts yesterday to push its advance but each time ran into profit-taking. The final hour produced a mild upturn, which was sustained to some extent, but the composite rate showed a loss of 0.20 point on the day.
BERLIN, Oct 19 (UP)--The Russians have uncovered a new and abundant uranium deposit near Zwickau, fifty miles south of Leipzig, the Neue Zeitung reported today.

A United States soldier with front-line troops in Korea has sent $50 to the building fund of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center. The donor, the center announced yesterday, is Capt. Sanford L. Max, a doctor in the Fifteenth Medical Battalion, a unit serving with the First Cavalry Division in the battle for the Communist capital of Pyongyang.

Dimitri Mitropoulos' policy as principal conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this season is to give each series one program of familiar works and a succeeding one with something contemporary and perhaps problematical on it.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 19--An official of the American Bar Association today branded as "utterly without foundation" an accusation that its Committee on Peace and Law Through the United Nations had used for improper purposes a grant of $15,000 made to it by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

Immediate anti-trust action against any United States newsprint mill that follows the lead of two Canadian mills in raising prices has been urged in a letter sent to United States Attorney General J. Howard McGrath by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--A hearing on proposed increases in commuter fares on the Baltimore Ohio and Pennsylvania Railroads in the District of Columbia, Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia was set today for Nov. 15. The increases were to become effective Sept. 15, but on Sept. 13 the commission suspended them until April 14, 1951.
The Stage Relief Fund, theatrical charity organization, will benefit from a special performance to be given on Sunday evening, Oct. 29, by "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" at the Ziegfeld Theatre.

SCOTIA, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP)-- Dr. Robert E. Doherty, president emeritus of Carnegie Institute of Technology at Pittsburgh, died here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.
ALBANY, Oct. 19-About 4,000 New York servicemen and women will be eligible to cast war ballots in the November election, the Division of Servicemen's Voting estimated today.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, state director of civil defense, told the New York chapter of the American RedCross yesterday that "the Red Cross will contribute more to civil defense than any other agency I know of."

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 19 (AP)--The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers today selected Seattle, Wash., for its 1952 biennial convention and re-elected all its officers at the closing of the thirty-sixth biennial convention. There were 2,750 delegates here.

A series of plays for children, in which adult professional actors take the part of animals, will be presented by Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street, Mrs. Sam T. Green, educational director of Christ Church, announced yesterday. The first play, "The Adventures of Kiki, the Monkey," will be presented at 1 P.M. today on the stage of the parish hall.

OTTAWA, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press)--The 1950 wheat crop on Canada's prairies was placed today by the Federal Statistics Bureau at 430,000,000 bushels as of Oct. 1, down 25,000,000 from a previous estimate of 455,000,000.

Inez Palma is a pianist who places communication before technical prowess. When it is successful--as it often was in her Town Hall recital last night--this commendable approach can be effective indeed.

The Furriers Joint Council, representing fur workers in this city, called on fur manufacturers yesterday to meet with the union in an effort to curb price rises in the fur industry. The union complained that a few dealers in raw furs were resorting to "unbridled and unconscionable profiteering."

The Shell Chemical Corporation has named F.S. Swackhamer manager of its Eastern division sales development department. Mr. Swackhamer, formerly assistant manager of the department, succeeds W.S. Lewis L. Fawcett, former Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice, and Mrs. William H. Good were elected to the board of directors of the Park Association of New York City yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Banker's Club, 120 Broadway.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 19 (Reuters)--The West German Bundestag today elected Hermann Ehlers, a leading Protestant layman, as its new president. Herr Ehlers, 46, a member of the Christian Democratic Union, succeeds Erich Koehler, of the same party, who went on leave last July because of ill health.

A United Air Lines plane moved what was described as a record load of domestic air mail yesterday from New York to Chicago, Denver and Los Angeles. The load weighed 17,000 pounds, or the equivalent of approximately 680,000 letters.
Five employes were cited yesterday for excellence in the performance of duty by Ralph A. Beals, director of the New York Public Library.

The Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, net income amounting to $27,809,000, an increase of $9,100,000 over the $18,709,000 earned in the first nine months of last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP)-- President Truman today officially proclaimed Nov. 23 as Thanksgiving Day and appealed to all Americans to pray for "that peace which the world cannot give."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19--A sharp difference of opinion as to whether the commercial airlines of the United States would be nationalized in the event of war was brought out here today at the sixth annual meeting of the International Air Transport Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19--Men can drive better than women but they don't, the male is more skillful at the wheel of an automobile but the female seems to have more sense, and the man has more police tickets and more accidents.
Mixed emotions were expressed yesterday by the first group of forty-seven women enlisted reserves to be called for active duty at the Army General Dispensary at 90 Church Street.
Corp. Wallace R. Evans of Fort Jay received the Soldier's Medal yesterday from Maj. Gen. Willard C. Wyman, chief of staff, First Army, at the retreat parade on Governors Island.

Bound for what they hope will be a victorious invasion, thirtyfive Fordham players entrained last night at Jersey City for Morgantown, W.Va., where the Rams will meet the West Virginia football team tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Sales of large independent retailers in September fell 2 per cent below August, although they topped September, 1949, by 14 per cent, the bureau of the census has reported.

GENEVA, Oct. 19--The first serious effort to put across a radical new approach to the problem of making economic aid to underdeveloped countries effective will be made in the United Nations report on technical assistance to Bolivia, soon to be released.

A banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will place on the market today a new issue of 100,000 shares of $100 par value 4.60 per cent dividend preferred stock of Alabama Power Company at $102.20 a share. PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Sentencing of Harry Gold, 39-yearold chemist who confessed delivering atomic secrets to Russian agents, was delayed today, at the Government's request, until Dec. 7.

American aid to Yugoslavia gives Marshal Tito greater comfort than it does the nation, exiles King Peter II of Yugoslavia said yesterday after arriving from London at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The Newsdealers Association of Greater New York announced yesterday that a meeting to protest the attempt of the License Department to enforce orders limiting the size of newsstands will be held on Sunday at 4 P.M. in the Capitol Hotel.

Arutiunian of the Soviet Union replied today before the General Assembly's Economic Committee that the claim was "bereft of valid reasoning and grounds."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP)-- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, National Selective Service director, reported today that 21,101 physicians, dentists and veterinarians had registered in the medical draft last Monday.

The marriage of Miss Eileen Glass, daughter of Mrs. Blanche Glass of 101 West Fifty-fifth Street, and Herbert Glass of Coral Gables, Fla., to Leonard J. Michelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Michelman of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Edward J. Regensburg of 885 Park Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Jacob Radin performed the ceremony.
Bernard Shaw's "Arms and the Man" is not different from any other play in one respect: It needs to be acted and directed.

IT happened years ago and the statute of limitations is on his side, so the revelation that Stout Steve Owen was once a bookmaker will harm no one. Lest Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy spring into action, it must be noted here and now that no "ice" was involved.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--During the week ended Oct. 18, member bank reserve balances increased $456,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 19--The Christian Democratic Union, largest of the West German political parties, has decided to break all ties with the party of the same name in the East German Democratic Republic.

DUBLIN, N.H., Oct. 19--Joseph Lindon Smith, artist and archaeologist, died here last night in his home at the age of 87. An authority on Egyptian art, he had been employed by the Egyptian Government to teach the technique of art reproduction to Egyptian students.

The New York Ski Club last night announced that it would present the premiere showing of John Jay's full-length kodachrome "Skis Against Time" at the Hunter College Auditorium, Nov. 1-2. Highlights of the 1951 world championships at Aspen, Col.; Lake Placid, N.Y., and Rumford, Me., will be seen.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 19 (AP)--Fair trade laws will face critical tests in 1951, the director of the Bureau of Education on Fair Trade said today.
Columbia University's Teachers College announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Everett A. Dakan as student counselor.

Joseph P. Pizzo, Bronx County campaign chairman for Acting Mayor Impellitteri, the Experience party candidate for Mayor, resigned his post last night and announced that he wouud support Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, the Democratic-Liberal nominee.

TOWACO, N.J., Oct. 19--The engagement of Miss Mary Louise Allen to James William Allcroft Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allcroft of Linden, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Allen. The wedding will take place in December.

Roland La Starza, Bronx heavyweight, will oppose Duilio Spagnolo of Italy in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena tonight. The battle has attracted considerable interest and promises to draw a large crowd.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in cotton futures was moderately active yesterday and prices rose 11 to 29 points

LONDON, Oct. 19--Prices rose on the stock markets here today though less business was done than yesterday. Announcement of Britain's favorable trade balance for the first half of 1950 and prospects of an early end of the Korean war reinforced the note of cheerfulness.

The firm of Goldberg Jacobs has acquired the stage rights to "Their Second Spring," a Jewish novel by Rose Shoshano, which is to be convered into a Yiddish musical comedy-drama for presentation in November at the Parkway Theatre in Brooklyn.

Extension of the Internal Security Act's provisions to cover members of the Spanish Falange comes at a time when travel between this country and Spain is on the upturn, according to the shipping industry.

The United States Forest Service has on its hands the biggest single battle against insects in its history. In Colorado the service is at grips with the Englemann spruce beetle, a bug smaller than a fly, with only a two-year life span...

A record turnout of officials from all of the nation's frontier areas is expected at the twentyseventh annual dinner-dance of the United States Immigration-Naturalization Officers on Saturday night at the Statler Hotel.
The women's dress shop of Abraham Straus was the scene yesterday of a fashion show of clothes prescribed by Mrs. Ida Bailey Allen, author of "Youth After Forty."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--President Truman indicated today that the report of the Bell mission on the economy of the Philippine Republic might never be made public.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Chinese Nationalists today said their guerrillas recaptured Fouyin, a tiny island off the Chinese Communist port of Foochow, Oct. 4. They said thirty of the 100 Red soldiers were killed.

With Dr. Howard A. Rusk, Professor and chairman of the Department of Physical Medicine at the New York University College of Medicine, as principal speaker, the Visiting Nurse Service of New York started its Queens campaign for $30,000 yesterday with a luncheon at the Forest Hills Inn, Queens.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19 --Tabulations completed today by the Westchester Board of Elections showed that the new county registration is 293,053, a record for a non-presidential year. The figure in the Gubernatorial year of 1946 was 270,455. The top Presidential year registration was 320,407 in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission authorized the Otter Tail Power Company, Fergus Falls, Minn., today to issue $5,000,000 in firstmortgage 2.85 per cent bonds due in 1980.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP)--General Electric Company today announced record net earnings of $112,919,454 for the first nine months of 1950. The company also announced record high sales of $1,354,483,215 for the nine-month period.

PIERRE, S.D., Oct. 19--Even Democrats are conceding today that Republican Representative Francis A. Case will win the Senatorial contest in the G.O.P. stronghold of South Dakota but that is as far as they will go.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman of the Crusade for Freedom, urged Americans yesterday to join in a nation-wide bell-ringing for freedom, in unison with the first pealing of the World Freedom Bell, Tuesday, United Nations Day.

AMES, Iowa, Oct. 19. (UP)--Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said tonight that the Government might know by early spring whether price controls would be needed to prevent runaway food costs.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 19-- Early establishment of voluntary labor-management committees in West Coast communities to try to stabilize the labor market, prevent "pirating" of workers and eliminate recruitment methods injurious to the defense program was called for here today.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Oct. 19-- Tony Tiso, Vernon Hills, was named president of the Westchester P.G.A. tonight, succeeding Maurice Walsh of Sunningdale. Roy Bronsdon, Greenwich, and Phil...

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19--United Nations members received a report today saying that the Korean conflict--with its heavy demands for foodstuffs and supplies--had incidentally brightened economic conditions in most countries.

A program intended for traffic relief in the garment area will go into effect on Monday, Traffic Commissioner Lloyd B. Reid said yesterday. The plan is based upon voluntary cooperation and if it fails regulations may be put into effect to curb daytime truck travel.

To be associated with Governor Dewey is a "degrading experience," Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic candidate for Governor, declared last night in another campaign speech attacking his opponent's character.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Ralph S. Euler, senior vice president of the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, today was elected to the Allegheny Ludlum...

Net income of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation for the three months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $2,545,611, or $1.63 a common share, the company reported yesterday. This compared with a net profit of $1,414,832, or $1.13 a share, on a smaller number of shares outstanding for the same quarter of 1949.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Music apparently doesn't come under the Government's new "shackle" on consumer credit. Beethoven, Bach and the other masters now can be heard on credit in the nation's capital. The National Symphony Orchestra benefits.

Another letter appeared yesterday in the state political campaign, one written by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for re-election, to Alger Hiss, expressing sympathy and defending him against "unfair accusations."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP)-- The Navy identified today the thirty-nine Navy men injured when the minesweeper Pirate struck a mine and sank off Wonsan harbor on the east coast of Korea last Thursday. The injured included Richard Jerome Carey, hospital corpsman 1/c, son of Mrs. Mary J. Carey, 134 Warren Street,...
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 19 (AP)--Uruguay withdrew today from the world amateur basketball tournament in Buenos Aires after a dispute over radio and press facilities.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 19 (AP)--A trial in Bratislava was reported today to have brought out charges that there were antiGovernment underground units in all three of Czechoslovakia's provinces.

The Republic Steel Corporation reported yesterday that it has sold its holdings in the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company. The holdings amounted to 100,920 shares of the iron company's common stock. Republic de clined to disclose the selling price of the stock, the purchaser or how the sale was handled.
LONDON, Oct. 19--Lewis W. Douglas, retiring United States Ambassador in London, described the British Commonwealth today as the most significant political phenomenon of the last 300 years.
Col. Melvin L. Krulewitch, a combat veteran of World Wars I and II, has been named chairman of the New York County Veterans Committee for Dewey and Hanley, it was announced yesterday at...

Vice President Alben W. Barkley told 2,000 diners at the sixth annual dinner of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation last night that government's function was to keep open the channels of human initiative and free enterprise.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, Oct. 19--Francisco Corneiro, United States District Attorney here, and his assistant, Croxton Williams, have received the following cablegram from Deputy Attorney General Peyton Ford:

Eighty non-profit voluntary hospitals, members of the United Hospital Fund in all boroughs, are now seeking to raise $3,500,000 to be prepared to treat the ills of a population of 8,000,000. At least one of them is in your community. Today we salute:
FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 19 (AP) --Patty Berg, the defending champion from Minneapolis, and three Texans survived the quarter-finals of the Hardscrabble women's open golf tournament today.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 (UP)--The condition of H.L. Mencken, author, "remains about the same as this morning when he took a turn for the worse," a Johns Hopkins Hospital spokesman said in a late bulletin today. "Nothing has changed since this morning when he failed for the first time to respond," the spokesman added.

The first threat of a strike by television performers came yesterday when the New York membership of Television Authority, representing five performer unions, voted strike authorization to its board, which is negotiating with the networks for minimum wages and working conditions.

Philippa Macdonald introduced her latest collection, which was shown at a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel yesterday, as "clothes without season." Miss Macdonald, whose shop is at 19 West Fiftyseventh Street, explained that since the fashions were custom made, the selection of both fabric and color may be made to suit any climate.

MADRID, Oct. 19--Generalissimo Francisco Franco left Madrid today on a tour of Spanish West Africa and the Canary Islands. The trip is expected to last twelve days, and it has the primary aim of strengthening the prestige of his Government in those areas.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 19--With ceremonies of the Peronista Loyalty Week concluded, President Juan D. Peron and his wife left today for a brief vacation at the nearby estate of San Vicente, Most high Government officials are taking a vacation at the same time.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 19-- A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. H. Bridgman Griswold on Tuesday in the Greenwich Hospital. Mrs. Griswold is the former Miss Diane P. Dobbs of New York. The child will be named Pamela Post.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer will be the principal speaker at the annual dinner of New York City Post 505, Veterans of Foreign Wars, in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow night. Thomas J. Curran, New York Secretary of State, also will speak.
WOODMERE, L.I., Oct. 19-- Friends Academy of Locust Valley defeated Woodmere Academy, 13--0, today in an Athletic Association of Private Schools football game.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Del Flanagan of St. Paul, Minn., gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Johnny De Fazio, Bayonne, N.J., tonight. Flanagan weighed 139 pounds, De Fazio 140.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 (AP)-- The California Public Utilities Commission today denied Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company's request for a $36,000,000 yearly increase in telephone rates in the State.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19--The United States informed the United Nations today that two of its jet fighters mistakenly attacked aircraft on a Soviet airfield near Vladivostok Oct. 8. The attack had been protested earlier by the Soviet Union.

A picture of Lou Gehrig, famed baseball star of the New York Yankees who died in 1941 of a muscle disease about which little is known, was presented yesterday to the New York Hospital by Mr. Gehrig's widow. Mrs. Gehrig made her gift, she said, in view of her...

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 19--As part of The Hill School's celebration of the 100th anniversary of its founding, 200 fathers from seventeen states will attend a twoday fathers' conference, opening tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19--A nation-wide drive to collect $70,000 for the erection of a fountain outside the United Nations Manhattan headquarters will be opened next Wednesday under the auspices of the American Association for the United Nations. The drive will be opened by Mrs. Arthur B. Langlie,...

If price controls are imposed in spite of the contention of the retail industry that they are unwarranted at the present time, they should not be based on a "flat freeze" basis, J. Gordon Dakins, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association declared yesterday.
Joan Blondell, actress, has sold her twenty-six-acre estate on Route 9 in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., to David Bogdanoff, through the Fred Berger Company, broker.

The sale of the Southern Seas Corporation's tanker Fort Meigs was announced yesterday by James F. Neal, operating manager of the United States Navigation Company, Inc., an affiliate of the vessel's owners. The ship is to be delivered to the Colonial Steamship Corporation tomorrow in Jersey City.

Miss Roslyn Kaye of 62 West Forty-ninth Street, niece of Mrs. Jacob I. Hubbart of Philadelphia and Belle Harbor, Queens, was married to Murray Layton Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Green of New York, last evening in the study of the Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein, who performed the ceremony.
MONTREAL, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Maurice (Rocket) Richard, with two goals, led the Canadiens to a 4-0 National Hockey League shutout over the New York Rangers tonight before a crowd of 14,155.

JACKSON, Mich., Oct. 19 (UP)-- A convicted murderer was trapped in a sewer filled with scalding steam as he attempted to escape from Southern Michigan State Prison tonight and was critically burned before guards, attracted by his screams, rescued him.

Business loans made by New York banks dropped last week, registering the first reduction in twenty weeks. The decline of $46,000,000 following nineteen successive weekly increases, left the total expansion since May 31 at $1,207,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19--The way was paved here today for the creation of an independent and sovereign state in Libya, a former Italian colony in North Africa embracing Tripolitania, Cyrenaica and the Fezzan.

A vacuum cleaner that can aid in the shampoo of a rug and, in a pinch, can dry hair in addition to its normal functions, was shown yesterday at the Dale Distributing Company, Inc., 40 East Thirtysecond Street.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 19-- Editorial reaction to President Truman's San Francisco speech in New Delhi was uniformly critical today. All three newspapers that commented on the President's talk expressed the belief that there was little in it to appeal to Asians.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (UP)--The Government disclosed in Commons today that Communist saboteurs might be sneaking into this country from foreign fishing vessels in near-by waters. Home Secretary James Chuter Ede made the disclosure in answer to questions and...

DENVER, Oct. 19--Speculation is shifting almost by the hour one the outcome of one of the nation's closest Senatorial contests--the effort of a "Fair Dealing" Representative to oust one of the most firmly established Senate Republican elders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today a $9,000,000 loan to the Industrial Development Bank of Turkey, established last June to stimulate private investment in Turkish industry. The loan is guaranteed by the Turkish Government.

The United Nations reached a historic turning point as an instrument for the suppression of aggression and the preservation of international peace when the General Assembly, acting as a committee, approved the seven-nation resolution bearing the trenchant title of "United Action for Peace."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 19 (Reuters)--Two United States destroyer escorts, the Gustafson and the O'Neill, will be officially transferred to the Netherland Navy on Oct. 23 at Boston, the Government said today.
Former President Herbert Hoover proposed last night that further economic and military aid to Western Europe be withheld "until a definitely united and sufficient European army is in sight."

Socialization of social work will be the issue of the next decade and lay workers will have to fight to keep it a private enterprise, Edward H. Kavinoky told a board members institute of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The United Nations has at last gotten round to the herring. The fish, that is, and not the incarnadine symbol of a sidetrack.
Directors of Burlington Mills Corporation have elected two additional vice presidents, it was announced yesterday. The new officers are Kenneth R. Fox and Donald Cook.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19--The first Carnegie International Exhibition of Painting since 1939, when the long series of such annuals was interrupted by the second World War, opened this evening at the Founder's Day Exercises in the Music Hall of Carnegie Institute.

Stockholders of the National Dairy Products Corporation, at a special meeting here yesterday, approved an extended pension program covering employes with fifteen or more years of service and increasing the benefits of those previously covered.
WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 19--Poland's industrial production during the first quarter of the year amounted to 104 per cent of plan, according to provisional figures released today by the Government.

Michael M. Platzman, president of the Video Corporation of America, said yesterday that his company had no intention of shutting down its operations and that present orders alone assured its continuance.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 19--The New Brunswick Council of Churches, representing twentynine Protestant Churches in this area, criticized today what it termed the commercialized promotion of Children's Day. The day was observed in many cities last Sunday.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 19--Lack of interest among farmers in this year's election is causing Republican leaders of the predominantly rural counties of central and northern New York as much concern as the possible adverse effects of the publication of the Hanley letter.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 19--Because James O'Brien was registered in more than thirty-five classes, played halfback on the varsity football squad and held two full-time jobs, administrators at Marquette University figured they had a superhuman student enrolled this semester.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19-- Three new projects were announced today for the William PerlbergGeorge Seaton production unit at Paramount, in addition to "The Blossom Seelgy Story," which they are scheduled to make next year with Betty Hutton.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--A visiting delegation of Japan's senior judges watched the United States Supreme Court in action today after meeting the members of the tribunal at a private conference.

The marriage of Miss Helen Norma Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rosen of 1185 Park Avenue and Lawrence, L.I., to Dr. Jacob Louis Yellin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Yellin of New York, took place last night at the Pierre.

A "Youth Night" service will be held by the Salvation Army in Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street, tonight at 7:45 o'clock. Thirty young men and women who were delegates to the International Salvationist Youth Congress in London last summer will participate.

Mrs. Marshall C. Sewall gave a luncheon yesterday at Chez Cardinal, 14 East Fifty-second Street, for Mrs. W. Barton Baldwin Jr. and Mrs. C. Berwind Harjes of Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

The New York Chiefs, trailing by 12--11 at the half, turned back the Philadelphia Panthers, 28--24, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory as the Roller Derby returned to New York last night. A crowd of 3,400 attended the opener of a twelve-game series.
HONOLULU, Oct. 19 (AP)--The Navy's Marianas Mars flying boat set down safely at Keehi lagoon today after flying the last 400 miles from Alameda, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The Senate defense "watchdog" subcommittee will investigate steel and aluminum supplies, the manpower situation and the quality of American arms used in Korea, Donald C. Cook, chief committee counsel, said today.

Confronted by an increase in population that threatens to cause a school crisis, eight communities in the North Westchester area have joined forces to improve and expand their public school programs and facilities.

LONDON, Oct. 19--Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, indicated today that competition from the United States for available supplies of newsprint was at least partly responsible for the reimposition of rationing on British newspapers.

Guaranty Trust Company of New York, trustee under the Utah Power and Light Company first mortgage, has been appointed paying agent and registrar of a new series of $8,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 2 7/8 per cent series, due on Oct. 1, 1980.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 (AP)--The City Boxing Commission today approved the Ezzard Charles-Nick Barone world heavyweight championship bout, Nov. 28, although some of the members said they believe the challenger did not have a chance.

Already thinned to one-man depth at most positions, the City College football team has lost the services of its only remaining right halfback, Joe Mas, for tomorrow's game with Wagner. Coach Irving Mondshein said yesterday that Mas' father had died Wednesday night.

Brown Company, producer of pulp and paper products, has borrowed $16,000,000 from investing institutions on new collateral trust bonds for the purpose of refunding $3,953,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds and notes and $12,620,100 of general mortgage 5 per cent bonds, Laurence...

Prof. Eliezer Rieger, chairman of the School of Education at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, addressing the board of directors of the National Council of Jewish Women yesterday at the BarbizonPlaza Hotel, emphasized the role of freedom "as the cornerstone of education."
SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 19-- A demand of complete independence for Vietnam was made here today in an interview by Tran Van Huu, Premier of Bao Dai's Vietnam Government.
DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP)--Full speed ahead in the nation's public housing programs despite the uncertain international outlook was urged tonight by Mayor DeLesseps S. Morrison of New Orleans.
Mrs. Walton Livingston Oakley gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Richard H. Swartwout, who returned recently from Biarritz and Paris.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 19--Garbage trucks were rolling here today after a "wildcat" strike started yesterday by crews employed by the Frank Stamato Company of Lodi. Some of the garbage men were still striking and the work was being done by substitute crews.

While a fleet of minesweepers worked to clear the most intensive mine fields in history, carrier-based United States Navy planes of Task Force 77 yesterday continued methodical destruction of remaining military targets along the east coast between Hungnam and Chongjin.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 19-- President Chaim Weizmann formally asked Justice Minister Pinhas Rosen today to get together a new Government to replace David Ben-Gurion's four-party coalition that fell last Sunday.

Members of the Association of National Advertisers are experiencing increased abuses by retailers in charges for cooperative advertising, the organization declared in a statement issued by its board...

Japan is capable of producing sufficient raw silk to supply the demand of the world market, Seiji Yoshida, president of the Japan Silk Association, declared yesterday. In less than five years the industry has recovered from a state of devastation to the point where production exceeds 160,000 bales annually, he said.

SHAWNEE-ON-THE-DELAWARE, Pa., Oct. 19--Following her pace-setting opening round of 82 with 42, 39--81 today, Mrs. Philip Conway of the Siwanoy Country Club won the annual postseason contest of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association at Shawnee Country Club with a 36-hole aggregate of 163.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 19--A resurgent Republican state organization, long out of power in Maryland, is driving hard to unseat Senator Millard E. Tydings and Gov. William Preston Lane Jr., Democrat incumbents.
BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--The Red Sox today added Eddie Mayo, manager of the Toledo Club of the American Association, to the coaching staff of Steve O'Neill, Red Sox manager.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 19--The Communist party dissolution bill passed the final stages in the Senate tonight. It will receive royal assent from Governor General William John McKell tomorrow.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 19-- The Sperry Corporation announced here today that it had bought from the United States Government its Nassau plant and 144 acres of land at Lake Success at an undisclosed price.

The Boys Club of New York was the beneficiary of an elaborate entertainment and dinner dance, known as "La Fete des Roses," underwritten by Parfums Caron, given last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

The American Communications Association announced yesterday that 1,600 employes of R.C.A. Communications, Inc., in the United States and Hawaii would receive a general wage increase of 12 cents an hour, plus employer-financed welfare benefits amounting to 4 cents an hour more, under the terms of a new wage agreement.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 19 (AP)-- Taking the lead shortly after the break and stubbornly holding on to it, Cross Hill Ranch's American Glory raced to a two-and-one-halflength triumph today at Garden State Park.

Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for Mayor, charged last night that his Democratic-Liberal party opponent, Ferdinand Pecora, had the support of Frank Costello, nationally known racketeer; Frank Erickson, convicted professional gambler, and the whole underworld in the Mayoralty race.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Garrabrant Perine of West New Brighton, S.I., and Chestertown, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Helaine Anne, to William Yates Wemple Magruder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Thomas Magruder of West New Brighton.

Rita M. Adler has sold the onefamily dwelling at 11 Deepdale Drive in Great Neck, L.I., to Alfred S. Horowitz for cash above a mortgage of $5,700. Robert Freedman was the broker. Title was in sured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--James M. Nebrit Jr., Professor of Law at Howard University, today told the Conference of Presidents of Negro Land Grant Colleges that all statesupported segregation was doomed.
The Citizens Union yesterday gave its full endorsement to nine candidates for Assembly in the twenty-five districts of the Bronx and Queens.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19 (AP)--Herman Hickman, the big reason for unbeaten Yale's amazing mid-season football success, today promised his youngsters he would work on a novel three-platoon system if they upset Cornell Saturday. Both are big orders.

Many of the displays seen at the New York Antiques Fair, now being held in the Armory at Thirtyfourth Street and Park Avenue, are lighted by table and standing lamps to augment the armory's overhead illumination.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19-- Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, defended the price and expansion history of the nation's steel industry here tonight and called on the Government to stop making steel a "political football."

A resolution adopted here yesterday by shipyard workers attributed the present widespread unemployment among the nation's maritime workers to a "disregard and indifference" to the need for preserving the facilities, skills and well-being of the shipbuilding and repair industry.

ST. MATTHEWS, S.C., Oct. 19 (UP)--Mayor T.M. Nelson, chairman of the local draft board, said today the entire membership had resigned because they disagreed with some of the Selective Service deferment rules. One member said a young man evaded the draft simply by enrolling in college.

A representative of the Bank of Japan has opened an office at 20 Pine Street, Room 2600, it was announced yesterday. The office will function as an information center on banking, business, exchange, and investment conditions in Japan.

Seymour J. Sindeband, formerly technical director of American Electro Metal Corporation, yesterday was elected executive vice president of Mercast Corporation. Almost everything happened at last night's performance of "Aida" at the City Center. Singers were tripping (and not in song), dancers were skidding, clothes and accouterments did not behave, and a quartet of singers new to their roles had a rather rocky time of it. It was one of those evenings when nothing went right.

Efforts to negotiate new wage agreements covering members of five mechanical unions employed by major New York newspapers will be renewed this morning in the regional offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, 341 Ninth Avenue. The United States Customs Service realized $74,227 at a daylong auction sale yesterday of thousands of items of abandoned, unclaimed and seized merchandise. The auction was held at the seizure room, 201 Varick Street.

The Quarter Century Club of the Bank of the Manhattan Company held its ninth annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. Of the 361 members who attended, forty-five had completed twenty-five years of service during the last year. Frederick P. Goelz, president of the club, presided.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP)-- The Government warned potato growers today they must trim next year's output by 21 per cent--91,000,000 bushels--to avoid surpluses which would force down prices.

LONDON, Oct. 19--The House of Commons, without a vote, unseated tonight an Irish Protestant clergyman who had been elected as a Conservative. The ban was pronounced on the Rev. James G. MacManaway because he is an episcopally ordained priest of the Church of Ireland, and, as such, is barred by an old law from sitting in Parliament.

After sixty-seven years as a player and manager Connie Mack has taken himself off the bench. His is the longest and finest individual career in our national sport. He has been a fine sportsman in both success and failure.

PARIS, Oct. 19--Foreign Minister Robert Schuman is expected to propose to the Cabinet Saturday that the question of German rearmament be solved by merging the Continental European forces in a single army and by similarly unifying the armament production of the western part or this Continent.

Eighty-five United States soldiers, sailors and marines who had been wounded fighting in Korea, received an unannounced visit yesterday from their Commander in Chief, President Truman.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)-- The American Battle Monuments Commission approved today a design for a 104-foot tower to be constructed at Manila as a memo rial to American war dead.
Ed (Whitey) Ford, finest young hurler to hit the major leagues in a long time, will be pitching for Uncle Sam instead of the world champion Yankees next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)-- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, put the nation on notice today to expect additional multi-billion dollar increases in taxes, nothwithstanding the victory in Korea.

Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, reported yesterday that his department had awarded contracts totaling $3,000,000 in the first nine months this year and planned to award additional contracts for $5,500,000 before Dec. 31.

Two third-party versions, as mutually contradictory as the firstperson accounts, of discussions between Carmine DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, and Acting Mayor Impellitteri were given to the public yesterday.

A bid by the North Atlantic powers to gain the support of under-developed countries in the drive for an effective control and reduction of armaments received the official seal of approval yesterday when it was voiced by President Truman in his address before the United Nations General Assembly.

Two local laws designed to prevent policemen from submitting retirement applications to avoid signing waivers of immunity when called before a grand jury were introduced into the City Council yesterday.

Attendance at the 1950 National Business Show, now being held in Grand Central Palace, increased about 25 per cent over the previous day's figure to reach slightly more than 11,000 last night.

The aroused curiosity of a pharmaceutical house salesman who noticed a serial number on a penicillin bottle in a physician's office brought about the arrest yesterday of two men on charges of burglary and criminally receiving stolen property.

Angelene Collins, the first singer to receive a Naumburg Award in five years, gave yesterday afternoon at Town Hall the debut recital that was her reward for winning the approval of the exacting judges who pass annually on talent for the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation.

For the second consecutive year, California wine production will be less than consumption, it was indicated last week by sales figures to date. As the tendency toward greater wine popularity continues, trade observers see higher prices as inevitable.

The first showroom in this city to display the decorative fabrics of Stoffel Co., which traces its beginnings back to the eleventh century, will open today at 598 Madison Avenue. The concern has offices on the West Coast and in Chicago and its main office in St. Gall, Switzerland.

Creation of single, unified departments of defense and foreign affairs by the Atlantic pact nations to meet the threat of Communist aggression was proposed yesterday by Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, and nine other military, naval and veterans' leaders.

This is National Apple Week, and with it comes the good news that this year's crop, now at its peak, will be especially abundant. The United States Department of Agriculture estimates that 120,000,000 bushels of apples will be available this year. Although this bumper yield is slightly less than last year's, it is larger than average by 11,000,000 bushels.

Foreign Office sources estimated today that by forced marching they could reach the forbidden city in two weeks.

Every week beef-hungry New Yorkers devour over 500 pounds of rib roast alone at the Beef and Bourbon Restaurant. As its name implies, the restaurant's specialty is beef. And as for the bourbon, that too may be had--some twenty different selections.

Tin and rubber futures continued to rise on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday as trade and commission-house buying lifted prices to new seasonal highs. Tin futures advanced 250 to 450 points in sales of 70 tons, while rubber moved forward the permissible limit of 200 points, or 2 cents a pound, with 610 tons traded.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October was the heaviest for any month since January, 1946. Sales for the month were also the largest for an October in thirteen years, or since 1937.

Grant Company, stressed the fact that stores do not receive enough factual information about goods they sell. The Hilton Hotels Corporation announced here yesterday that it had acquired controlling interest in the well-known twelve-story Jefferson Hotel in St. Louis, Mo., through purchase of more than 70 per cent of the common stock in the Jefferson Hotel Company. The sellers were Max L. Teich, Carl E. Roessler and members of their families.
The Manhattan Council for Social Planning was called on yesterday by Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the City Planning Commission, to begin to make plans to meet social welfare problems in wartime.

The State of New Jersey sold yesterday $25,000,000 of institution building construction bonds due from 1952 to 1965 at an interest cost of 1.1858 per cent to a banking syndicate headed by the First National Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The Department of Agriculture in a summary issued today predicted that food prices would rise moderately next year, possibly to record levels unless checked by antiinflationary measures.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 31--The voters in this border state will have a clear-cut opportunity on Nov. 7, to choose between the political philosophies espoused by a liberal Democrat and a conservative Republican.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 31 --Princes and dignitaries from the whole world will accompany the late King Gustaf V to his last resting place in Stockholm's Riddarholm Church on Nov. 9.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--A leading New England manufacturer wants Congress to raise the minimum wage to $1.06 an hour in the cotton and rayon textile industry. This would bring the Southern mills, which are largely unorganized, up to the wage level of the unionized Northern mills. He said the differential was destroying a major New England industry.

THE waterfowl season will open in Connecticut at noon on Friday, with prospects excellent for native black ducks but not even fair for the greater scaup or broadbill, which have not yet arrived in sufficient numbers to attract the open water shooters.

PARIS, Oct. 31--The French Government in a memorandum handed to the Sultan of Morocco this evening agreed to some minor reforms in line with the Sultan's request but rejected any basic modification of the French protectorate in Morocco.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The buying splurge of last summer eased off in September but sales were still running well ahead of a year ago both in the manufacturing and retail divisions of distri bution, the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce reported today.

MIAMI, Oct. 31 (UP)--Florida's crime crackdown brought suspension of the sheriff of the Daytona Beach resort area today for alleged winking at gambling, and a winter round-up was ordered of hoodlums flocking to the Miami Beach Gold Coast farther south.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company had a consolidated net income of $23,455,627 for the first nine months this year, against $20,200,956 for the similar period a year ago, William F. Humphrey, president, reported yesterday.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 31-- The nation's prefabricated home builders are looking to increased sales in 1951 despite Federal mortgage restrictions.

The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday that its directors have proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock. The board also declared a dividend, of 80 cents a share on the stock, an increase of 15 cents over previous quarterly payments this year. The disbursement will be made on Dec. 26 to holders of record of Dec. 7.

Miss Helen Allen, executive vice president, secretary and assistant to the president of Corday Parfums, Inc., died early yesterday morning at Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. She was 42 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)-- The Federal Communications Commission today asked the Radio Corporation of America, to turn over its tricolor television tube to the Columbia Broadcasting System for experiments with the approved C.B.S. color plan.

DETROIT, Oct. 31--Frank Couzens, former Mayor of Detroit, died today at the age of 48 of a chest ailment. He had undergone an operation several weeks ago for carcinoma of the chest bone and his condition grew gradually worse.

A compact for interstate action in the event of an atomic attack or other emergency, in which ten Northeastern states and the adjacent Canadian provinces are expected to join, is being drafted here, it was learned yesterday.

A last-hour selling wave flattened the stock market again yesterday. Almost matching in volume the late assault of Monday and equaling the extent of losses, the list managed a partial recovery just before the closing bell that softened the setback. The plunge left the composite rate lower by 1.12 points.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP)-- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today there was no way of protecting the nation's cotton supply that would satisfy everybody.

Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for Mayor, asserted last night that he had proof that the candidacies of Acting Mayor Impellitteri and Ferdinand Pecora had the support of the underworld, despite their denials.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Morris Weintrob of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Meta, to Alan Edward Willis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Willis of Rego Park, Queens. The wedding will take place in June.

A syndicate of eighteen investment banking houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will put On the market today an issue of $40,000,000 of new general mortgage bonds of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation due on Oct. 1, 1980, at an investment yield of about 2.81 per cent.

New York City's gross funded debt was a record $3,139,894,614 on June 30, 1950, an increase of $182,975,675 over the $2,956,918,919 total on June 30, 1949. These figures were included in the annual report of Controller Lazarus Joseph, made public yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 1--The lights of this Oriental capital will glow again tonight after four months of blackout and power failure.

The Credit Research Foundation will undertake two new research projects, it was announced yesterday by David A. Weir, executive vice president. The first, on productivity of credit, will continue indefinitely, to aid the foundation's program for highlighting the importance of credit work.

Government loans which financed the founding of the Kaiser Steel Corporation at Fontana, Calif., in 1942 and helped sustain it since then were paid off in full yesterday--nearly twenty years before maturity.
