The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for chil- ...

White flowers formed a garden background yesterday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in East Eightyeighth Street for the marriage of Miss Sylvia Obolensky, daughter of Mrs. David Pleydell-Bouverie of
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--Everpresent on a wall of the White House Secret Service office is a warning to Secret Service men to be alert and not be deceived by appearances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--Persistent reports that Congress may discard plans for an excess profits tax and substitute a uniform increase in corporation levies were discounted by Congressional tax authorities today.
Prince and Princess Vladimir Romanovsky-Tirtoff of 173 East Sixty-fourth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Princess Barbe Marie ...
The idea behind many of the new devices now appearing in the housewares departments of stores here is to simplify kitchen chores. Among these short cuts for home cooks:

Two home-made bombs of the "Molotov cocktail" type were hurled by an unidentified man yesterday into a room occupied by fifty persons at the Puerto Rican Government Labor office--1881 Broadway--but they failed to explode.

Nine broad policies which comprise the national manpower mobilization program of the Government were described to more than 800 industrial executives here yesterday by Robert C. Goodwin, executive director, Office of Defense Manpower, Washington. He spoke at the annual fall conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management at the Statler Hotel.

Trustees of the United States Trust Company of New York have called a special meeting of stockholders for Dec. 5 to approve a stock dividend of 150 per cent on the 40,000 shares of stock outstanding, Benjamin Strong, president, announced yesterday. If approved, the dividend will be paid on Dec. 27 to holders of record of Dec. 11, it was said.

Directors of the National Dairy Products Corporation yesterday declared an extra dividend of 20 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 70 cents, both payable to common stockholders on Dec. 31.

Adding sparkle, color and elegance to the 160 fashions modeled in the ninth edition of "Fashions of The Times," which is being presented at Times Hall through this evening, were some of the latest and most exciting items of jewelry.

The attempted assassination of President Truman was not only shocking; it was mystifying and senseless. So far as he was concerned, in a personal and official capacity, he was the last person that Puerto Ricans honestly seeking the independence of the island should have attacked.

Although communism is the greatest threat to this country today Republican leaders fight against every effort to build up a coalition of free nations to combat the Communist menace, Senator Herbert H. Lehman declared last night.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Milton Buzby of San Juan, Puerto Rico, of the engagement of their daughter, Camille Helene, to Edward Miner Lamont, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Stilwell Lamont of 101 East Seventy-second Street, this city, and Sky Farm Cottage, North Haven, Me.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2--Group practice and regional organization of hospitals are the two methods "holding the greatest promise for the improvement and quality of medical care," the American Public Health Association was told here today at its annual meeting.

The Chinese Communists are driving into Tibet and there seems every reason to believe that they will soon take over the fabulous mountain country. It is called a "liberation." That it is another act of bald aggression will hardly be doubted in most of the world.
DETROIT, Nov. 2 (AP)--The New York Rangers battled from behind while short-handed in the third period to tie the Detroit Red Wings, 2--2, in a bruising National Hockey League battle here tonight.

WARSAW, Nov. 2--The first split in the Polish Roman Catholic Church hierarchy was indicated by the Government today when it announced that Dr. Edmund Nowicki, acting Apostolic Administrator of the See of Gorzow Wielkopolski, had endorsed the Government's demands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--The optimistic opinion expressed yesterday by Secretary of State Acheson on the progress and prospect of an agreement on plans to integrate armed Germans in a defense system for Western Europe does not alter the fact that the military authorities and their civilian chiefs of the other North Atlantic nations unanimously and irrevocably oppose the proposal of the French Government.
New talents and some already familiar to the public are making their appearances in New York's art galleries this week.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 2--A representative for the revolutionary Nationalist party of Puerto Rico paid a visit today to the United Nations to deposit an urgent request with Secretary General Trygve Lie to bring the Puerto Rican revolt before the Security Council as a matter endangering international peace.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2--President Truman's single political speech of the off-year election campaign here on Saturday night and his return home to vote may well be the deciding factor in Missouri's important United States senatorial race.

MANHASSET, L.I., Nov. 2-- Gilbert V. Steele, vice president, a director and chief engineer of Abbott, Merkt Co., Inc., 10 East Fortieth Street, New York, consulting engineers, died here today in his home, 10 Stuart Place, after an illness of several months. His age was 63. He was noted as an authority on the design of department store and industrial buildings.

Walter F. O'Malley, new president and controlling owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers, yesterday announced that Emil J. (Buzzie) Bavasi and LaFayette Fresco Thompson had been named as joint directors of the baseball club.

The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark, N.J., has purchased the fourteen-story industrial building at the northwest corner of Tenth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, in Manhattan, from the Red Wing Realty Corporation.

Women active in behalf of Greek Children's Care, Inc., met yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. George M. Livanos at 875 Park Avenue. The organization was founded in March, 1949, by a small group of American and Greek women in New York to supplement United States aid to Greece with private assistance to the children of needy families in Greece.

Police Commisioner Thomas F. Murphy announced last night that the services of more than 19,000 policemen would be available next Tuesday to guarantee voters complete freedom from intimidation, coercion or threats at the polls.

Mrs. Caryl Sayre of The Creek club was elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday, to succeed Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol, who has held the post for four years.
Acting Mayor Impellitteri charged last night that he had been subjected to an unprecedented campaign of vilification because he refused to be bossed or bought.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--The Soviet Union charged here today that the United States had used Japanese troops in the Korean war.

Ferdinand Pecora, Democratic candidate for Mayor, attacked Acting Mayor Impellitteri in campaign speeches last night for urging his followers to skip the entire Democratic list of candidates on the voting machine.
Government and religious leaders throughout the world sent congratulations yesterday to President Truman on his escape Wednesday from an attempted assassination.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 2--The Soviet delegation to the United Nations issued today a statement attacking a report in THE NEW YORK TIMES that Soviet officials

This is to report that the Woolford Farm's Delegate is back in the best of health. Yesterday he won the main event on the Empire City-at-Jamaica race program. He was the $9.50-for-$2 third choice in a $5,000 added handicap that was run over the mile-and-a-sixteenth course.

WHEN George Orwell died last January a talented and provocative writer was lost to the world. A stimulating and dog matic literary critic, an eloquent political propagandist and an indifferent novelist, Orwell could not be fitted into any literary pigeonhole. He was modest to eccentricity. Orwell was a pseudonym. His real name was Eric Blair.
ALBANY, Nov. 2--There is greater confidence of victory on election day among the Democrats of upstate New York than there is among their colleagues in New York City's five boroughs.
Governor Dewey introduced four photographs on television last night to refute Democratic charges that his administration had built no new mental hospitals in the last eight years.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 2 (AP) --Sammy Snead swept through the third round of the North and South Open golf tournament with a 6under par 32, 34--66 today to move into the fifty-four-hole lead by two strokes with 205.

Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally yesterday ordered 108 names stricken from the voting lists and permitted eight others to remain, among them a Bowery habitue who not only won the right to vote after addressing the Court as "Sonny," but also received a cash donation from the Court as well.

ANNANDALE ON-HUDSON N.Y., Nov. 2--The nation's colleges and universities were urged today to pay greater attention to the moral and social needs of their students, as well as to other aspects of student guidance.

Charles H. Hussey of 440 West Thirty-fourth Street, Chief Clerk of the City Court, New York County, and Democratic district leader of the Third Assembly District, Manhattan, died yesterday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital. His age was 74.

The Horse Show Ball, the most important social event in connection with the National Horse Show, which opened on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, will be held tonight in the newly enlarged Starnight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Guests of honor will be Army and Navy officers, Col. Alois Podhajsky,, commandant of the Spanish Riding School in Vienna, and members of the international jumping teams.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 2--A 1951 budget totaling more than $2,000,000, largest in the history of the religious-Zionist movement, was approved here tonight by more than 1,000 delegates at the thirtieth annual national convention of the Mizrachi Organization of America to carry on the group's activities in this country and Israel.

LONDON, Nov. 2--It is expected that soon after the arrival here of William L. Batt, new Marshall Plan administrator for Britain, preliminary informal discussions will begin on the question of curtailing or suspending United States financial assistance to the United Kingdom. Prime Minister Attlee

A veteran Navy deep-sea diver donned his 250-pound gear and slipped thirty feet into the Hudson River at 134th Street yesterday to weld the last major piece of pipe in a 1,840-mile line that will bring enough natural gas from Texas to meet the demands of more than 4,000,000 consumers for at least twenty years. The gas is expected to be flowing into New York before Christmas.

Dwight G.W. Hollister, president of A.P.W. Products Company, Inc., of Albany, N.Y., manufacturers of paper products, announced yesterday that he and other holders of the company's securities had concluded an agreement to sell their holdings.

Commodore Frederick G. Reinicke, U.S.N., retired, formerly Commissioner of Marine and Aviation and wartime Navy port director in New York, will leave next week by air to become a special adviser to the Government of Thailand.

Continuing his attack on Representative Walter A. Lynch, his Democratic-Liberal opponent, Governor Dewey charged last night that Mr. Lynch, as a member of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, favored a proposal to "free the underworld" from criminal income tax prosecution.

As though Coach Steve Owen were not already fully aware of his team's shortcomings, the appearance yesterday of the National Football League's weekly team statistics clearly indicated the points that must be stressed by the New York Giants in preparing for Sunday's battle against the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds.
The Great White Way, which George Bernard Shaw glimpsed in 1931 for the only time, was dimmed last night in tribute to his contribution to Broadway and the rest of the theatre world.

Two hundred and fifty delegates to the National Foreign Trade Convention, many of whom have shipped merchandise through this port but have never seen its myriad sea transport facilities, were guests of the Port of New York Authority and the New York Central System yesterday on a ferryboat tour of the harbor.

LONDON, Nov. 2--Consideration was being given today to the possibility that George Bernard Shaw, who died this morning, might be buried in Westminster Abbey, the final resting place of so many of Britain's greatest men, among whom he was certainly numbered.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (AP)--For the second night in arrow, the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight downed the Montreal Canadiens, this time by 2--1. The victory increased Toronto's lead in the National Hockey League to five points over Montreal.

The Mexican Army team won the General Manuel Avila Camacho Trophy for the third straight year at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night before 10,000, but a gallery half the size at the matinee received the day's main thrill when, for the first time in three years, the Star Spangled Banner rang to hail a victory for a United States team.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 3--United Nations forces, under savage attack by the North Korean Communist Army reinforced by troops of the Chinese Red Army, today pulled back spearheads close to the Manchurian border and were attempting to form a new defense line in the threatened northwest sector of Korea.
Puerto Ricans here yesterday condemned the attempt to assassinate President Truman Wednesday in Washington.

Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, denounced as "monumental misstatements" charges made this week by Governor Dewey, his Republican rival, which sought to picture Mr. Lynch as a legislator amenable to the wishes of big financial interests.

Henry Fonda hasn't said "yes" nor has he said "no" about his appearance next season under the Leland Hayward banner in Paul Osborn's dramatization of the J.P. Marquand best-seller, "Point of No Return," to be staged by H.C. Potter. According to the way the weather-vane is veering, this may be regarded as specific: The

In the third of a series of court actions to ban "spurious charities" from raising funds in New York State, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein sought an injunction yesterday against the National Cancer Hospital of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--A tenyear increase of 19,028,086 in the population of the United States-- placed officially today at 150,697,361--will cause a switch of twenty-eight seats in the House of Representatives, unless the House raises its membership.

Orders on the books and expected reorders will keep domestic dinnerware manufacturers operating at "fairly good levels short of capacity" until Dec. 15, Wilbert A. Betz, secretary, United States Potters Association reported yesterday. He said the industry is well on its way to recovery from the slump in the first half of the year, which he described as the worst since 1935.

Economic controls now necessary in the fight against communism should constitute only "temporary expedients" if sacrifice of the freedoms the United States is trying to preserve is to be avoided, according to the "final declaration" of the thirty-seventh National Foreign Trade Convention, issued yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2--A strong bullish sentiment developed today on the Board of Trade here in regard to the trend of the soybean, corn and oats markets, with all deliveries of corn and oats and July soybeans selling at new highs for the season.

All city employes and civilians who will be part of New York City's civil defense army of 450,000 will be required to sign a loyalty oath and indicate whether they were or are affiliated with any of the 128 organizations listed as subversive by the United States Attorney General.
Dr. Hugh Keenleyside, in 315 E 68th St; William Davidson, in 440 E 56th St; Thomas Rall in 4 E 81st St--Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2-- Yale is quoted a 6-point favorite over Dartmouth in Saturday's battle in the Bowl, which will draw 50,000 or more, but Herman Hicktman think somebody slipped up in his arithmetic.

The campaign of major elements in all branches of organized labor to elect the Democratic-Liberal slate in this state reached its peak yesterday at a luncheon meeting of 600 union leaders at the Astor Hotel.
Although the United States is still a signatory to the International Whaling Convention there will be no American-flag entrant in the Antarctic whaling season that opens late next month.

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 2--Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley spent a quiet day in the Columbia County Memorial Hospital here today, recuperating from exhaustion that will probably prevent him from making any more major pre-election campaign appearances. His only visitors were members of his family.

Final performances of "Fashions of The Times" will be given this afternoon and evening at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, bringing the number who have seen this ninth annual presentation by THE NEW YORK TIMES to 4,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--A Presidential Emergency Board recommended pay and welfare improvements today for Railway Express drivers in New York, but said they should be penalized for a strike that was "outside the spirit, if not the letter, of the Railway Labor Act."

The Department of Agriculture's goal for a 16,000,000-bale cotton crop in 1951 will be difficult to attain, according to Robert C. Jackson, executive vice president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute. While it appears likely that the next crop will be substantially greater than the 9,000,000 bales produced in the season just ended, a 66 per cent gain would mean doubling in one year the best increase ever before achieved, he pointed out.

HAMHUNG, Korea, Nov. 2-- Troops of the South Korean First Corps, fighting a few miles north of here, were pushed back about four miles during the last twentyfour hours, by Chinese Communist troops. The South Koreans started

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2-- George Killion, president of American President Lines, asked the Department of Commerce today to recheck export licenses for cargo being loaded on the company's steamship President Madison for delivery at the Communist-controlled Chinese ports of Taku Bar

Three Brooklyn College students were suspended for the remainder of the semester and three others were placed on probation yesterday for "conduct unbecoming a student." The action was taken by Dr. Frederick W. Maroney, dean of students.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--The Harmon international aviation trophies, suspended during the war period, were presented by President Truman today to three persons noted in the history of American aviation.
Starting his recital in Town Hall last night in a rather noncommittal manner, the pianist, Beveridge Webster, carried it to a resounding climax with a performance of Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit."

SAIGON, Indo-China, Friday, Nov. 3 (AP)--French troops have abandoned the big Chinese frontier fortress of Laokay, yielding full control of the northwest IndoChina frontier to the Communistled Vietminh Army.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 2--The extent of war damage to Korea's economy was outlined today in a tabulation of estimates of relief needs prepared for the United Nations by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Unified Command.

The latest reports of the Metropolitan Opera and the New York PhilharmonicSymphony emphasize the fact that the very life of these great organizations is at best precarious, and, at worst, in serious danger. The Metropolitan's deficit last season was $430,000, largest in history, while the orchestra reported an operating deficit of $173,000.

A judge's warning to a 19-yearold prisoner in 1934 became reality yesterday in General Sessions when the same defendant was convicted of a first degree murder charge that carries a mandatory sentence of death by electrocution.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 2--In a sharply worded note to Communist China India has declared that the Mao Tse-tung Government had "no justification whatever" for invading Tibet. India implied that
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--Oscar Collazo, Puerto Rican political fanatic who with a colleague attempted to assassinate President Truman yesterday, was arraigned today on a charge of murder.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov, 2--The acquisition of a collection of Italian Renaissance paintings valued at more than $1,000,000 was announced today by R. Sturgis Ingersoll, president of the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

Miss Barbara Ann Bandler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Evon Fox Bandler of 125 East Eightyfourth Street, was married to John Irving Farian, son of Mrs. Irving S. Farian of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Farian, yesterday afternoon at Sherry's. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence Schwartz performed the ceremony.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 2--Nationalist rebels came out of the hills in droves today and surrendered meekly in the aftermath to the abortive Puerto Rican uprising and the attempt to assassinate President Truman. Top Nationalist and Communist leaders were jailed.

Variegated orchestral fare and the debut of a young pianist, Aldo Ciccolini, from Italy, made the program of the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Dimitri Mitropoulos conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.
Greater comfort in formal wear was one of the important trends in men's fashions forecast in "Fashions of The Times," annual style show presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES at Times Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today announced revised export quotas under its order limiting shipments of American cotton to 2,146,000 bales for the eight-month period ending next March 31.

The National Federation of American Shipping, representing a majority of the shipping companies of the country, joined yesterday with the Post Office Department in urging the early dispatch of Christmas mail for overseas destinations.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2 (AP)-- The United States crushed France, 48--33, tonight, in the round-robin final series of the world amateur basketball tournament, and tied idle Argentina for the lead.
Walt Disney has finally agreed to put his animated characters before the television camera--at least for one performance. He will produes a special film entitled "One Hour in Wonderland," which is to
TOKYO, Nov. 2--The basic problem of the Army in Korea, in the words of an experienced officer, was that the United States had "a creampuff army, not an army of soldiers."

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 2-- James (Piggy) Lynch of Palisades Park and Arthur Longano of Englewood, alleged associates of Joe Adonis and Frank Erickson, surrendered to Superior Court Judge J. Wallace Leyden here this morning. They had been sought in warrants issued last week-end at the request of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler, who is directing the state's investigation of gambling in Bergen County.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 2. (UP)-- Federal Judge John McDuffie, who helped write the Philippines Independence Act while a member of Congress, died here yesterday at the age of 67, after a long illness.

Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, got a public dressingdown yesterday from the President of the United Nations General Assembly for long and personal attacks against John Foster Dulles. The Soviet delegate, making an hour and a half speech at Flushing Meadow against the resolution to give the Assembly power to act against aggression, devoted a good part of his time to attacking Mr. Dulles, a United States delegate and chief author of the plan.
That ten-cent glass of beer may soon join its fabled cousin the nickel schooner as part of a faded memory of old New York.

Net income of the Celanese Corporation of America established a new high record, at $32,994,645, for the first nine months of this year, exceeding the earnings of $20,640,826 reported for all of 1949.

THE football season long since should have reached that state where upsets are no longer a novelty. By mid-October in any normal campaign form has leveled off and early estimates have been reassessed. But this is no normal campaign. Two new films arrived in firstrun theatres this morning. At the Strand, the attraction will be "Rocky Mountain," a Warner Brothers Western, starring Errol Flynn and Patrice Wymore (Mrs. Flynn). Scott Forbes, Guinn Williams, Dick Jones and Howard Petrie are among the supporting players. William Keighley directed and William Jacobs produced from a script by Winston Miller and Alan LeMay and a story by Mr. LeMay.

Having begun its career at Columbia University last January, Jan Meyerowitz's opera, "The Barrier" has now reached Broadway by easy stages. It was sung by Lawrence Tibbett and Muriel Rahn at the Broadhurst last evening. Music lovers had a high opinion of it when it opened last winter. But it looks and sounds like "art art" in the shrill neighborhood of Broadway. To at least one theatregoer,

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 2--The American Dental Association, representing 75,000 United States dentists, put its stamp of approval today on the artificial addition of sodium fluoride to community water supplies in the interest of public health.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--A lower court decision that had led building-trade union leaders figuratively to "dance in the streets," because it had upset the Taft-Hartley Act's ban against a type of secondary boycott, was appealed to the Supreme Court by the Government today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--The National Science Foundation, designed to advance research and education, came to life at last today with President Truman's appointment of twenty-four educators, industrialists and scientists to its National Science Board.

Four young men were arraigned yesterday on charges of felonious assault before Magistrate Peter Abeles in Bronx Magistrate's Court in the wake of a series of interracial disturbances involving Puerto Rican and Irish residents of a south Bronx neighborhood.

IPSOK, Korea, Nov. 2 (UP)-- Chinese Communist hordes, attacking on horse and on foot to the sound of bugle calls, cut up Americans and South Koreans at Unsan today in an Indian-style massacre that may prove to be the costliest of the Korean war.

The Marquis de Cuevas' Grand Ballet added two ballets to its repertoire at the Century Theatre last night, both of them more than familiar in the repertoires of other companies. They are George Balanchine's "Concerto Barocco," set to the Bach concerto for two violins, and Anton Dolin's "Pas de Quatre" to the music of Pugni.

Wage controls inevitably bring price and profit controls to produce a thoroughly regimented economy, W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the executive committee of the National City Bank of New York, warned yesterday. Speaking before 300 members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at 65 Liberty Street, Mr. Burgess...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP)-- The Government, which tried with only moderate success to hold down this year's corn crop, said today a "substantial" boost in production is needed next year to provide "abundant" output of meat and other livestock products.
ROME, Nov. 2--The sixth session of the Committee of Ministers of the European Council will open in Rome tomorrow under the chairmanship of Italian Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza.
A hasty conclusion reached at Columbia's weekly football press luncheon yesterday at John Jay Hall was that Cornell's scrimmage sessions must be pretty rugged.

"The Loyalty of Free Men," by Alan Barth, formerly with the Treasury and the Office of War Information, has been scheduled for Jan. 22 publication by the Viking Press. The book is an examination of the Government's loyalty program, of treason and perjury trials, of investigations and legislative hearings, of teachers' oaths

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 2--A Kiisang girl, the equivalent of a Japanese geisha girl, died today with a love song on her lips as twentyseven convicted collaborators were executed in a hillside cemetery outside this city.

NEW ROCHELLE, Nov. 2--The Very Rev. Brother Joseph P. Noonan, Superior General of the Christian Brothers' Congregation for the last twenty years, died today in Dublin after a long illness, according to word received here. He was 76 years old.

DETROIT, Nov. 2--Brig. Gen. P.W. Smith, chief of the Procurement Division, Air Material Command, U.S. Air Force, and Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, today announced the signing of letter contracts authorizing Ford to take over facilities of the Government-owned aircraft engine plant in Chicago and manufacture Pratt and Whitney Wasp Major engines for the B-36 Bomber.

The four-story business building assessed at $150,000 at 1155 Avenue of the Americas, southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street, has been sold by the Greenwood Properties Corporation to Henry Goelet, operator, it was announced yesterday. L.V. Hoffman Co. were the brokers in the sale.

Efforts are being made to put the American Theatre Wing Professional Training program, organized in 1946 to retrain veterans of the entertainment world, on a permanent basis. The theatrical training program, which will continue as long as veterans' benefits under the G.I. Bill of Rights are

Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc., has arranged to borrow up to $40,000,000 from eight New York, Chicago and Indianapolis banks over the next three years. R.A. Gallagher, president of the company, estimated that expansion expenditures of the company will reach $90,600,000 by the end of 1953 and that $40,000,000 will have to be raised through the issue of securities.
Because of teachers' resistance, the city's Open School Week, scheduled to begin Monday, will bog down this year.

SHEFFIELD, Mass., Nov. 2-- Berkshire School's football squad is experiencing tough sledding this season and things look no brighter for 1951. For, according to Coach Fred Harrison, the ex-Yale backfield ace who starred for the Elis a decade ago, the Green and Gray is due to lose many of its varsity and second-stringers through graduation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--The United States accused the Soviet Union today of a "flagrant violation" of the four-power agreement on Austria.

The demand for business credit developed renewed strength last week as borrowings from the New York banks rose $95,000,000 to reach a new high total of $5,860,000,000. The advance in the week ended on Wednesday, marked the continuation of the upward movement resumed in the previous

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP)--Roy Conacher, thirteen-season veteran of the National Hockey League, scored two goals tonight to run his lifetime record to 200 as the Chicago Black Hawks bolstered their hold on fourth place with a 5-to-2 victory over the Boston Bruins before 10,201 fans.

Reflecting the $22,490,000 annual rate increase that became effective on May 14, the New York Telephone Company reported yesterday for publication today a net income of $42,451,510 for the twelve months to Sept. 30. This compared with $25,301,901 in the end of the preceding twelve months. The higher figure represented a return of 5.62 per cent on invested capital.

Edward Corsi, Republican mayoralty candidate, called last night for an immediate hearing by the Kefauver Senatorial Committee on his charges that his mayoralty rivals, Acting Mayor Impellitteri and Ferdinand Pecora, had the support of the underworld in the present campaign.

Retailers may expect only small gains during the next nine months, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., predicted yesterday at the company's spring planning meeting in Hampshire House. He explained that he was summing up the opinions of his executives.

Arrangements for a gasoline and automobile service station on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Coney Island Avenue and Crawford Street in Brooklyn have been completed through a lease and double sale of the property.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 31 to 41 points net lower on the day.

The new correlated collection of home furnishings introduced yesterday by Parzinger Originals, 601 Fifth Avenue, is literally a oneman show. There are about sixty pieces of furniture, almost a dozen lamps and lighting fixtures, three wallpapers, two printed fabrics, and a large miscellaneous group of silver and brass accessories, all signed and designed by Tommi Parzinger.

Fred Smith Co., Inc., New York public relations and business consultants, has purchased the Philip Ritter Company, Inc., fiftyyear-old advertising agency, also of New York. The agency will be known as the Philip Ritter Company, a division of Fred Smith

Prices of tin futures on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday continued their sharp advance in an expanded volume of trading, amounting to 105 tons. Final prices were 200 to 350 points higher, with the near-by December delivery ending at $1.29 a pound bid, up 350 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--The Truman family moved into Blair House when the official residence across Pennsylvania Avenue was declared unsafe and its reconstruction was ordered. At first they were delighted with their new quarters: the rooms are pleasant, the building historic and the site very conveniently located.

A.E. Meyer, formerly sales manager for International Projector Corporation, Bloomfield, N.J., manufacturer of motion picture projection and sound equipment, has been appointed vice president in charge of sales.
TORQUAY, England, Nov. 2-- The second phase of the world trade conference opened at Torquay today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--Almost everything in America is changing faster than the American politician.

For the first time this week, the stock market managed yesterday to move appreciably higher. In the dullest full day's session in two months or since Sept. 7, prices worked forward under the leadership of motor, steel and oil issues.

Young matrons headed by Mrs. Stanley M. Rumbough Jr. and Mrs. R. Clifford Wilson, as well as a large group of debutantes of this season, are aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Bell, Book and Candle," starring Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer, on the night of Nov. 16 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2-- "Letter From the President," a screen story by John Fante and Jack Leonard about a Mexican immigrant, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for production next year. Jules C. Goldstone negotiated the sale for the authors.

Jim Konstanty, whose stalwart relief pitching helped the Philadelphia Phillies win their first pennant in thirty-five years, yesterday was established as the National League's most valuable player of 1950. His selection marked the first time a relief pitcher ever has won this honor.

The apartment house at 1710 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, accommodating eighty-five families, has been purchased by Reserve Properties, Inc., from A. Leibman, operator. The attorneys were James J. Leibman for the seller and William Himlyn for the buyer.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 2 --United States authorities here said today they would give German officials in WuerttembergBaden two weeks more to remove former Nazis as teachers. If the Germans do not act a proposal for action will be placed before the Western Allied High Commission, they said.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 2--A Polish proposal for studies of national income in the underdeveloped countries was converted today by the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee into a serious effort to eliminate some of the great gaps in the world's economic information.
Daniel L. Schorr, 34-year-old special correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor, received last night the first William the Silent Award for Journalism.

Outstanding price reductions at the butcher shop this week-end are on pork; loin roast and chops as well as smoked ham are 4 cents a pound cheaper. But with the exception of sirloin steak, down 7 cents a pound, all, other meats remain at last Friday's levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3--Lieut. Col. Robert (or Roger) T. Lincoln, daring secret intelligence agent of the United States, has been promoted to full colonel for the fine work he has been doing in the Middle East and Far East. Latest advices on his exploits reached the White House today.

Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian leader, told 300 members and friends of the New York Counpil of Church Women at a World Community Day service yesterday that "The religion of Jesus is not mere creeds and doctrines, it is a life."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3-- "The Golden Goose," a screen comedy by Robert Harari, has been acquired by Thor Productions, Bert Friedlob's independent company, for filming as that company's next venture, with Eleanor Parker (Mrs. Friedlob) and Fred MacMurray as the stars, Friedlob announced today.

A political torchlight procession by opponents of Representative Vito Marcantonio marched through the heart of his district last night with police protection that rivaled in size the number of marchers. No untoward incidents were reported.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 3 (AP) --Sam Snead beat par by two strokes with a 35, 35--70 today, four strokes ahead of Johnny Palmer for his second straight North and South open golf championship. Snead had a 72-hole score of 275.

Lucas, Democratic majority leader of the Senate, who sought a third term.

Conflicting claims and varying figures still left open last night the possibility that W. Kingsland Macy, Republican chairman of Suffolk County, had lost his seat in Congress as a result of his having bucked the Dewey state organization in connection with the famous "Hanley letter."

TUNK RIVER, Me., Nov. 8-- In a country predominantly flat and with only a half-dozen mountains within visual range, it was inevitable that we should draw the one local guide who insisted upon hunting the high ridges.

The Vitrified China Association yesterday authorized immediate formation of an advisory committee to work more closely with the Government in regard to armed forces contracts for both vitrified china and classified war materials. The action was taken at the annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--One of organized labor's political spokes men traced the election results to day to the global crisis.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP)-- Little did Eddie Sawyer think two years ago that he would be baseball's manager of the year in 1950.

Myth, fiction, illusion--call it what you will--it was the idea that Vincent R. Impellitteri was independent of the party bosses that won his extraordinary victory over the regular Democratic organizations. That is the real significance of his election to be Mayor of New York and it has several important implications.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 8--The four-nation project for dealing with the Arab refugee problem presented to the United Nations by the United States and other members of the Advisory Commission of the Palestine Refugees Work and Relief Organization is expected to result in a call by certain of the refugee leaders for a march on Israel.

Five new films opened in firstrun theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall the attraction is "King Solomon's Mines," the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer adaptation of the H. Rider Haggard adventure featuring Deborah Kerr, Stewart Granger and Richard Carlson. Compton Bennett and Andrew Marton directed and Sam Zimbalist produced the offering, which was filmed in Africa in Technicolor from a script by Helen Deutsch.

A substantial reduction in operating costs together with an increased volume of business were responsible for the marked improvement in Trans World Airlines' earnings in the first nine months of 1950 compared with the similar period of last year, Warren Lee Pierson, chairman, and Ralph S. Damon, president, reported yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 8 --Yugoslavia's Chief of Staff charged today that Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary, the Danubian states that were allies of Hitler during World War II and that are now satellites of the Soviet Union, were violating the military clauses of the 1946 Paris peace treaties and building up large armies in excess of the limitations specifically fixed by those statutes.
Giving their rivals a three-goal handicap, the Toronto Maple Leafs treated the New York Rangers to a decisive drubbing in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Before this day is over between 250,000 and 300,000 telephone workers in the nation may have walked off their jobs, and the country's, communications service may be seriously disrupted. Walt Dropo, slugging first baseman of the Red Sox, is rookie of the year for 1950 in the American League.

Mr. and Mrs. Hugh McMillan of Grosse Pointe, Mich., have sent out invitations for the marriage of Mrs. McMillan's daughter, Miss Jane Olmsted Houghton, to Rollin Van Norstrand Hadley Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Rollin V. Hadley of

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8--The Midwest farm belt seemed again today to be a continuing battleground for the 1952 Presidential election as three key states returned sharply to the Republican column and other states showed significant Republican gains in yesterday's election.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 9-- Fighters and bombers of the United States Far East Air Forces struck immediately south of the Manchurian border in full strength yesterday.

Joseph Fuchs continues to be one of the most rewarding violinists in the business, as his playing at Carnegie Hall last night proved once again. He may not be the dream fiddler of the chi-chi set, but he deserves the patronage of those who care about good music performed with high and serious standards.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, Nov. 8-- This former Japanese naval base on Tokyo Bay now known as "Fleet Activities Yokosuka," is the logistical "anchor" of the United States Navy during the Korean war, a visit to the base today disclosed.

Despite wide Republican gains throughout the nation, New Jersey maintained the present party ratio in its fourteen-member delegation to the House of Representatives, and again sent nine Republicans and five Democrats to Congress.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 8--Upsetting twenty-year precedents, the Republican party has captured two traditionally Democratic Governorships in the Southwest and tonight had the edge on a third.

Sid Gary, a baritone who once was teamed in vaudeville with George Burns, will began a new radio series over WMCA next week. Entitled "Sid Gary Sings," the series will be presented on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 7:15 to 7:30 P.M.

Production of primary aluminum in the United States during the third quarter of 1950 amounted to 371,945,743 pounds, the highest level in more than six years, Donald M. White, secretary of the Aluminum Association, reported yesterday.

RED BANK, N. J., Nov. 8--Mrs. Katharine Elkins White, first woman to be elected Mayor in this seashore residential and river sports community of 15,000, expressed calm determination today to work harmoniously with the five Republican members of the Borough Council, which she will head. She said she would play the role of "watchdog" for the betterment of the town.

Culinary requests from a home cook who has had nothing but "frightful failures" in making all whole wheat bread and from a public library that cannot find a caper sauce recipe are among the daily problems that the Food News Department of THE NEW YORK TIMES is asked to solve.
Chinatown celebrated yesterday with an outbreak of fireworks and the drumming music of the "dragon" dance as its new Chinese Merchants Association headquarters was opened at Mott and Canal Streets.

Early reorganization of Tammany and displacement of Carmine G. DeSapio as its leader by a man approved by Mayor-elect Impellitteri are expected to result from Tuesday's election. A revolt against continued domination of the Democratic state organization by State Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick and National Committeeman Edward J. Flynn, Bronx leader, is another probable consequence.
A gladiolus blossom, flowers that "dance" around the handle and textured brocade are among new motifs for sterling silver flatware being shown in New York this season.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8--Claude A. Putnam, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, warned tonight that even if aggression abroad were flattened, if inflation in the United States were not crushed the country would "go down to a ruin as devastating as any shower of atom bombs a foreign country could possibly drop." AT A U.S. AIRBASE, in Korea, Nov. 8--In the world's first battle between jet planes, which took place today at a speed of 600 miles an hour close to the Manchurian border on the Korean side of the Yalu River, the score was one enemy jet destroyed and a second damaged while United States planes were unscathed.

TRENTON, Nov. 8--Superior Judge Ralph E. Smalley permitted O. John Rogge, New York lawyer, to withdraw today as a member of defense counsel for six Trenton men awaiting retrial on a murder charge.

DETROIT, Nov. 8--Michigan named a Republican to the Governors office by about 5,500 votes, elected its first woman to Congress and set an off-year voting record in yesterday's election. More than 1,900,000 ballots were cast.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 8--The existence of a thriving trade in opium-smuggling in Thailand has been called to the attention of the United Nations by officials of the United States Government.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8--Another Latin-American Chief of State will be invited to the United States during 1951. Unless plans change before Jan. 31, the added guest will be Getulio. Vargas, former dictator, whose election as president of Brazil is assured.

The Central Park carrousel, dear to the hearts of small New Yorkers since 1871, was ruined by fire before dawn yesterday. Its fortyfour gaudy wooden steeds were charred into black immobility, while fire and water combined to halt its mechanism and silence its carnival music.

TODAY through Nov. 30, daily from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., a special indoor chrysanthemum show, colorfully displayed in a Chinese garden setting with pool, bridge and bamboo fences, will be on view at the New York Botanical Garden's Conservatory in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--Secretary of State Dean Acheson ridiculed today a statement by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky that there were no Chinese Communist units fighting United Nations forces in Korea.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov 8-- The sixty-one-acre plant formerly occupied by Chance Vought Aircraft in near-by Stratford has been purchased for $2,010,000 by Robert Hirsch and seven other Bridgeport business men, it was learned here tonight. Mr. Hirsch is secretary of Marcus Hirsch Co., Inc., a real estate, insurance and travel agency.

Arthur W. Wallander, the city's Civil Defense Director, sharply rebuked Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the City Planning Commission, yesterday for "unauthorized" announcement of a plan to care for 1,500,000 Manhattan residents in the event of an atomic attack in shelters beneath parks and other public areas.

Surface returns from Tuesday's Congressional elections concededly spell trouble for the programs that President Truman wanted to put through the Eighty-second Congress if not during the waning Eighty-first. An excursion below the surface has indicated, however, that the trouble will be much deeper than can be implied by a retained, though close, numerical Administration majority in the two houses.

A gesture to ease the tensions on the Korea-Manchuria border was made last night by Sir Gladwyn Jebb, United Kingdom representative on the Security Council, who gave public assurance that the United Nations forces in Korea planned no "aggression or expansion."

Aircraft of the United States Far East Air Forces struck at North Korean communications centers, supply areas and military forces Wednesday. Joined by Marine, Royal Australian Air Force and Republic of Korea fighters, operating under the control of the Fifth Air Force, fighters and bombers pounded the Communists, particularly in the northwest area of operations.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8--President Truman's home state of Missouri stuck with him through yesterday's election and became the only state in the country to oust a Republican Senator.

Advertising in the seven major New York City newspapers for the ten-month period January through October totaled 124,738,531 lines, a gain of 6.33 per cent over the like period of 1949, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. All categories recorded gains. Financial was up by 24.57 per cent, automotive 12.54 per cent, classified 8.83 per cent, department stores 7.84 per cent, total retail 5.58 per cent, and general 4.64 per cent.

After Jan. 1, 1951, two branches of the city's oldest realty family will join forces in a merger that will continue a brokerage and management enterprise that was started in 1794 by William Cruikshank and carried on uninterruptedly by his descendants ever since.

The first Japanese-flag ship to visit New York since 1941 will arrive here next month with a cargo of 10,000 cherry trees. The plants, it was learned yesterday, will be placed aboard a vessel of the Nippon Yusen Kaisha Line. They are consigned to the United Nations headquarters here.
Rosella Hightower danced "Swan Lake" last night at the Century Theatre in the first presentation here by the Marquis de Cuevas' Grand Ballet of that venerable item.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)-- Completely reversing the trend of two years ago, Republicans have captured six Democratic Governorships and appeared virtually certain to win a seventh for a 26-22 majority across the nation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--The Administration today asked William McNear Rand, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, to take the post of Director of Price Stabilization.

Among large emissions reported approved were West Virginia's $90,000,000 war veterans' bonus proposal, and Michigan's $65,000,000 hospital borrowing. WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall today presented to an Air Force captain and a rear admiral the National Air Council's 1950 awards for outstanding achievement in aviation research.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 8-- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said here tonight that apparently a statement he had made earlier in the day that "it looks as if I may have to go to Europe" had been misunderstood at a press conference, leading to an incorrect assumption that he had been definitely assigned to a command in Europe.
The 200,000 votes for Governor polled by the American Labor party this year constitutes a new low-water mark for its nominees for that position.

Better action at retail in men's wear lines in the last week or so has strengthened confidence that Christmas holiday sales of this merchandise will range close to 10 per cent above last year, according to market estimates here yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 8--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that Western Germany would make an adequate contribution to the defense of Western Europe so long as it enjoyed equal rights and was part of a coalition sufficiently strong to deter Russian aggression.

The list of companies announcing special dividend declarations for stockholders continued to swell yesterday, with four of them increasing disbursements, eight voting extras, two issuing stock and three resuming dividend payments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission today authorized the Northeastern Gas Transmission Company, Boston, to supply a part of New England with natural gas.

Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, has accepted the chairmanship of a major fund-raising campaign in behalf of the American National Theatre and Academy, the Congress-chartered organization designed-to encourage interest in the legitimate theatre on a national basis.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 8--An undercurrent of concern appeared here today regarding future American support of United Nations aid programs in view of the outcome of yesterday's elections.

Two little girls with long yellow pigtails put on a polished show of ice-skating skill yesterday at a rally starting observance of Hospital Week here.

An automobile windshield designed to reduce road glare and sun heat was shown yesterday by the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company. The protective factors consist of slightly tinted bluish-green safety plate glass with graduated shading above the eye level.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 8--According to present plans, a treaty establishing the economic union of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg will be signed here next month, but the union will not be the one orginally conceived by the three Governments exiled in London during the war.

Three motorcycle policemen had only moderate difficulty yesterday in rescuing Robert Baker from a swampy Brooklyn meadow. It was the 13-year-old's unbridled imagination that caused the real trouble.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 8 --The increasingly successful program of Puerto Rico to raise the living standards of its people is catching the Administration in a crossfire in which wages are not keeping pace either with living costs or with a growing desire for more consumer goods.

Say a few words of welcome and appreciation to Christopher Fry and John Gielgud. For Mr. Fry is author of "The Lady's Not for Burning," which was put on at the Royale last evening, and Mr. Gielgud leads the company that is playing it brilliantly. Little puffs of enthusiasm have been coming out of England for months over Mr. Fry's witchery with words.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it has approved an amended plan of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation of New York to effect further compliance with the Holding Company Act.

The first local public demonstrations of color television will be initiated Tuesday by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Ten color receivers are being installed on the ground floor of the former Tiffany Building at 401 Fifth Avenue, near Thirty-seventh Street, where several hundred persons can be accommodated for each presentation.

War developments in the Far East continued to dominate prices in the strategic import commodities on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Tin futures shattered all previous records, while natural crude rubber futures advanced the permissible limit of 200 points, or 2 cents a pound, under the domination of the primary markets at Singapore and London, where the markets set thirty-two-year highs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--Secretary of State Dean Acheson told the press today that he had "no intention whatever" of resigning as a result of the election victory of some of his most avid critics.

MOSCOW, Nov. 8--What is a word in three letters that warmongers fear more than anything else? What, in five letters, is Gen. Douglas MacArthur's concept of a courtesy call? What force causes helpless rage among warmongers (five letters)?
HARTFORD, Nov. 8--Senator William Benton edged to a 1,484vote victory today over Prescott Bush, his Republican rival in Tuesday's election, but Republican leaders said they would contest the result.

Although the Korean conflict was expected to increase the number of emotionally disturbed children brought to the juvenile courts of New York for breaking laws, it has in fact caused no increase, Justice John Warren Hill, Presiding Justice of the Domestic Relations Court, reported last night. He attributed this to the effectiveness of the preventive programs now established in the city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--The Senate Subcommittee on Elections and Privileges will delve into campaign spending in Ohio as a part of a broadened inquiry into election expenditures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that he foresaw no change in United States foreign policy as a result of the elections, and declared with unusual emphasis that he had no intention of resigning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8--A Republican gain of one United States Senate seat and one seat in the House was the West Coast's total contribution to the changed Congressional picture emerging from yesterday's election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--A 33 per cent drop in college enrollments of war veterans was reported today by Dr. Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--The United States Coast Guard and the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics today were granted the right to issue "D.O." (Defense Order) ratings for their purchases. This authority, which heretofore has been confined to the Department of Defense and to the Atomic Energy Commission, was extended to the two additional agencies by orders of William H. Harrison, Administrator of the National Production Authority.

MANILA, Nov. 8--Aid to the Philippines, supervised and administered by the Economic Cooperation Administration, in accordance with the Bell mission's recommendations, was tactfully offered today by William C. Foster, E.C.A. administrator, who is visiting Manila for President Truman.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8-- The opening of the Big Three series here Saturday will send one of the best Princeton teams since the championship outfit of 1935 against a Harvard eleven seeking its first victory of the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--A number of distillers agreed today with the Senate Crime Investigating Committee to study the possibility of excluding known gangsters and criminals from the ranks of their wholesale distributors. A study committee will be established to make recommendations by Dec. 1.
PARIS, Nov. 8--Officials here are strongly convinced that the way is being prepared for an agreement between Washington and Paris on the rearming of Germans for Western defense.

Twenty-five years ago junior clothes began to be treated as fashion. It was the Judy 'n Jill styles, the pretty, young, modish dresses designed and manufactured by Jack Horwitz and his two partners, that started the trend. Yesterday the concern celebrated its silver jubilee with a fashion show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 8 --Plans are being made for Wilhelm Furtwaengler and the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra to make a tour of major cities in the United States beginning next spring, it was learned here today.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 8--Associates of Senator Robert A. Taft made no secret today of their belief that the Republican Senate Leader had put himself out in front of the race for the party's 1952 Presidential nomination by polling the biggest vote ever cast for a Senatorial candidate in this state.

Braising, boiling and stewing may not be the quickest or most glamorous methods of meat cookery, but for the housewife on a budget they are often the most practical. It requires more time to prepare meats in this way rather than to broil them, but they need little attention while on the stove and the investment in minutes may prove worth-while since less tender and hence frequently less costly cuts may be used.

PARIS, Nov. 8--Devoting her mid-season opening to Christmas party frocks, Maggy Rouff concentrates interest on gracious, plunging necklines. Very wide, square and dipping to below the bust, the necklines are filled in by a heartshaped modesty in identical or contrasting fabric.

Harry La Montagne, a racetracker for half a century, got a first dividend of $3,250 on a $36,000 investment when the Blue Larkspur 3-year-old, Steel Blue, won the best of the Empire City-at-Jamaica races yesterday. Those in the crowd of 18,412 who had backed Steel Blue into favoritism got $4.50 in exchange for each $2 ticket.

BOSTON, Nov. 8--Gov. Paul A. Dever of Massachusetts emerged today from his smashing re-election triumph as the logical Democratic candidate to face Republican Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. in 1952.
