Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy met yesterday with Brooklyn District Attorney Miles McDonald and representatives of District Attorney offices in the other four boroughs to formulate plans for a practical course on court procedure for... BUTLIN'S WINS NEW DELAY

Black or white for sharper drama in evening fashions was Russeks' well-illustrated theme in yesterday's presentation at the Plaza Hotel. Theatre suits and short dinner frocks offered glimpses of black in paillette or...
Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said yesterday that a heavily-laden national food basket would halt any inflationary spiral and obviate the need for rationing and price controls.

PARIS, NOV. 9--Upon constitutional grounds, the National Assembly rejected today, by 466 to 98, a motion for the release of former Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain from imprisonment on the island of Yeu, off the Brittany coast.

PARIS, Nov. 9--Three projects for the development of science, including a long-range survey of all scientific activities of United Nations countries, were approved today by the executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

CONWAY, S.C., Nov. 9 (U.P.) --Masked nightriders have ter rorized an ailing farmer and his two sons, it was reported today, as the sheriff and a local Ku Klux Klan leader each blamed the other for the incident.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9-- Serious misgivings over the legal validity of certain of the principles applied in the Nuremberg trials and of their subsequent formulation by the International Law Commission were voiced in the United Nations General Assembly's Legal Committee today.

The Rev. Dr William P. Merrill, minister emeritus of the Brick Presbyterian Church and formerly president of trustees of the Church Peace Union, and Dr. Harry N. Holmes, field secretary emeritus of the World Alliance for...
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 9 --The first Puerto Rican plunge into Government-subsidized industry ended last month with the sale of five plants to private operators.

Only a small proportion of all cerebral palsy cases can be attributed to obstetrical mistakes; Dr. Winthrop Phelps reported here yesterday afternoon at a session of the Cerebral Palsy Institute sponsored by the New York City Coordinating Council for Cerebral Palsy.

Reflecting the renewed demand for credit for cotton, grains and other commodities, business loans by New York banks advanced $48,000,000 last week to set a new high total of $5,908, 000,000. The rise, during the week ended on Wednesday, marks the twenty-second increase in twenty-three weeks.

Kentucky's wonder five of a couple of years back, bolstered by considerable outside support and now playing under the banner of Indianapolis, thoroughly spoiled the home debut of the New York Knickerbockers last night.

The Philharmonic-Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall last night was a pastiche of dark and romantic colors, poetical melodiousness and gusty outbursts. Dimitri Mitropoulos is repaying--with interest--the debt he incurred by offering atonal music last week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)-- The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization voted unanimously today to continue its advisory committee on world food problems.
Sam Jethroe of the Boston Braves is the National League's rookie of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Those Senate Democrats who favor the moderate rather than the radical approach to public questions will control the actions of the Eighty-second Congress to the extent they wish in consequence of Tuesday's election. This group is known as "conservative" to the...

Chrysanthemums in all shades of yellow and gold are a dominant note among the thousands of flowers assembled for the annual autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York. The three-day show, which opened yesterday in the Colonnades Ballroom of Essex House, Central Park...

An at least temporary loss of contact with Chinese Communist troops in Northern Korea is reported from the United Nations front. It is possible that the enemy, having been once contained, is regrouping for a fresh assault. If so, the next few days may see fighting as severe as any that has taken place in Korea. Such an attack would mean, also, a definite end to the hopes for early pacification.

The stock market extended its advance yesterday, scoring the best gain in more than a month. Furthering the response to the national election results, all segments of the list again participated in the rise, with some fairly impressive gains in the investment type of issues.
A survey of metropolitan package stores yesterday disclosed a definite shortage of top Scotch whisky brands and indicated that supplies would be even smaller by the holidays.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 10--Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters officially stated yesterday for the first time that strong forces of the Chinese Communist Army, estimated at 60,000 men, had entered the Korean war with an equal number of reinforcements believed to be on the way to oppose the United Nations march to the Manchurian border.

Removal of tension, fears and hostilities, the acceptance of a feminine and maternal role, may help explain a previously childless woman's having a baby after she and her husband have adopted a child, Dr. Abraham Stone, director of the Margaret Sanger Research Bureau, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP)-- Oscar Collazo, Puerto Rican Nationalist, boasted so much about his attempt to assassinate President Truman that he "put the finger" on a number of suspected accomplices arrested in New York.

Palmer Plastics, Inc., manufacturer of plastic toys and novelties, has leased the one-story building at 23-31 Stone Avenue, Brooklyn, from Koepel Brothers, Inc., through the Kalmon Dolgin Company, broker. The lessee is moving from Long Island City to obtain larger quarters.
Formation of a committee to seek what it termed "constructive corporate defense taxation" in stead of the proposed excess profits tax was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Secretary of State Dean Acheson, assailing talk of preventive war as "selfdestructive hysteria," called upon the nation tonight to keep "clearly in mind" the moral purposes behind its efforts for material and military superiority.

A generally discouraging outlook for the American merchant marine and the shipbuilding and repair industries was reported yesterday by John B. Woodward Jr., president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9--Secretary General Trygve Lie asked the United Nations today to set aside $1,117,000 to reimburse employes who are nationals of the United States for their income taxes this year.

Facilities for the treatment of emotional illness in this country are "incredibly poor," with only the "very, very rich" and the people who are so sick they must go to mental hospitals, able to get help, Oren Root Jr., president of the newly formed National Association for Mental Health, declared yesterday.
As a result of agreement among all police officials of the state on a curriculum for training auxiliary police, the active enrollment of auxiliaries will soon begin in this city.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week dropped 712,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 104,350,000 barrels, compared with 105,062,000 a week earlier and 104,257,000 a year ago.

Thirty-three thousand telephone workers went on strike yesterday in forty-two states and the District of Columbia, curtailing long distance service somewhat but not hampering local operations in most cities.
Both the local pro coaches, Red Strader of the Yanks and Steve Owen of the Giants, were busily repairing their football fences yesterday.
DETROIT, Friday, Nov. 10 (UP) --The Democratic Governor, G. Mennen Williams, took a lastminute lead over his Republican challenger for the Michigan Govnership early today.

Members of the Democratic County Committee of the Fourth Assembly District, South, elected Bert Stand, former secretary of Tammany, leader of the district in place of William J. Ahearn at a meeting last evening in the auditorium of Seward Park High School, Grand and Essex Streets.

Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare, charged yesterday that "the Communist element and those who adhere to it have already begun the work of consciously undermining the civilian defense of the city."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee will look into conditions in the Far West, it was announced here today. Senators Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee; Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, and Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, will hold the hearings.
Shipping receipts at the Port of New York rose last month to a new high for 1950, reflecting the continuing steady increase of import values.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8-- The Atomic Energy Commission, the Department of Defense and the Air Force have approved the scenario of "High Frontier," R.K.O.'s photoplay about a B-36 bomber squadron which Luther Davis has written, the studio disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 9--A program of retrenchment, aimed at placing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on a self-sustaining basis by this fiscal year's close, was announced today by board members. The agency expects to cut administrative expenses to $11,000,000, compared with the $16,000,000 expended on salaries and operating costs last year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 9--A special agreement is being negotiated in Washington under which Yugoslavia would benefit for the first time from the Marshall Plan. It is planned that 100,000 tons of flour should be sent here from Western Germany and Italy in an emergency move to avert the threat of famine.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 9--The political tug of war that has rent the First Congressional District since Election Day still has not decided to everybody's satisfaction who won the race.

Laurent Dauthuille, the French middleweight who has had one shot at the middleweight championship of the world, will make the first appearance of his career in a New York ring when he faces Paddy Young of Greenwich Village in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Joe Adonis, the racketeer, and four of his underworld associates found themselves yesterday the targets of a New York County grand jury's criminal information alleging that they had conspired here to violate the gambling laws of this State and New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--The Department of Defense announced today that Mrs. Anna Marie Rosenberg of New York had been recommended for the post of Assistant Secretary of Defense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Personal income in September achieved a new high annual rate of $228,300,000,000, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today. The figure was $2,900,000,000 more than the August total which also had established a record.

The television manufacturing industry, which can make a mistake the same as anyone else, currently is responsible for a serious abuse of the normal concern of parents for the well-being of their children.

PARIS, Nov. 9--In strawberry reds, soft yellows, black and white, Jacques Heim's mid-season collection of simple, wearable frocks concentrates interest on skirts. Bodices are of tailored simplicity, gently bloused in back.
TOKYO, Nov. 9 (AP)--Release 628, issued by General MacArthur's headquraters at 4:40 P.M., Thursday (2:40 A.M., Thursday, Eastern standard time):

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that its application for court enforcement of the amended plan of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation of New York, to effect further compliance with the Holding Company Act, will be heard in the United States District Court of Delaware on Dec. 15.

A brief work stoppage by longshoremen that caused a virtual suspension of activity on four of the United States Lines North River piers from late Tuesday till noon yesterday ended when the men appeared for the 1 P.M. shape-up.

LONDON, Nov. 9--Strenuous efforts now are being exerted in London, Paris and Washington to resolve the differences between France and the United States on German participation in Europe's defense and clear away that obstacle to the rapid formation of collective military forces.

THE roster of football's major unbeaten powers has now shrunk to six and only Cali fornia would seem to be endangered this week-end as Army, Princeton, Kentucky, Miami and Oklahoma face more digestible opposition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Indications that the armed services have shaved their original requests for cotton were seen in the easing today of governmental restrictions on exports of raw cotton. The Government increased its export...
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 9-- Against the background of cowboys, cactus and casinos, a showdown between labor and management is brewing as part of Nevada's political situation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9--The Soviet Union formally requested today that the United Nations grant "independence immediately" to Eritrea, former Italian colony, and order Britain's "occupation forces" out of the Red Sea territory within ninety days.
Bronx County Judge Samuel J. Joseph yesterday sentenced a youth who had stolen $3 to serve from twenty to thirty years at the Elmira Reception Center.

A series of desks, tables and chairs characterized by the restrained architectural style for which the makers have become noted were introduced yesterday by the Herman Miller Furniture Company. Most of the designs were from the drafting board of architect George Nelson, but there were also a few variations on the Charles Eames pieces.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 9--Guatemala appears calm on the eve of a three-day election period for choosing a successor to President Juan Jos Arevalo, whose sixyear term will end on March 15. Block-long lines wait to register and obtain voting cards, with women and men in about equal numbers.

AFTER the failure to conquer Tunis in December [1942] the force of our initial blow in North-West Africa was spent, and the German High Command was able temporarily to restore stability in Tunisia. Refusing to recognise that he could not safeguard by sea or air even on the short passage between Sicily and Tunis, Hitler ordered the creation of a new army in Tunisia to meet the impending Allied attacks from both east and west...
With prices continuing to edge downward on both broilers and fowl, a "chicken in every pot" should be a budget-wise objective this week-end. Shoppers will find the smaller birds especially abundant.

The "advance guard" of an expected 20,000 veterans of both World Wars attending the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division reunion here through Sunday marched into City Hall Plaza yesterday to receive the city's felicitations and welcome from Mayorelect Impellitteri.
Baseball's "comeback of the year" award yesterday went to Eddie Waitkus, the Phillies' fine first baseman, who escaped death by a narrow margin.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov.9-- With an elaborate ceremony befitting his royal status and long reign, King Gustaf V was laid to rest here at noon today in Riddarholm Church, burial place of Swedish kings since the Middle Ages. An impressive turnout accompanied to his last resting place the monarch, who died Oct. 29 after ruling his country for nearly forty-three years.
Eschewing soapbox protestations for a change, Clifford Odets has written and directed a backstage drama, "The Country Girl," which gets under way at 8 o'clock this evening at the Lyceum.

We know that our younger readerswill be expecting some comment from us promptly on that fire up in Central Park that ruined the carrousel. Well, we feel mighty sorry about it. We are aware that it was more important, in some circles, than a Republican sweep...

The Department of Sanitation, satisfied with the success of its three-month experiment to prevent parked vehicles from hampering street cleaning operations, will extend the plan to other parts of the city within two weeks.

Maj. Gen. Raymond W. Bliss, Surgeon General of the Army, who has recently returned from an exhaustive survey of the Medical Service in Korea and the Far East Command, reported here yesterday that the death rate among wounded American troops in Korea was less than 2 per cent as compared with 4.5 per cent in World War II and 8 per cent in World War I.

The New York City Youth Board formally started in Brooklyn yesterday its first major-scale project to fight teen-age delinquency by assigning a coordinated staff of trained young men and women to work directly with street gangs.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Nov. 9-- The differences between the French and leaders of the Bao Dai Government were regarded as having been moderated during the visit here of Jean Letourneau, French Minister for the IndoChina States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--An unidentified former, naval offices was cited today by the Senate Armed Services Preparedness Subcommittee as the shrewdest operator in surplus war materials it had discovered. The subcommittee's account of his dealings was filled with admiration and even a little envy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9--With the war scare subsiding and no special news to influence the market, grain futures were extremely irregular here today, with price changes reflecting many trade cross-currents.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 9-- Adrian W. Maher of Bridgeport, United States Attorney for Connecticut, said tonight that he was prepared to seek an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the disputed election between Senator William Benton, incumbent Democrat, and Prescott S. Bush of Greenwich, the Republican nominee.

A model house that suggests solutions for most of the problems present in a modern house with a glass wall and an open floor plan is now on view at the Robert Morris Park Development in Morristown, N.J.

Mrs. Albert G. Bostwick of Westbury, L. I., and Henry W. Sage of 555 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Sage, to H. Lawrence Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raeburn H. Parker of Monkton, Md., formerly of Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

The Columbia football squad will leave this morning for Hanover, N.H., and tomorrow, as Lou Little sees it, the Lions will face a betterrounded football team in Dartmouth than the Cornell eleven they conquered in one of the season's most notable reversals.

The career of Tommy Henrich as a Yankee regular seemed ended yesterday when after failing to receive assurance from Dr. George Bennett of Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, that an operation would restore his left knee to full efficiency, Tommy decided against surgery.

Dr. Charles Phillips, Cooper, Professor Emeritus of Journalism at Columbia University and for thirty years a New York newspaper man, died yesterday morning at his home, 476 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness. Dr. Cooper, who was in his eighty-fifth year, was a former night city editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES. A funeral service will be held at the home at 2 P.M. tomorrow.
The present annual magnesium production capacity of 48,000,000 pounds will shortly be increased fourfold to 240,000,000 pounds and more of the metal may be available for commercial use.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)--A shortage of scientific manpower may limit research and development in strategic Alaska, a Defense Department official said today.
State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick declared yesterday he "had no thought" of promulgating a 15 per cent increase in rent ceilings in this city.
BIRMINGHAM, ALA., Nov. 9 (AP)--Temple W. Tutwiler, widely known Birmingham businessman, died today after a long illness, at the age of 71.
The wage increase granted to workers in the coat and suit industry will have no immediate effect on prices of spring lines now being opened, according to manufacturers in the trade.
Plans for taking 2,000 scholars and professional men from dis placed persons camps in Europe and settling them in fitting jobs in this country were described yesterday.

The Board of Elections started yesterday its canvass of the New York, City vote in Tuesday's election and David B. Costuma, its secretary, announced that the check of the vote for Mayor would be completed next Tuesday. At City Hall plans went ahead immediately to swear in Mayor-elect Impellitteri as Mayor on that day.
American Tobacco Company and its consolidated subsidiaries reported yesterday an estimated net income for the third quarter of $13,684,000 after all charges, including increased taxes.

ABOARD THE YACHT MY MARY GAIL, Nov. 9--President Truman, cruising today in Chesapeake Bay, was acknowledging hundreds of 'messages' expressing gratification that he was not hurt in the attempt to kill him a week ago yesterday.
LOGANSPORT, Ind., Nov. 9 (AP) --More than a score of persons were injured slightly as a Pennsylvania Railroad train rammed the tender of a standing switch engine here today.

There was a bit of a surprise in the top contest at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday. Curruhuinca, a 6-year-old horse from the Argentine, won it with nary a bit of trouble in the role of $19.50-for-$2 fifth choice in a field of nine.

Recent charges by the International Fur and Leather Workers Union of America that raw fur dealers impede operations of the fur industry by increasing prices were denied last night by David R. Hochberg, retiring president of the American Fur Merchants Association.

We live in a world so fraught with dire developments and vast global problems that it is only too easy to ignore or accept relatively minor catastrophes. One such is occurring these days on the Bulgarian-Turkish frontier and it involves 250,000 innocent human beings.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 9 (AP)-- A twenty-year-reign of Democratic Governors in Arizona was broken tonight.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 9 (AP)--The somewhat unusual situation of a college football coach announcing his retirement while his team was on top--and in the middle of the season--came today as Blair Cherry said he would step down at the University of Texas when the 1950 campaign is finished.

The opera last night at the Metropolitan was "The Flying Dutchman," and the performance has as many superlative futures to recommend it as the production of "Don Carlo" on the opening Monday night of the season.

The New York City general fund is benefiting by nearly $400,000 a year in increased court fees levied in the Municipal Court. It was reported this money originally was intended for use in raising the salaries of both the justices and the employes of the court.

Three shipping men in the American operating field and a New York marine insurance expert will be named by the Department of State to advise the Government in the coming shipping conference of the Atlantic Pact nations, it was reliably reported last night.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9-- Seven faculty members and two non-academic employes of San Francisco State College were dismissed today for failing to sign the state's new special loyalty oath.

The State of Connecticut executed long-term and short-term borrowings totaling $45,500,000 in the public market yesterday. The transactions consisted of the sale of $15,500,000 of bonds due from 1951 to 1970, and of $30,000,000 of housing notes due Nov. 20, 1951.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 (AP)--Some persons in this industrial center still do not know who won the election.

Debutantes of recent seasons, including the Misses Jo Jeanne Millon and Mary Hicks Edson, are aiding members of the executive committees in plans for the Fan Ball to be held on the night of Dec. 13 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund.

A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., dropped several Axminster patterns yesterday from its running carpet lines at the standard 12 per cent trade discount for discontinued merchandise Jack Lees, general sales manager, emphasized...

We believe everybody was fed up with political speeches and the other paraphernalia of campaigning at least two weeks before Election Day. Most of the orators were thoroughly worn out, repeating themselves like a cracked phonograph record. The already convinced party faithful were, as usual, the mainstay audience at rallies. The unconvinced could stay comfortably at home and take their fill by radio or television.
CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 9-- It has been brought home to us more clearly than ever during the last few days just how much the character and attitude of a guide can affect the quality of a hunting trip.

The Kings County District Attorney's office received yesterday a major legal setback when the Appellate Division, Second Department, ruled that former Police Inspector Frederick A. Hofsaes was within his constitutional rights in refusing to appear before the gambling investigating grand jury under a waiver of immunity signed while a member of the Police Department.
Year-end dividend announcements were again numerous yesterday, with extra distributions announced by sixteen companies, seventeenyear-end declarations, three increases and two stock dividends.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 9 --Western Germany faces some austerity in the coming year as its resources are built up for the Western defense program, Allied and German authorities indicated today.

The difficulty of simply speaking and acting as one thinks right was said last night by Sir Benegal N. Rau, India's permanent representative in the United Nations, to be a characteristic of his new republic's foreign policy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (UP)--Snow fell in Mobile, Ala., and fur coats appearedr in Mississippi today as winter's first cold wave chilled much of the nation.

Within thirteen minutes after being notified, a police helicopter left its base at Floyd Bennett Field, made a landing yesterday and rescued an injured youth and flew him to a waiting ambulance a mile away.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 10--Col. Alfred G. Katzin of South Africa, who has been special. United Nations representative in Korea, was named today to fulfill the role of Agent General in Korea until the General Assembly approves the machinery for administration of Korean relief and reconstruction.
The establishment of the United Nations in this country permits observers from all parts of the world to observe the American scene at their leisure.
The nation's steel mills shattered all production records last month, turning out 8,718,978 tons.
At last Clifford Odets has really got down to work. "The Country Girl," which opened at the Lyceum last evening, is the best play he has written for years, and perhaps the best of his career.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 10-- The Government of Tibet has appealed directly to the United Nations to use its good offices for "peaceful settlement" of ChineseTibetan relations, the Indian Ministry of External Affairs said today.
ABOARD THE PRESS YACHT MY MARY GAIL, Nov. 10--President Truman appointed John D. Small of New York as chairman of the Munitions Board today.

UPTON, L.I., Nov. 10--At Brookhaven National Laboratory, where 180 of the nation's leading theoretical and experimental physicists have gathered for a two-day conference, there were strong indications today that the physics textbooks are in for another drastic revision.

In one of the most unusual lifts ever attempted in the harbor, salvage crews of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation raised yesterday a 150-ton bow section of the dredge Sandcraft, which was sunk July 2 after colliding with the collier Melrose in the Narrows.

AT AN AIRBASE IN JAPAN, Nov. 10--Business is wonderful in this town. Until the war broke out in Korea the principal activity was fishing, but now it is the sale of beer to United States fliers. This is the place from which Maj. Gen. William H. Tunner's airlift takes off for Korea.

Pittsburgh Steel Company increased its earnings in the first nine months this year to $3,981,942 from $1,972,285 shown in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 10--Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza told the Chamber of Deputies today that the Italian Government had been considering recognition of Mao Tse-tung's regime, but that after the intervention of Communist Chinese troops in Korea it had postponed a final decision.

Special awards for outstanding performances in the line of duty were presented to thirteen employer of American Airlines yesterday at the Wings Club in the Biltmore Hotel.
The City of Los Angeles, Calif., announced yesterday the indefinite postponement of a sale of $13,600,000 of bonds originally planned to be offered on Dec. 5.

A "sneak preview" of a live television program in full color was put on the air yesterady morning by the Columbia Broadcasting System as a preliminary to public demonstrations scheduled to start next Tuesday.

Federal mediation efforts failed yesterday to end the virtually nation-wide telephone walkout as strikers adopted new hit-and-run picket line tactics. A total of 120,000 workers had become involved in the stoppage.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10-- Dr. Harlan B. Perrins of 14 Wright Lane, Hamden, an obstetrician and gynecologist with an office here at 59 Trumbull Street, died last midnight is Grace Hospital.

Mark Linder, playwright, actor and producer died on Thursday evenings apparently of a heart attack, as the was alighting from a bus en route to his home at 1684 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx. His age was 69.

Dick Shea broke his own course record in retaining the individual title and leading Army to its fourth straight team victory in the twelfth annual cross-country championship of the Heptagonal Games Association at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Retail sales here remained below figures established last year, according to estimates made yesterday by trade observers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 (AP)--A Cornell professor recommended here today that elderly inmates of institutions be subjected to "harmless nutrition studies" to determine whether certain diet changes might slow the processes of aging.

Howard C. Kelly, chairman of the Board of Higher Education's finance committee, promised support yesterday for salary increase requests submitted by spokesmen for the staffs of the four municipally owned colleges.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 (AP)--William M. Rand, St. Louis financier and president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, today turned down a chance to become the Federal director of price stabilization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10--Brief experience with voluntary controls have convinced officials that production controls are best administered through regulations backed up by industry cooperation, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, told a news conference here today.

DETROIT, Nov. 10--The topsyturvy Michigan Gubernatorial election took another in its many turns tonight when the latest "error" in the returns sent the Republican candidate, former Gov. Harry F. Kelly, back into the lead with a 306-vote margin.

Six patterns for the new Encanto shape by the Franciscan China Company are on view at the Franciscan Galleries, 45 East Fifty-first Street. TORQUAY, England, Nov. 12-- The future of the sterling area is once again very much in the balance. A combination of internal strains, reminders of commitments under international agreements and renewed United States pressure for modifications of the essential features of sterling monetary policy have hit the British all at the same time.

Construction will begin late this month on the new Beekman-Downtown Hospital. William C. Langley is vice president of the institution and chairman of its building fund.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 7--New municipal councils will be elected in the fourteen leading cities and towns of Israel on Nov. 14. Rural areas will elect thirty local councils on the same day, in the first countrywide elections for local administrations.
The bees of Bronx Park have moved indoors to buzz around the chrysanthemums that are arranged this year as a Chinese Garden in House No. 4 of the conservatory in the New York Botanical Garden.

CINCINNATI, Nov.12--The National Council of the Joint Defense Appeal today adopted a budget of $5,784,321 for 1951 to be used by the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in promoting intergroup relations and combating bigotry and discrimination throughout the country.

SANTA FE, N.M., Nov. 12 (AP) --A woman physician who blamed financial worries was held today in the kidnapping of 9-year-old Linda Stamm. The woman faces a maximum, penalty of death. Thirty waiting officers seized Dr. Nancy Campbell, 43-year-old obstetrician, last night as she reached for a $20,000 ransom.

PARIS, Nov. 12--France is ready for another four-power conference if she were assured that it could reach an acceptable solution Foreign Minister Robert Schuman said today, in a presumed reference to the Soviet Union.

Dried fruits of all kinds now are higher in price than a year ago-- in some cases by as much as 25 per cent. These increases, unfortunate news for housewives who expected to utilize the fruits in the holidays and winter months ahead, are attributed by the trade to a number of factors.

Heretofore Lester Meyer has been content to coast along as a co-producer on Broadway. WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (U.P.)-- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, asked Attorney General J. Howard McGrath today to bring an antitrust suit against the newsprint industry for "making uniform price changes."

The Long Island Duck Growers Marketing Cooperative, Inc., Eastport, L.I., is starting a promotion program to widen its markets and to assist the retail trade in the movement of Long Island ducklings. Newspaper advertising is scheduled for eastern and southern cities in cooperation with corporate chains, supermarket operators and retailers for the fall and winter. Brooke, Smith, French Dorrance, Inc., is handling the account.

Despite higher prices and some shortages, desirable values were offered in various wholesale markets here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Some manufacturers found it necessary to clear inventories and concentrate on production of new lines.

Mayor-elect Impellitteri indicated yesterday that he intended to go slow in accepting or rejecting tentative peace feelers that have reached him from the Democratic party chieftains who supported Ferdinand Pecora for the Mayoralty.

There was very little the Chicago Black Hawks could do wrong in their National Hockey League game against the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The energetic sextet from the Windy City turned in a fine exhibition in setting down the blue-jerseyed skaters by 4--1 before a crowd of 10,415.
Mrs. Edward H. Sothern, who as Julia Marlowe was one of the famous actresses of the American theatre, died yesterday after a brief illness, in her apartment at the Plaza Hotel. She was 85 years old.

The strain of inordinately tough schedules is beginning to tell on the powerhouses of college football Ohio State, Oklahoma, Texas and Southern Methodist University showed signs of coming loose at the seams Saturday and the Mustangs suffered their second successive defeat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--The public officials who administer state liquor laws, mindful of the need for more uniform regulation, proposed today a set of twentyfour principles to be used as guideposts for attaining that objective.

LONDON, Nov. 12--Sooner or later soaring commodity prices are going to involve difficulties for many industries but it is only short views that are being taken and to most market observers here the short-term outlook still appears to be favorable enough.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12--Developments in Korea started the week with soaring prices for all grains and soybeans; new highs being established for the season. Old crop deliveries of wheat were close to the high crop levels. Short covering was on a tremendous scale in all pits, lifting prices rapidly.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 12--The entry of the Chinese Communists into the Korean war has indefinitely postponed the invasion threat to Formosa, island citadel of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

One of the last properties ownedby the once-famous Merchants and Miners. Line--extensive pier and loading facilities at India Point, Providence, R.I.--has been sold to Melvin T. Berry, president of the Barton Corporation. The property is assessed at $321,020 but no purchase price was announced.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 12-- The annual two-day tournament of the Northeast Field Hockey Association which attracted 160 women athletes from New York, Connecticut, New Hampshire and Massachusetts came to a close today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--President Truman was reported tonight to be in sympathy with a move to increase the Republican representation on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee from five members to six.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 12--Recent figures show a big rise in Industrial production. On the basis of 1938 equaling 100, the average daily production index for September has jumped to 151, against 134 for August. Production now is 50 per cent above pre-war.
Political observers seem to agree that the most dramatic and the most important single event in last Tuesday's elections was Senator Taft's victory in Ohio.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 12--Ninety-five per cent of the students at Vassar want to be married and have children before they are 30 years old a year-long survey of the college's "social climate" showed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)-- Tommy Thompson's sparkling passing and fine running by Steve Van Bnren and Frank Ziegler led the Philadelphia Eagles to an easy 33-0 victory over the Washington Redskins today before 29,407.

Of the major musical presentations on television the Fred Waring show has been rather consistently the most imaginative and professional. Mount Sinai Hospital announced last night that it had received a gift of $1,000,000 from Frank Z. Atran, a Russian-born citizen of the United States who came here ten years ago.

The engagement of Miss Mary Newbold Cross, daughter of Mrs. W. Redmond Cross of 12 East Eightieth Street, and of Bernardsville, N.J., and the late Mr. Cross, to Donald Pond Spence, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph B. Spence of Bronxville, N.Y., has been announced by her mother. The wedding will take place in June.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 12-- The Indian Government announced today firm measures to prevent the Congress party of Nepal from using Indian territory as a base of operations against the independent kingdom of Nepal.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12--The steel industry in the face of tight scrap, ore end coal markets was able last week to boost its operating rate to 103 per cent of rated capacity, up one-half a point from the week before, for a new record in steel-making.

ZURICH, Nov. 12--Responding to many requests from the United States for more exact particulars of proposals for speedy liquidation of German pre-war foreign debts reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 23, Rudolf J. Ernst, manager of the Union Bank of Switzerland, in Basle, has just drafted a concise survey of what for the sake of brevity now is being called the "Ernst Plan."

Because of a drop in engineering school enrollments, the United States faces a serious shortage of engineers, according to a nationwide survey sponsored by the manpower committee of the American Society for Engineering Education.

Another busy week in the art galleries includes more than a score of one-man shows by both well-known and less familiar artists, working in a wide variety of media and manners, and several group exhibitions of equal diversity.

LONDON, Nov. 12--Following the collapse and removal to Warsaw of the Communist-supported World Peace Congress, which was to have begun at Sheffield tomorrow, the British Peace Committee appealed today for a "Pay for Peace Protest Fund" of 20,000 ($56,000).

The recently promulgated dogma of the Roman Catholic Church on the bodily Assumption of the Virgin Mary into Heaven was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken as being without "a shred of Biblical evidence to support it" and as a "perversion of the Gospel."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 12--Dr. James E. Pollard, director of the Ohio State University School of Journalism, announced here today the election of the late Carr V. Van Anda, former managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and the late Robert F. Wolfe, former publisher of The Columbus Dispatch and The Ohio State Journal, to the Ohio Journalism Hall of Fame.

Curbs on new construction, as announced recently by the National Production Authority, threaten to stifle work in the planning stage and to reduce sharply the supply of skilled labor in the building industry without making a "sound" contribution to the national defense, the New York Building Congress protested yesterday.
The Magnesium Association called yesterday for increased supplies of the metal, a critical defense item.
Last night's piano recital by Ray Lev was her twenty-fourth appearance in Carnegie Hall--not a poor showing for a young woman who made her debut there only nine years ago.

A memorial service for the dead of the Seventh Regiment was held yesterday afternoon at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The service was preceded by a parade from the armory at Park Avenue at Sixty-seventh Street.

Eight hundred members of the Catholic War Veterans, Department of New York, and their women's auxiliary attended the organization's annual Armistice Day memorial mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12--The marriage of Miss Annette Troth Riley, daughter of Mrs. Woodbridge Riley of Chestnut Hill, to Varian Mackey Fry of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Varian Fry of Ridgewood, N.J., took place here yesterday at the home of the bride's mother. The Rev. Harry B. Scholefield performed the ceremony.

Henry A. Wallace called upon the United States last night to increase its armed strength "as fast as possible" until Russia and Red China gave "concrete evidence" that they were interested in a specific, and not a propaganda, program for peace.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Nov. 12--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Andrew Moffett 2d of the engagement of their daughter, Helen Wilmot, to James Russell Lowell Jr. of Oyster Bay and New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell of 812 Park Avenue, New York.

Christians should do everything "humanly possible to avert war," the Rev. Dr. Albert T. Mollegen, Professor of Christian Ethics at Virginia Theological Seminary, Alexandria, Va., declared yesterday at the morning service at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 12--Dr. Leland Bradley Snoddy, well-known physicist, member of the faculty of the School of Physics at the University of Virginia for the last seventeen years, died today in University Hospital at the age of 52.

DR. ABRAHAM MYERSON, one of the most distinguished of American neurologists and psychiatrists, was at work on a book for the general public when he died in 1948. In fact, he had been working on it ever since 1930, when Alfred Knopf approached him for such a book.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--Following is the text of a statement issued by President Truman in releasing a "Report to the President on Foreign Economic Policies" by Gordon Gray, special assistant to the President:

CHICAGO, Nov. 12--Never-- well hardly ever--does a George Halas-coached eleven lose two straight to the same team. Thus, the news from Wrigley Field that the Chicago Bears, beaten by 38--27 at New York two weeks ago, fashioned a 28-20 equalizer against the Yanks today, should not come as a surprise.

A new English translation of Mozart's "The Magic Flute" will have its first hearing in the Metropolitan Opera's third week, which begins Nov. 20, it was announced yesterday. This composer's "Don Giovanni" will be heard twice during the week.
LONDON, Nov. 12--By 1954 the trained military manpower in the Soviet Union will be stabilized at about 12,000,000 or 13,000,000, Brassey's 1950 Annual, a British Armed Forces year-book, ...

When the Cunard liner Britannic arrived here yesterday from Liverpool stewards reported only one serious case of seasickness aboard. The victim, a native of Scotland and a veteran ocean traveler, was unable to explain as sudden illness.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12-- A major bargaining goal in the negotiation of a new labor management contract by the Screen Actors Guild and the film producing companies will be "protection for Guild members against 'hit-andrun' competition for acting jobs," Ronald Reagan, newly re-elected Guild president, announced at the organization's annual membership meeting tonight.

Saturday night's performance of "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House was to have featured the debut of Paolo Silveri, the Italian baritone. However, the fall weather affected Mr. Silveri's vocal cords and, in his stead, Frank Guerrera sang the role of the elder Germont.

PARIS, Nov. 12--The scarcity of raw materials has become one of the foremost problems of France While seeking as international ac cord for a more equal distribution of rare products, the Government at the same time is trying to develop economic resources in French territories overseas.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 12 --Three hundred and thirty examples of oil paintings, water colors, drawings, sculpture and craftwork were judged this afternoon in preparation for the opening tomorrow night of the twentieth annual exhibition of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild at the Westchester County Center.

It has remained for China, never an aggressive Power until it fell under Communist leadership, to demonstrate that the policy of containment of the Soviet empire has run into the hard fact that the Soviet empire cannot contain itself.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 12 (AP)-- Albert G. Feeney, Mayor of Indianapolis and center of the unknown Notre Dame football team that upset Army in 1913, died of a heart attack today, his fiftyeighth birthday.

Child labor in certain age brackets has tripled in the last ten years and the expanding job market expected as part of the defense economy will bring even more youngsters into the nation's work force, according to the annual report of the National Child Labor Committee.

My Dear Mr. President: On March 31, 1950, you asked me to undertake an assignment as your special assistant to make recommendations to you in charting our course in the field of foreign economic policies and programs.
Cagey Steve Owen dug into his capacious bag of tricks yesterday and came out with his old A-formation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12--A radically new craft is tied up at the big elevator owned by Cargill, Inc., on the Calumet River here. It consists of a tow boat and barge which fit together to form a single craft. Looking at it from the side it appears to be a single craft. Actually, the two sections may be uncoupled to be used as separate craft.
No progress toward the settlement of the four-day-old strike of the Communications Workers of America, C.I.O., against the Western Electric Company was made yesterday.

Changes in the rate of inventory accumulation and liquidation are a far more important cause of business cycles than has been suspected, a study released for publication today by the National Bureau of Economic Research indicates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12-- United States aid to Western Europe should go on for three or four more years while the free world's defenses are made stronger there, President Truman was advised today in a special report.

Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris, one of the two experts representing France in the international chess masters tournament at the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, took the lead last night by winning his second-round game from Herman Pilnik of Argentina in thirty-five moves, according to a report from Amsterdam.
Seamen of a halved tanker who years ago navigated her stern-half safely into port have brought suit for a salvage award.

A 4-year-old Czechoslovak boy will arrive here today on an International Rescue Committee transport thanks to the action of the Netherlands Government in declaring him a "political undesirable" in order to reunite him with his family prior to immigration to the United States.

A trust fund totaling $205,000, the largest bequest ever made to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, is to be placed in the records this year in the fund's thirty-ninth annual appeal, which will get under way next month.
LONDON, Nov. 13--An extra allowance of a few rationed foods will be granted during Christmas week, it was announced in the House of Commons today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 13 --The Eastern States Antiques Fair opened its thirty-first edition today at the Westchester County Center, giving every indication after an hour or two of business of a prosperous run through Saturday.
Three hundred men and women of foreign birth became citizens of the United States yesterday morning when Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan administered the oath of naturalization.

LONDON, Nov. 13--The London stock markets were generally quiet today, but a firm undertone was discernible. The sharpest advances in domestic shares were in textiles, while in the foreign market Japanese bonds were in demand.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 13--The United States assumed today the leadership of a group of countries searching in the United Nations for a "practical compromise solution" to the problem of Eritrea, former Italian colony with 1,000,000 inhabitants between Ethiopia and the Red Sea.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company countered union hit-and-run tactics yesterday by refusing to allow nonstriking long distance operators to work unless they gave assurance that they would remain on the job "regularly" and ignore future picket lines.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 13--The agenda of the Security Council, heavily laden with complaints and counter-charges filed by Middle Eastern countries against one another, received one more item today submitted by the United States, Britain and France, urging these lands to settle their disputes at home.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 13 --William L. Schultz, president of Shulton, Inc., manufacturers of toiletries, died today at East Orange General Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 74.

The forthcoming White House Conference on Children and Youth will be asked to put its weight behind a campaign for enactment of laws in every state barring employment of children under 16 years old, in school hours.

Among the latest to join the ranks of the increasingly popular "of-the-month clubs" that provide members every thirty or thirty-one days with a book, a box of candy or a ticket to a Broadway show is the Cheese Guild, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a Federal tax might be valid, even though it was regulatory in effect and bore "close resemblance to a penalty."

Two personal appointees of former Mayor William O'Dwyer resigned their posts in the city administration yesterday as Acting Mayor Impellitteri prepared to be sworn in today as Mayor, in his own right, for the three-year remainder of the O'Dwyer term.

KALIMPONG, India, Nov. 13--The Tibetan National Assembly was reported today to have decided to send a peace delegation of officials, monks and abbots to meet Communist forces march ing on Lhasa and negotiate a truce. This account was given by the first eyewitness of the fighting to arrive here from Tibet.
Whether the occasion is a formal ball or a date at the soda fountain, Gimbels can suggest a gown for it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered a cut of about 3.5 per cent, effective Jan. 1, in rail and water freight rates between a score of Midwestern cities and the remainder of the Western states.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--The highest Congressional authorities in both parties were confident today that President Truman now had given up any thought of summoning the Eighty-first Congress before its scheduled reassembly Nov. 27.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13--The United Council of Church Women, representing an estimated 10,000,000 churchgoers in seventy Protestant denominations, opened its four-day biennial national assembly here tonight.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 13 (AP)-- Gray-haired, taciturn Bernie Bier man today asked to be relieved of his football coaching duties at the University of Minnesota, thus ending an eighteen-year career that included the brightest era of Gopher gridiron history. He will stay until the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)-- The Supreme Court denied the Government today a hearing on its claim that the former Maritime Commission was the outright owner of $8,000,000 worth of common stock of Dollar of Delaware.

Under the smart guidance of Willie Boland, Renew of the King Ranch scored a decisive triumph in the Adventurers Handicap at the Jamaica race track yesterday. In competition with only four others in the mile and a sixteenth test for fillies and mares, Renew won from William Noble's Abbie Co.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13--The so-called self-service gas station is not only here to stay but is setting an evolutionary pattern in gasoline retailing, the Americanistic Petroleum Institute was told today.

THE Giants and the Cardinals headed for the clubhouse between halves of Sunday's game at the Polo Grounds. Vince Banonis, the center of the Cards, glanced up as his path crossed that of Stout Steve Owen, who was wearing the same contented expression of the cat that had just swallowed the canary. Banonis scowled.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts sold yesterday bond issues totaling $75,145,000 due from 1951 to 1980 at an interest cost of 1.26246 per cent.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society has paid $730,000 in Federal amusement taxes since 1941, $112,000 of it last year. The orchestra can expect to meet its deficits with certainty only for the next two seasons.

Dr. Samuel J. Kopetzky, director of the Department of Otolaryngology at Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital, died unexpectedly yesterday in his home at 300 East Fifty-seventh Street. He was 74 years old.

Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., in the forty weeks ended Oct. 8, increased earnings 199 per cent and sales 77 per cent over the corresponding period of last year, Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, president, reported yesterday.

VIENNA, Nov. 13--The Austrian Government sent a third note to the Allied Council today asking that body whether the Government's measures to control the recent Communist disorders were in conflict with the Council's statutes, as Russians contend, or were in accord with them as the Western occupation powers hold.

Television Authority, which represents performers in video, will give its answer today to a minimum wage offer proposed by the networks last Friday.

Darius Milhaud, one of the most famous and prolific of living composers, has waited thirty-five years for the first American performance of his "Les Choephores."

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Nov. 13-- John Sedlmayr and Fred Gronauer of the Sands Point Club scored 32, 34--66, five strokes under course figures, to win the one-day amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island Professional Golf Association at the Glen Head Club today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 15--Nassau County's long search for a man to head its new Department of Franchises as Director of Transportation ended here today with the appointment of Ervin N. Hatch of 300 Old Courthouse Road, New Hyde Park.
Yale University yesterday gave Herman Hickman what undoubtedly amounts to the strongest vote of confidence ever received by a man serving in the normally precarious role of a college football coach.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15--A new type of beam from the high-voltage betatron may prove more useful in treating cancer than the X-ray beam, Dr. Roger A. Harvey, Professor of Radiology at the University of Illinois college of medicine at Chicago, reported today.

Several comments have been received from readers disagreeing with the advice recently given on this page to Mrs. M.G.S., who was having a "frightful time" making breads and cakes with whole wheat flour.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 15--The Puerto Rican Government's finances are in their best shape since the end of World War II, according to Sol Luis Descartes, Treasurer. Revenue collections for the general fund amounting to $90,700,000 for the fiscal year ended June 30 were second only to that of $104,000,000 in the fiscal year 1943-1944.
READING, Pa., Nov. 15--The Rev. Hugh A. Dalton, a priest for thirty-five years, died yesterday in St. Isaac Jogues Novitiate, Wernersville. Pa., at the age of 71.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15--Dr. William McClellan, former trustee of the University of Pennsylvania, where he served as dean of the Wharton School from 1916 to 1919, died yesterday in Alexandria (Va.) Hospital. His age was 78.

Dr. Vannevar Bush, atomic scientist, in an address last night before the Economic Club of New York, outlined his ideas on how we should be prepared to fight World War III, when and if it comes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--In a reversal of policy, the Truman Administration decided today to go ahead with dollar loans to Spain from the $62,500,000 fund authorized by Congress for the purpose.

TODAY through Sunday young stamp collectors will find a wealth of interesting material on exhibit at the National Postage Stamp Show, Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirtyfourth Street. Admission 30 cents.

Frank Erickson twice escaped being cited for contempt of court yesterday. He first refused and then agreed to tell a grand jury whether there had been "pay-offs", by Frank Costello and... another gambler in return for oil leases Erickson shared with them.
For those who seek a solution for the city's varied traffic problems, midtown Fifth Avenue offers a fascinating field of study.

Two amputee victims of bombing in the siege of Jerusalem, who met at a hospital in Jaffa and were married in Israel, yesterday sat in the home of a Brooklyn rabbi offering prayers that they would find rehabilitation in the United States.
LONDON, Nov. 15--Exports from the United Kingdom reached a post-war record in October.

Manufacturers of durable goods and purchasing agents for big users of such equipment are preparing to ask for a national Production Authority priority to provide raw materials and parts for making boilers, engines, machinery...
TORONTO, Nov. 15 (Canadian Press)--Jalisco, ridden by Lieut. Joaquin D' Harcourt of Mexico, tonight won the international handy course jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--Secretary of State Dean Acheson warned today that the United States must employ all its wisdom, and employ, it with the utmost soberness and resolution, if it was to prevent the entry of Chinese Communist troops in Korea from causing a world-wide tragedy "of the most colossal nature."

TOKYO, Nov. 15--A steady stream of Russian-made tanks has reached the North Korean armies opposing the United Nations forces ever since the beginning of the Korean war, a spokesman for the Intelligence Section of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters asserted today.
United Nations forces continued to advance north yesterday against spotty enemy resistance. Some limited objectives were taken, while extensive patroling was conducted along the entire front.
NEWARK, Nov. 15 (UP)--The price of one brand of gasoline went up in Newark tonight and dealer groups announced a State-wide price war would end tomorrow.

HOUSTON, Tex, Nov. 15--Dr. Wilbur W. White, former president of the University of Toledo, died here last night at the age of 47. He was the brother of Mrs. William V. Houston, wife of the president of Rice Institute here.
Breakfast takes on a savor of the season. Mincemeat fills a coffee cake; turkey is the basis for a hash. Ideas, of course, for Sunday, when there is time to relish such temptations.

WARSAW, Nov. 15--Last-minute preparations were being made today for the second Communistbacked World Peace Congress, which may or may not convene here tomorrow as scheduled.

Sound business procedures worked out by the Quartermaster have eliminated any semblance of red tape in transactions between contractors and the Government, according to Col. Louis H. Shirley, chief, clothing and textile branch, New York Quartermaster Procurement Agency.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 15--A surge got pressure by influential German industrial sources has been directed toward the reconstruction of German and possible European cartels as the tra ditional and most economical method of integration.

Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, proposed yesterday that an AngloAmerican commission be set up to study the present state of higher education, and "formulate objectives" for its improvement.
LONDON, Nov. 15--The British Foreign Office is convinced that a political formula must be found to allay Communist China's fear of aggression if a spread of the conflict in Korea is to be avoided.

Mayor Impellitteri fulfilled yesterday his promise to appoint a committee to study the advisability of incorporating in the municipal transit system the abandoned Rockaway Beach branch of the Long Island Rail Road.

Mrs. Florence Brooks Adler, who was active in mental hygiene and war welfare work in the second world conflict died on Tuesday in her home, 300 Central Park West, after a brief illness at the age of 50. She was the widow of Arthur H. Adler, president of the Adler Shoe Company, chain-store firm.

A safari of 22,300 children found adventure yesterday on a trek to the opening of THE NEW YORK TIMES' fourth annual Boys and Girls Book Fair in the American Museum of Natural History, where the exhibit will continue through Sunday.

ALBANY, Nov. 15--The application of New York City for permission to construct a $140,000,000 dam and reservoir at Cannonsville, N.Y., to augment its water supplies was approved here today by the State Water Power and Control Commission. It also must be approved by the United States Supreme Court.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15-- William Wyler, Paramount producer-director, will test Charlton Heston next week for the leading role for the projected screen version of Sidney Kingsley's play, "Detective Story," it was learned today.

The State of North Carolina yesterday sold issues of school and port bonds totaling $32,500,000 to a banking syndicate headed by First National Bank of New York at an interest cost of 1.4127 per cent. The next best bid, submitted by First Boston Corporation and Lehman Brothers, designated an interest cost of 1.4285 per cent.

ALBANY, Nov. 15--Reorganization of New York's Air National Guard as an integral part of the state's military forces, conforming with the pattern of the United States Air Force, has been completed, Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, Chief of Staff to Governer Dewey, reported today.

HONG KONG, Nov. 15--The evacuation of Russian dependents from Manchuria, the removal and dispersal of machinery from Manchurian plants, the reported reduction of Communist purchasing here and the continued concentration of both Chinese Communist and Russian forces in Manchuria are some of the more ominous signs of war in the Orient.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15--A week ago Charlie Caldwell candidly stated that he did not see how Princeton could lose to Harvard unless the men became fat-headed enough to think they had only to walk on the field to win.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose to new high levels for the season yesterday, closing strong, up 19 to 57 points, with strength most pronounced in old crop months.
In a reorganization of Rayonier, Inc., one of the nation's largest woodpulp producers, Charles R. Blyth, president of the investment banking company bearing his name, yesterday was elected chairman.
THE most famous thing about William Faulkner, a great American storyteller who last week won last year's Nobel Prize in literature, is his obscurity.

It is more important for this nation to assert its spiritual values among the countries of the western world than to give military and economic aid, Prof. Hans Kohn of City College asserted yesterday at the annual Honors Day convo cation of Brooklyn College. He spoke before 1,500 faculty members and students in Roosevelt Hall.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (UP)--A former policy gambling leader was wounded today as authorities began a search for a new suspect in the September killing of Detective William Drury.
NEAR YONGBYON, Korea, Nov. 15--The war-weary First Cavalry Division has suffered three nights of bitter cold. The effect on men and material has been very serious.

The Farrell Medal, recently instituted by the Farrell Lines board of directors to recognize exceptional heroism and meritorious service "beyond the call of duty" by the men who man company ships, was awarded yesterday for the first time to two officers of the line.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 15-- As a result of concerted opposition on the part of members in New York, Chicago and other large cities, the directors of the National Association of Real Estate Boards announced tonight that they had withdrawn a proposal for assessment of all members to finance a national drive to spread home ownership.

The status and treatment of South Africans of Indian descent is now before the United Nations in a resolution condemning the Union's racial policies. It is well for this unsavory issue to yet a thorough airing.

Wayne Belden has been named executive vice president of Ajax Flexible Coupling Company, Inc., Westfield, N.Y. Charles Belden has been made vice president and Robert G. Cady has been appointed sales manager.

The three-story store and apartment building at 537 Alabama Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Fannie Mittelman to Esther Taylor. Murray Rubien was attorney for the buyer and George Abrams acted for the seller. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

HONG KONG, Nov. 15--After achieving relative price stability by heavy taxation and government controls, the Chinese Communists are now grappling with a price disparity problem that has reduced the purchasing power of the peasant and created pressures for higher wages in the cities.

Sales and earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were the largest for any similar peacetime period, according to the statement released today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--More than seventy-five legislative measures, all classified officially as "important" and on which affirmative action has been taken at one or more stages of Congressional procedure, await the return later this month of the Eighty-first Congress for it final and so-called "lame-duck" session.

Columbia kept working on its offense in a short but rugged heavy contact scrimmage at Baker Field, yesterday, as Quarterbacks Mitch Price and Kermit Tracy sharpened their passing in preparation for the Lions Saturday home encounter with Navy.

Development of rich iron ore deposits in the Labrador-Quebec region will be begun immediately by the iron Ore Company of Canada, George M. Humphrey, president, announced yesterday after reporting Completion of a $200,000,000 financing program for the project.

A scheduler plan to evict 120 veterans and their families from converted barracks at the Mitchel Air Force Base was abandoned yesterday by the Air Force, in the face of protests from the Public Housing Administration and the New York State Division of Housing.

Television and radio receiver production soon will cut back much more drastically than all previous estimates provided because of intensified shortages of parts and components in the last week.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP)-- Cross Bell Ranch's American Glory won the featured $3,500 Sir Francis purse in easy fashion at Pimlico today. Apprentice Augustino Catalano completed a triple with the $6.80-for-$2 favorite.

The action of the Federal court in Chicago temporarily restraining the introduction of color television on a commercial basis next Monday was hailed last night by set manufacturers as an important victory.

Miles Laboratories, Inc., of Elkhart, Ind., manufacturer of drugs and medicines, has leased the nineteenth floor and penthouse in 6 East Forty-fifth Street for its Eastern executive and sales offices. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers, negotiated the lease.

The Los Angeles Rams have averaged close to forty points and have advanced the ball more than 430 yards a game, the official National Football League statistics show. These impressive scoring and ground-gaining totals ordinarily should tend to make a rival highly defense-conscious.

An increase last week of 1,115,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 105,465,000 barrels, compared with 104,350,000 a week earlier and 103,577,000 a year ago.

Britain's new Christmas toys and young members of the Police Athletic League met yesterday in the first class lounge of the Cunard liner Britannic, and there was no need of introductions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (UP)--The Professional Golfers Association today gave a vote of confidence to its officers, re-electing all major officials as the final business move of the thirty-fourth annual meeting.

An investor has purchased from William Rohe the five-story apartment house on lot 20 by 100 feet at 33 East Sixty-third Street in a deal reported by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. Schenley Distributors, Inc., have scheduled a heavy holiday campaign for its Reserve brand of whisky. Starting on Monday, reproductions of a multiple-page magazine ad will appear in 330 newspapers.

BERLIN, Nov. 15--Otto Grotewohl, East German President, proclaimed today the transition of the Soviet zone and sector of Berlin to a "worker's state."

Inclusion of driver-training courses in the curriculum of every public high school in this city by Feb. 1 was forecast yesterday, with an estimate that 110,000 pupils, would be enrolled for classroom lessons in behind-the-wheel techniques.

PNOM PENH, Indo-China, Nov. 17--The spill-over of Communistled Vietminh revolutionary activity from South Vietnam into Cambodia provides the French and Cambodian Government authorities with their main security problem these days.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 17 (AP) --The Illinois junior varsity football team closed its season with a 21-13 victory over the previously undefeated Ohio State Jayvees.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 17 --Westchester County officials received notification today that the State Thruway Authority would hear complaints at 2 P.M. Nov 28 concerning tentative plans for construction ...
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 17--The Iona College basketball team beat the Alumni, 66--55, tonight. John J. Kelly paced the scoring for the varsity with 17 points. Iona led at the half, 28--19.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17--Two former football powers striving to regain big-time recognition clash tomorrow when Temple plays host to Fordham in the Owls' final home game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)-- Complaints of Reservists called to active duty that physical examinations were "a joke" and that they had not received time to get their family affairs in order were reported today by the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
The Synagogue Council of America, representing Orthodox, Conservative and Reform Judaism, has called on all constituents to set aside today as Agricultural Sabbath. Rabbis have been urged
CAIRO, Nov. 17 (UP)--Rouad Sirageldin Pasha, Interior Minister, banned all political demonstrations today following yesterday's riots at the opening of Egypt's Parliament.
The Board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange settled the Christmas holiday closing problem early this year. At its meeting
Lumber production for the week ended Nov. 11 was 11.9 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 17 (UP)--United States District Judge J. Waties Waring, who three years ago outlawed all-white elections in South Carolina, opened the way today for an attack on the state's segregated school system.

WONSAN, Korea, Saturday, Oct. 18 (AP)--A new United Nations military cemetery was dedicated here today. It is on a hill about 500 yards from the beaches where the United States First Marine Division landed unopposed Oct. 26. Chaplains John V. Peters of Philadelphia and George W. Cummins of Louisville, Ky., dedicated the cemetery.

The municipal bond business of Lebenthal Co. is celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding. The firm was formed as a clearing place for odd-lot municipal obligations. The business has since expanded its activities to cover round lots, but it is still a primary market for blocks of $10,000 of bonds or less.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 17-- Mrs. F.M. Hoffman of Plainfield was elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association to succeed Mrs. T.W. Hawes of Baltusrol at the annual meeting held this morning at the Montclair Golf Club.

NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y., Nov. 17 (AP)--The United States Gypsum Company announced today it has shut down its asphalt roofing plant here indefinitely because of a shortage of dry felt. The plant had about fifty workers when it was closed.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 17 (AP)--Airmen flying low over South Carolina's sea island beaches today found the body of Mrs. Frederick H. Ecker, wife of the chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Satisfied that the New York Yanks are "as ready as they ever will be" for their battle with the Los Angeles Rams at Yankee Stadium tomorrow. Coach Red Strader has canceled the final practice session scheduled for today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Spokesmen for organized labor called on Congress today for a stiffer excess-profits tax than the $4,000,000,000 levy advocated by the Truman Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon laid claim today to the powerful support of the Republican foreign policy leader, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, in his determination to obtain a seat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the new Congress.

RACINE, Wis., Nov. 17--The S.C. Johnson Son Company today opened its new fifteen-floor research and development tower, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, the noted architect, as the last in a group of unusual business buildings.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 17 (AP) --Unconfirmed reports from Nepal said tonight that Nepalese rebels had beaten off a Government attempt to retake the insurgent-held town of Biganj, southern gateway to Nepal's capital of Katmandu. The reports said the insurgents had turned the Government drive into a retreat.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 17-- Cardinal Spellman will dedicate an edifice for the new Bishop Dunn Memorial High School at Mount St. Mary-on-the-Hudson here at 4 P.M. Sunday.
Retail trade for the fall season reached a turning point this week, with weather conditions apparently stimulating consumer buying, merchants here said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Dr. Simon Greenberg, executive director of the United Synagogue of America, warned tonight that national peacetime militarization threatened "justice and mercy" and "truth and brotherhood."

The City College football team, with a record of seven defeats, will play its last game today, Lowell Textile providing the opposition at Lewisohn Stadium. Coach Irving Mondshein says the Beavers have a good chance of closing with a victory.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 17-- "Mom-cops," as school children have named the seventeen Red Bank mothers who have volunteered for traffic duty at hazardous intersections near the Oakland Street elementary school, took over their posts for the first time today.
The New York City Theatre Company, the civic sponsored theatrical group operating at the City Center, has selected its second play of the winter season.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 17 (UP)--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru started Parliament today by announcing that he planned to reduce the size of the army and slash defense appropriations.
