Mayor Impellitteri left La Guardia Airport yesterday morning for a vacation of ten days or two weeks in Florida and Cuba, leaving Frank J. Sampson, former leader of Tammany, as his political representative. He arrived in Havana yesterday afternoon.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 17-- The dredge Magic City is putting the finishing touches this week on the job of widening the entrance to Huntington Harbor to make it safe for pleasure boats and commercial craft.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Nov. 17 (AP)--Erwin G. (Murph) Chamberlain, former National Hockey League star, today was appointed coach of the Vancouver Canucks in the Pacific Coast Hockey League.
Koppers Company, Inc., has been awarded a contract to build a complete coke oven plant and steelmaking facilities for Republic Steel Corporation in Cleveland,
Applications to speak at a public hearing on rent control here Wednesday continued to pour into the offices of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission up to the deadline for filing last night.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 17 (AP)--District Court opened for business today but there was no business. Not a single defendant was on the docket for arraignment. And in keeping with an old English custom, Sgt. Harry McLaughlin, arraigning officer, presented to Judge Luigi DePasquale a pair of spotless white gloves, symbolic of "purity in the community."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 17--With "better learning today for better living tomorrow" as their theme, more than 2,200 student leaders from over the state gathered at Rutgers University here today for the twenty-fifth annual conference of the New Jersey Association of Student Councils.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 17--A Korean Communist underground made up chiefly of North Korean troops unable to reach their own lines, and of Communist civilian shock troops, has completed the organization of at least 40,000 guerrallas south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel, Chough Pyung Ok, Minister of Home Affairs, told a press conference here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared tonight that persons who say they want to "re-examine" United States programs abroad would tear up the roots of policies of this Government dating back to the founding of the Republic.

LONDON, Nov. 17--Representatives of the twelve North Atlantic Treaty powers got down to work today on the actual details of how to incorporate German manpower in the collective military forces of their alliance.

The first volume in a series of books aimed to increase knowledge of American classics in Europe and an appreciation here of European artists and craftsmen has arrived from France. It is a volume of poems by Edgar Allan Poe that has been illustrated by Jean Gabriel Daragnes.

The nation must prepare to maintain a high level of military preparedness and, at the same time, continue economical and political programs for peace for "several generations," Assistant Secretary of the Army Karl R. Bendetsen warned last night.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 17--The marriage of Miss Mary Eleanor Straatsma, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clarence Ralph Straatsma, to Dr. Forbes Delany, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brunn Delany of Scarsdale, took place here this evening in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dan C. Thomas performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Wykagyl Country Club.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 17 (AP) --Army's cleated football legions, bringing their might across coun try for the second time in twentyone years, will spring into action against Stanford tomorrow. The cadets are 20-point favorites to maintain their unblemished record. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P.M. Pacific Coast or 5 P.M. Eastern standard time.

The claims of 4,000 long distance operators, who had applied for immediate unemployment insurance benefits on the grounds that they had been locked out of their jobs, were rejected yesterday, but the operators said they would appeal the decision.

AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 17-- Donald Gaboury shot a small doe last week. He stuffed the skin with hay and propped it in a field near his home.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 17 (AP)--Head football Coach Clyde B. Smith of Indiana University, whose teams have won five of twenty-five games in the last three seasons, was given a new three-year contract today.

Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States will induct Bishop Horace W.B. Donegan as twelfth Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York at 3 P.M. today at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The New York Knickerbockers, having won three in a row, will seek to add to their string tonight at Madison Square Garden at the expense of the Philadelphia Warriors, who currently are in a firstplace percentage tie with the Boston Celtics in the Eastern Division of the Basketball Association of America.

A priority status should be given at once for aluminum to be used in electronic and industrial processing instruments available for the defense effort, Henry F. Dever, president of the Brown Instruments division of MinneapolisHoneywell Regulator Company, declared yesterday.

Import cargo congestion in the Port of New York is beginning to "ease" but will continue a problem until after the Christmas-shipment season has ended, a canvass of port facilities showed yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 17-- Missing twenty-seven years, Robert Sheridan, 54 years old, a veteran of both world wars, returned to Elizabeth today to face an indictment charging him with desertion of wife, Mrs. Helen Sheridan, and two children in 1923.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Nov. 17 (AP)--John A. (Buddy) Hassett said today he has resigned as manager of the Colorado Springs Skysox of the Western Baseball League. The Skysox entered the circuit last year and Hassett, former major leaguer with the Yankees, Braves and Dodgers, was the first manager.

The City of San Antonio, Tex., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 12 on issues of electric and gas revenue bonds amounting to $26,300,000.

GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 17--For many dreary months during World War II a large china jar stood on a counter in the U.S.O. clubhouse of this tidy little up-state city. The country sheriff made daily pilgrimages to farm homes hereabouts to replenish the jar with the best cookies the farmers' wives knew how to bake for the hungry sailors from the nearby Sampson training station.
Sixteen aliens seized under the new Internal Security Act and detained at Ellis Island were ordered released in bail yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan.

ATLANTA, Nov. 17 (UP)--The Southern coaxial cable that carries long distance calls and television programs into Birmingham was knocked out accidentally today.

The St. John's University varsity quintet overwhelmed the alumni, 90--65, in the season's inaugural last night at DeGray gymnasium. The winners were out in front at the intermission, 39--25. Joe McMahon excelled for the regulars with eighteen points.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Graham D. Mattison of 1 East End Avenue on Nov. 10 in Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Mattison is the former Miss Margaret Ridder, daughter of Victor F. Ridder. The child will be named Margaret Everitt.

Carmel Alcaro, 18-year-old pianist, made her recital debut last night in Times Hall. INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 17 (AP)-- The American Legion will hold its 1951 national convention in Miami; Fla., Oct. 15-18. The organization's national executive committee voted unanimously today to return the convention to greater Miami for the second time in three years.
BERLIN, Nov. 17 (UP)--Wilhelm Pieck, East German President, left Berlin today for a four-week rest care in the Soviet Union, the Eastern German Government announced today.

The United States Court of Appeals reversed yesterday the conviction of Antonio Corrao, 66 years old, and the company bearing his name of 253 Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, of the charge of violation of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.

The National Council of Millinery Associations will act against retailers who persist in fraudulent promotions of sample hats, according to Sam Finkelstein, executive administrator. Investigation, he said, reveals that most "sample hat" sales are a fraud on the consumer.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17--Plans are ready and some of them already in operation to deal with all Communists who would be loyal to the Soviet Union instead of Canada in the event of war, Stuart Garson, Justice Minister, said today.

Thirty members of the New York University Pershing Rifles, campus chapter of the national honorary military society, will take part in a two-day bivouac beginning today on the West Point military reservation. The unit will be under the command of Cadet-Captain Milton Rose of 1480 Popham Avenue.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 17 (AP)--The Chattanooga Moccasins snapped an eight-game losing streak as they won their first game of the season tonight by beating Duquesne, 32--20, before 8,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Average, primary market prices advanced 0.6 per cent in the week ended Nov. 14, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 (AP)-- Argentine newspapers have reduced their circulations by 20 per cent because of the continuing shortage of newsprint. The Government gave the newspapers the choice of reducing press runs or cutting the number of pages.

MADRID, Nov. 17--The Spanish Government voted tonight to express its thanks to the United States for the financial aid expected as a result of President Truman's order to put into effect the credit voted by Congress in August. It was not said what form the expression of thanks would take.

The slump in construction grades of Douglas fir, which plagued the lumber industry through most of October, definitely has halted, lumber industry leaders reported yesterday. They said mill prices are $1 to $3 above the lows prevalent a week ago.

This morning's new film is "Rio Grande," a historical Western, starring John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara, at the Mayfair. John Ford directed and co-produced the Republic release with Merian C. Cooper.

The stock market dropped into a pocket yesterday. While the number of issues to advance exceeded those with losses, the composite rate (measured by the key stocks) slipped 0.46 point.
The final returns are not yet in, but it is generally believed that expenditures in the 1950 Congressional election set a new record for a non-Presidential year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Controls and restrictions will be placed on the economy only as the growing needs of the defense program make them necessary, W. Stuart Symington, head of the National Security Resources Board, told a news conference today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--For a second time Democrats of the House Ways and Means Committee bluntly voted down today Republican attempts to obtain consideration of a revised version of the Administration's $4,000,000,000 excess profits tax program.

TOKYO, Nov. 20--The difficulties of creating throughout Korea the conditions necessary for holding free and democratic elections were stressed today at the first meeting of the United Nations Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea.

J.C. Berkwit Co., which buys ships of all descriptions in all conditions, "as is, where is," and most of the time without seeing them first, has dipped into a relatively inconspicuous Louisiana bay for its most recent purchase.

Although still fairly tight, the money market yesterday showed signs of easing. Member banks reported excess reserves of $75,000,000 on Wednesday, and this position was largely maintained on Thursday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 20-- Charles Bruce Vibbert, Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at the University of Michigan and former director of the American University Union, died Saturday afternoon here of a heart attack.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--President Truman today requested an extension of rent control by a joint Congressional resolution until next March 31, pending a re-examination of the whole issue.

The revised fund-raising machinery proposed by leaders of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds is not intended to replace the United Jewish Appeal so long as the latter continues to function, it was made clear yesterday.
"Never a Dull Moment," an R.K.O. romantic comedy with Irene Dunne and Fred MacMurray, which arrives at the Rivoli, is this morning's lone film newcomer.

Troops of the United States Seventh Division reached the Manchurian border on the upper Yalu River at Hyesanjin. To the south, other United Nations forces met stiffening resistance in their advance. [1:8, map P. 2.]
The 1949-50 annual financial report received yesterday by the Board of Higher Education from its accounting officer, J. Harvey Cain, is interesting on many accounts.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 20 (AP)--A re-enactment of its first run to Wauwatosa exactly a century ago and the voting of a $2 special dividend was the Milwaukee Road's way of celebrating its one hundredth birthday today.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 20-- Nepalese Government forces today entered Birganj, Nepal's second largest city, which fell to Congress party rebels nine days ago.
Rubber prices declined the limit permitted in the futures market on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday, reflecting sharply lower prices in London and in the primary market at Singapore.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20-- The "standard of luxuries" of the United States Army must be cut down and more men must be put into infantry units "if we are going up against the aggressor now loose in the world," Gen. Mark W. Clark asserted today.

LONDON, Nov. 20--British Government securities and most of the leading equities improved in the London stock markets today. Hesitancy showed itself, however, in some of the more speculative stocks, such as the gold-mining shares.

A major problem that has baffled European manufacturers seeking to enter this market--American merchandising techniques--is gaining greater understanding abroad, according to European bankers.

The market for United States Government securities seemingly entered a new phase yesterday as the accepted price for the 2 per cent Victory issue due in 1972 moved upward from the last Federal Reserve System support price for the first time since late September.

Deportation hearings against two of the sixteen aliens ordered released from Ellis Island on bond last week were opened yesterday with the introduction of new charges by the Government, based on provisions of the new Internal Security Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--The United States during the third quarter of this year came within reaching distance of the $300,000,000,000 annual output goal fixed by President Truman in January as a possibility for 1955.

THE New York Football Giants perpetrated a mousetrap play on their coach yesterday. The Mara family lured the unsuspecting Steve Owen to the weekly press luncheon at the Polo Grounds and suddenly presented a silver tea service to him in token of Stout Steve's silver anniversary as a member if the Giants. The tray was suitably engraved, of course. It paid the usual tributes but the most significant word on it was that of "friend."

Hoffman, former Governor of New Jersey, charged here today before a Congressional investigating committee that "certain pressures" were exerted on the Coast Guard to relax its safety regulation shortly before the fatal May 19 explosion that took thirtyone lives and injured more than 200 persons.

William W. Kleinman, attorney for Abraham Brothman, chemical engineer, and the latter's business partner, Miriam Moskowitz, in their Federal Court trial on a charge of obstructing justice rested his case yesterday without calling either defendant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21-- Aroused by the extent of the effort to place officials connected with the defense program in the three highest-salaried grades under the Defense Production Act of 1950, President Truman today limited the allowable total of such positions to 150. He prescribed further that only twenty of the 150 get the top salary of $14,000.

A resolution requesting the city to acquire the Rhinelander Houses in Washington Square by condemnation or private purchase as historic monuments was introduced into the City Council yesterday by Councilman Robert Weisberger, Manhattan Democrat.

The Granite City Steel Company of Granite City, Ill., has under consideration a $50,000,000 expansion program that would double its productive capacity, John N. Marshall, president and chairman, announced yesterday.

Winds of gale force continued to lash at the city yesterday after the severest storm of the season. The weather disturbance, part of one hitting a large section of the Eastern seaboard, sent the mercury here toppling to 31.8 degrees at 1 o'clock this morning, the lowest reading of the season.
The battle between supporters of Mayor Impellitteri and those of Carmine G. DeSapio, Tammany leader, for control of Tammany Hall became more intense yesterday.

The New York State Teachers Association, which has 47,276 members, urged yesterday that Communist teachers be barred from employment in the schools. The action came at the closing session of the 106th annual meeting of the house of delegates at the Commodore Hotel.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters has elected Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India; Arnold J. Toynbee, British historian; Andre Gide, French novelist and essayist, and Ignazio Silone, Italian novelist, honorary corresponding members. The announcement was made yesterday by Paul Manship, president of the academy.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 9--Intelligence reports have revealed that two Russian parties thoroughly surveyed large areas of Western Tibet in April, May and part of June this year and chose sites for air bases to be used as an eventual threat against India and adjacent countries. The reports expose a Soviet plan of grand strategy for Asia in great detail.

The Children's Aid Society dedicated yeaterday the Lord Memorial, its new building at 150 East Forty-fifth Street, which is the headquarters of the organization's foster home department and health and homemaker services.

Today it is 5,000 and Mr. Hough is probably the bestknown country editor in America. But it isn't only the excellence of his weekly newspaper that has made him so.

Sales of table wine for Thanksgiving attained a record volume, but there was a slight decline in September consumption, a citywide survey disclosed yesterday. Wine dealers said the heavy holiday sales indicate the possibility of a new wine-consumption record for 1950.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., in its fiscal year ended with August, attained the largest sales and earnings in its history, according to a report yesterday by Howard R. Walton, the president.

The New York Quartermaster Procurement Agency yesterday ended a two-day meeting with clothing manufacturers to deternine to what extent manufacturers can accelerate production. The discussions covered acceleration with and without increased costs, according to industry members present.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22-- The president of Princeton University issued a formal apology today to West Point for the bombing of the Military Academy with 20,000 leaflets yesterday by four Princeton undergraduates.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22-- The finest football team Charlie Caldwell has coached will play its last game of the season against Dartmouth in Palmer Stadium Saturday and for sixteen of the twenty-two starters of the offensive and defensive units it will be the last time out in the Orange and Black.

In the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection yesterday afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Breslauer, daughter of Mrs. Margaret K. Breslauer of 64 East Eighty-sixth Street and Milton K. Breslauer of 40 Central Park South, was married to Frederick Dalziel Vreeland, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Reed Vreeland of 400 Park Avenue and Brewster, N.Y.

TORONTO, Nov. 22 (Canadian Press)--The United States tonight won the International Team Challenge Trophy in the premier jumping competition that closed the Royal Winter Fair horse show. It was the first United States victory in eight nights of international contests.

Directors of the Kellogg Company yesterday called a special meeting of stockholders for Dec. 5 to vote on the creation of 153,013 shares of 3 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--The Secretary of State, Mr. Acheson, at his press conference today attributed to "misinterpretation" the generally bad reception, of his impromptu remarks last Friday night about "re-examinists."

A proposal to relocate the Flushing, Queens, bus terminal on the site of a city-owned parking facility won virtually unanimous approval yesterday at a public hearing held by the Board of Transportation at 250 Hudson Street.
DALLAS, Nov. 22 (AP)--The University of Tennessee tonight accepted an invitation to play the University of Texas in the Cotton Bowl on Jan. 1.
The "biggest show on earth," the circus, is represented in an even bigger one this year--the annual display of Christmas toys.
Inquiries from European countries for American bituminous coal have firmed up strongly for the first time since 1949, major coal exporters disclosed here yesterday.

A new colonial-style house, with a two-car garage, on Hardscrabble Circle in Windmill Farm, Armonk, N.Y., has been purchased by James R. Spence. The dwelling was designed by H. Lawrence Goggina, architect of the Windmill Farm homes, which are being built by Carlo M. Paterno.

Annie Birnback bought the sixstory apartment house accommodating fifty-five families at 588 Timpson Place, the Bronx, from the 588 Timpson Corporation through J.C. Schulman, broker, and resold it to an investing client of Emanuel Goldberg, attorney, though Max Fluss, broker. The property, on a plot 118 by 100 feet, is assessed at $160,000.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 (AP)--Joe Culmone took the lead over Willie Shoemaker in their battle for 1950 jockey honors by riding three winners today. A crowd of 4,921 saw Culmone boot home His Image at 5 to 2 in the third, True Dream at 17 to 5 in the sixth and Eugarp at 2 to 1 in the eighth and last race. All were favorites.

Demand for immediate-deliveries of copper has become so great that some buyers have offered more than sixteen cents a pound above refiners' prices for immediate deliveries, it was reported here yesterday by trade sources. Even higher prices have been heard, merchants said, mostly applying to imported stocks.

The New York City Ballet came forth with another fine evening at the City Center last night, making it clear that the brilliance of its opening session the night before was no accident but something of a precedent.

The campaign committee for the election of Ferdinand Pecora as Mayor has been left with a deficit of $150,000 to $175,000, it was learned yesterday. Leaders of the Democratic party are trying to figure out a way to raise the money, it was said.

The Second annual Junior League Ball for provisional members was held last night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, which for the occasion was festooned with white balloons.

Tin prices declined sharply on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, although the volume of trading was comparatively light, amounting to thirty-five tons. Final prices were off 650 to 800 points, or 6 to 8 cents a pound, taking the current November delivery to $1.35 a pound, off 700 points, and June, 1951, to $1.26 a pound, also down the same amount.
More price advances in the paper field by or before the early part of next year are in the making, trade sources declared yesterday.

THE arrival of large flights of greater scaup, more familiarly known as broadbill, well ahead of their normal time of arrival, has removed much of the pressure from the Connecticut puddle ducks along the coastal marshes.

As rescue workers toiled to free imprisoned victims of the crash on the Long Island Rail Road last night, survivors and neighborhood residents described the accident and the agonies of the trapped passengers.
That Tommy Henrich, the Old Reliable of the Yankees for so many years, will quit the diamond for the Bombers' broadcasting booth in 1951 is a possibility but by no means a certainty.

New orders for machine tools in October were more than five times as large as in the same month last year, according to the statistical report of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association released for publication today. Compared with September, 1950, the orders were only slightly higher, the national trade organization said.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Nov. 22 --A member of a House subcommittee investigating the May 19 munitions blast here charged today that the Hercules Powder Company had a "secret 'in' with the Coast Guard" that enabled the concern to violate a regulation limiting the shipment of explosives through this port.
Johnny Bratton, hard-hitting Negro middleweight from Chicago, knocked out Johnny Cesario of Boston in the third round of their scheduled ten-round feature at the St. Nicholas arena last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP)--Sales taxes are the largest income source this year for twenty-three states, the Commerce Clearing House reported today. Sixteen states put most dependence on gasoline taxes for revenue. Six get most of their money from income taxes, and one from motor vehicle fees.
Col. John Haskell, chairman of the disaster relief committee of the city's five Red Cross chapters, outlined yesterday plane for action in the event of such a disaster as an atomic attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--Producers of rubber goods, including tires for civilian use, will have the same amount of rubber available early next year as in this month but will be required to use a greater percentage of synthetic than they do now, the National Production Authority announced today.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov, 22 (AP)--Assault, champion 3-year-old in 1946, hit the comeback trail today in winning fashion.

In observance of Thanksgiving Day, the nation's security and commodity markets will be closed today. The livestock market also will be closed and the Department of Agriculture will make no estimate of receipts of hogs, cattle and sheep. The Canadian markets and the London Stock Exchange will remain open as usual.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22-- United Nations delegates today selected a fifteen-nation committee to make still another attempt at completing the treaty on freedom of information that the United States and Britain have opposed as a threat to the liberty of the press.

Winning two games in the eighth and ninth rounds of the international chess tournament, Miguel Najdorf of Argentina yesterday moved well ahead of the field with a score of 7 --1 , according to a report from Amsterdam.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22-- The Senate Crime Investigating Committee today prodded the Internal Revenue Bureau over asserted slowness in prosecuting taxevading criminals.

An increase of 3,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 105,468,000 barrels, compared with 105,465,000 a week earlier and 103,380,000 a year ago.

Louis Richman, president of Richman-Justman-Frankenthal, Inc., 199 Duane Street, produce growers, shippers and distributors, and a leader in Jewish charitable affairs, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 1049 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn. He was 73 years old.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)-- The Treasury tonight offered a new issue of 1 per cent five-year notes in exchange for $8,008,101,500 in securities falling due on Dec. 15 and Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--New unemployment among workers covered by state unemployment insurance laws has been rising seasonally in recent weeks after hitting a 1950 low in September.
SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., Nov. 22 --A memorabilia-filled cornerstone box for which there is no cornerstone was uncovered this week in the 198-year-old South Salem Presbyterian Church on Main Street.

The train crash last night near Richmond Hill, Queens, was the second major disaster on the Long Island Rail Road in the last nine months. It was the fifth large-scale rail wreck in the country this year.

PARIS, Nov. 22--The French Government intends to meet the crisis in Indo-China neither by abandoning that country nor by calling for the help of the United Nations but by strengthening the French forces while building up the native army and hastening the independence promised within the French Union, the National Assembly was told today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that he was all in favor of justifying and explaining United States foreign policy to Congress. He pledged the State Department to a continuation of policy discussions with Republican Congressional leaders.

Two thousand chronic patients at Goldwater Hospital, most of them in wheelchairs or on stretchers, will receive Christmas presents only if outside donors prove generous, the hospital's recreation chairman said yesterday.

The cranberry comes to the table this year crammed with much more than sharp tang and historical reference.

The Cities Service Company yesterday declared three dividends, payable before the end of this year to more than 235,000 stockholders. Two of the dividends will be cash and the third will be a stock dividend of 5 per cent (one share for each twenty shares held).

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 23-- United States and South Korean forces drove ahead yesterday in new advances to clear the Korean northeast.

NEWARK, Nov. 22--A total of 302 physicians, dentists and veterinarians, New Jersey's first group of doctors, underwent preinduction examination today at the Selective Service Center, 1060 Broad Street. They were in the 25-to-33 age group.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 22-- The Bruins of Brown University who will get up early tomorrow morning to work up an appetite on the gridiron for their Thanksgiving dinners have little to offer against Columbia except determination.

The formation of a new group, known as the Committee of Community Leaders to Safeguard the United Jewish Appeal, whose principal function is to oppose "two major threats to Israel," was announced here yesterday.

DONAWITZ, Austria, Nov. 22-- A $7,380,000 steel blooming mill presented by the Economic Cooperation Administration, one of the first of such projects to be completed in Europe, was formally opened here today in the Alpine Montan steel plant.

The Long Island Rail Road had the grimmest disaster of its illstarred career last night when at least seventy-five persons were killed and ninety-nine suburbanbound Thanksgiving eve travelers, were injured, some probably fatally, in the collision of two eastbound trains in the Richmond Hill section of Queens.

A 9-year-old girl entered Roosevelt Hospital yesterday, accompanied by her mother. Two months ago she had her appendix out and she was returning for a check-up. The child approached Renee Wile, psychiatric social worker on the hospital's social service staff, whom she had come to know during her former stay.

In an attempt to develop replacements for the rapidly diminishing ranks of boxers, the International Boxing Club will conduct an experiment in connection with its Dec. 15 boxing card featuring a ten-round bout between Paddy Young, Greenwich Village middleweight, and Kid Gavilan, Cuban, at Madison Square Garden.

Sixteen tugs led by a harbor cutter of the Coast Guard successfully moved the 45,000-ton battleship New Jersey to the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn yesterday for final drydock work before she goes to sea.

EMERYVILLE, Calif., Nov. 22-- The Shell Development Company dedicated a new consolidated laboratory for oil research here yesterday. It is described as the largest research institution on the Pacific Coast and one of the largest petroleum laboratories in the world.

William Reid, president of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, which operates the Hudson Tubes from New York to New Jersey, emphatically denied yesterday published reports that the road's uptown Manhattan line was about to be sold to New York City ...

After deliberating for three hours and fifty minutes, a Federal Court jury of seven men and five women found Abraham Brothman, chemical engineer, and his business partner, Miriam Moskowitz, guilty yesterday of conspiring to mislead a 1947 Federal grand jury investigating espionage.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 22 --The failure of Western Germany to decide on its contribution to Europe's defense has been an important factor in delaying the reinforcement of United States troops in this country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--A new formula for using sizable numbers of German troops in a collective Western defense force has been drafted by military leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--The United States Steel Corporation and the United Steel Workers, C.I.O., are on the verge of an agreement raising wages 15 to 30 cents an hour, but there is a hitch in the bargain--prices.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--Calls for a "top-level" conference Nov. 30 in the Pentagon to discuss wage stabilization and price controls will be issued soon by W. Stuart Symington, chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

The tiresome and familiar Russian charge that international economic assistance is merely a cloak for "American imperialism" was slapped down in refreshingly specific terms by the delegate from Haiti at the General Assembly this week.

JACKSON, Wyo., Nov. 22 (UP)-- Three forest rangers and a daring volunteer battling up one of the Rockies' sharpest peaks where a missionary plane crashed with twenty-one aboard were driven back tonight by winds "so strong they almost tore the skin off."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)-- The White House said today that the author of a book highly critical of the Federal Bureau of Investigation is a longtime friend of President Truman.

The Department of Health yesterday started checking with health agencies in other cities to determine what their experiences have been with deaths caused by carbon monoxide from defective gas refrigerators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--Drastic in-transit control measures to stop shipments of strategic materials to Communist China and Iron Curtain countries through United States ports are under serious but careful consideration by the Department of Commerce.

THE HAGUE, Netherlands, Nov. 22--The Netherlands Government has put into effect a number of measures to combat what Finance Minister Pieter Leiftinck described today as a "critical" financial situation.

ROME, Nov. 22--The Supreme Defense Counsel met today as scheduled under the chairmanship of Luigi Einaudi, Italian President to discuss questions pertaining to Italy's rearmament in keeping with terms of the North Atlantic treaty.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced last night that he had started a grand jury investigation of underworld influence in Tammany Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22-- Hugo Haas' second independent production, "The Bridge," which he and Arnold Phillips have written, will go before the cameras on Friday at the Motion Picture Center, with Haas, Beverly Michaels and Robert Dane heading the cast and Haas directing.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22-- Ethiopia informed the United Nations today that she was prepared to accept a fourteen-nation proposal for federation with the former Italian colony of Eritrea. Previously the Ethiopian delegation had expressed only misgivings about such a plan.
TORONTO, Nov. 22 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs increased their lead in the National Hockey League tonight with a 5-2 victory over the fourth-place Chicago Black Hawks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22--One of the top leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations told its annual convention here today that much of labor's trouble in the recent election came because it had been induced by the Democratic party to indorse "a lot of racketeers and political hacks."

Traditional football games will mark the Thanksgiving Day schoolboy program today. While a heavy card has been scheduled, the coaches' ban on extracurricular activities in most of the P.S. A.L. schools has resulted in a curtailment of holiday games among public school elevens.

The Chase National Bank declared yesterday an extra dividend of 20 cents a share on the 7,400,000 of its shares outstanding. Chase thus becomes the third large downtown bank to take special action on behalf of stockholders in recent weeks.

The two-year study of rezoning recently completed for the City Planning Commission was endorsed yesterday as "basically well-conceived and practicable" by the board of governors of the Real Estate Board of New York.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 22 --Flood damage in California and Nevada was estimated today at $25,000,000 as this state's rainswollen streams were subsiding and Reno, its downtown district ravaged by the Truckee River, was declared a disaster area by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday and final prices were 53 points higher to 15 points lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--The retail buying wave touched off by the Korean war subsided last month to a level less than 1 per cent above the pre-Korean high, the Department of Commerce announced today. Retail sales in October, according to the report, amounted to $12,085,000,000, or 9 per cent above a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22--Dr. Calvin O. Althouse, widely known educator who was associated with the Philadelphia school system for forty-two years before his retirement in 1947, died yesterday at the Rest Haven Convalescent Home in near-by Broomal. His age was 69.

White lilies and woodwardia ferns formed a garden background yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church for the marriage of Miss Cynthia Foy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Byron C. Foy of 60 East Ninety-third Street and Foy Farm, ...

LONDON, Nov. 22--Ambassadors of Britain, France and the United States probably will meet soon to agree upon the form of the West's answer to the Soviet Union's recent suggestion for the renewal of four-power talks.

For the third time in eight days Frank Erickson, bookmaker, appeared before the New York County grand jury yesterday. The gambler, the jury's only witness, appeared for an hour. Whether Erickson, who is serving a two-year sentence for bookmaking, answered any questions was not disclosed.

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 22 --Confusion and uncertainty on methods and aims stood out from the discussions of the Council of Europe's Assembly today as a result of Britain's flat refusal to accept a supra-national authority.

Clifford M. Rigsbee, formerly with L.S. Ayres Co., Indianapolis, has been appointed manager of the radio-phonograph-television group of the R.C.A. Service Company. He succeeds Thomas Whitney, who has been appointed operations manager for government service.

Selective improvement returned yesterday to the stock market after the indecisive performances in the two preceding sessions. The advance, though limited to certain sections, proved fairly conclusive.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 (AP)-- Vince Boryla, with 21 points, led the New York Knickerbockers tonight as they handed the Baltimore Bullets their fifth straight National Basketball Association defeat, 87--73.
The tides are running fast in Yugoslavia. M. Djilas, one of the top men in the Government, declared the other day that Belgrade has burned the bridges that linked it to Moscow.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during October totaled 230,287,918 lines, an increase of 7.1 per cent over the like month of last year, according to a report issued yesterday by Media Records.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP)--The Federal Communications Commission contended today that the Radio Corporation of America had "flagrantly" disregarded the record of the commission's hearings on color television.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Rogers Bloom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bloom of 262 Central Park West, to Lieut. (j.g.) Robert B. Klausner, Naval Reserve, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Klausner of Jersey City, took place last night at the Pierre. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Berman.

The New York Rangers demonstrated at Madison Square Garden last night that it could be done. Denied victory in their first six home appearances of the National Hockey League, the Blue Shirts hit the win column at the expense of the Canadiens of Montreal, 3 to 2.

Otis Treat Bradley, president of the New York State Bar Association, who was a partner in the New York law firm of Davis, Polk Wardwell, Gardiner Reed, 15 Broad Street, died last night of a heart attack at his home, 1160 Park Avenue. He was 55 years old.

TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 22-- Christian (Charlie) H. Detrick, a newspaper photographer for the last fifty-three years, died here early today in Holy Name Hospital after an illness of three weeks. His age was 75.
The decision of the International Court of Justice in the case of the Peruvian political leader, Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, is an example of making confusion worse confounded.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, Nov. 22 (UP)--Sir Archibald Flower, leader in restoring this town as a shrine to William Shakespeare, died today in his home at the age of 85.

Special plays, to be used against Fordham at the Polo Grounds on Saturday, were devised by Coach Hugh Devore of New York University yesterday. The Violet varsity tested the new offensive patterns in a two-hour drill at Ohio Field.

The New York City Housing Authority sold yesterday $16,565,000 of temporary loan notes for the financing of the Astoria and Flushing Houses, state-aided projects, at interest rates of 1.03 to 1.07 per cent. The notes, dated Dec. 15, 1950, will come due on June 20, 1951.

The designation of a five-year 1 per cent note for the Treasury's forthcoming refunding operations was taken in financial circles to reflect a full meeting of minds for the first time in a year between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve System on the question of the Government's borrowing cost.

A dense crowd that was jammed into the Long Island Rail Road waiting room an corridors at Pennsylvania Station learned of the wreck first at 7:35 P.M., when hawkers selling extra editions of newspapers appeared and began shouting the news.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 9-- The Soviet "cold war" against India and her neighbors will begin, according to plans revealed in intelligence reports here, after military bases have been set up in areas in western Tibet that have already been chosen.

A chill wind with a hint of snow in it did nothing to cool the ardor of auction-goers standing for two and one-half hours yesterday on a cement floor of an open garage where Elisabeth Bergner's household belongings were knocked down to avid bidders to satisfy several judgments.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 (AP)--Mayor Andrew J. (Bossy) Gillis of Newburyport was ordered today by Judge Eugene J. Hudson in Superior Court to restore $43,800 in teachers' pay increases to the city payroll or go to jail.

Mr. and Mrs. John P. Rutherfurd of 927 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rutherfurd's daughter, Miss Sherley Smith, to David McKendree Key Jr., son of David McKendree Key, United States Ambassador to Burma, and Mrs. Key of Essex, Conn.

Operating officials of the Long Island Rail Road asserted yesterday that "we feel we have every safety device we need" and that the road had no intention of installing automatic trippers such as are used by the city's subway system.

The Fisher Baking Company, whose plant has been taken in connection with subway extension work, bought a plot of 60,000 square feet on the north side of Forty-fourth Avenue, from Ninth to Tenth Street, Long Island City, ...
An expansion program at the Roosevelt Hospital, estimated to cost $11,000,000, will get under way next April when work is started on the Tower Memorial which will provide new out-patient facilities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23--A Congressional investigation of the policies being used in bringing Reservists and draftees into military service will be sought under Republican sponsorship.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 23 (AP)-- America's best force to fight aggression and build world peace lies in the United Nations, the National Grange said today in a Thanksgiving Day session of its eightyfourth annual meeting.
A UNITED STATES HOSPITAL, Korea, Nov. 22 (AP)--Twentyseven United States war prisoners freed by the Chinese Communists said today they believed the Reds had released them for propaganda purposes.

George Balanchine's "Prodigal Son," set to Prokofieff's admirable score, had its first performance of the season last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center, and proved once again its indisputable right to the title of a masterpiece.

A sense of frustration and irritation has been emanating from Strasbourg, where the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe has been meeting. In every quarter where high hopes had been entertained of speedy progress toward European unity there is discouragement and waning enthusiasm. Yet a vital idea is not to be killed so easily and no one should be so pessimistic as to prepare the funeral wreaths.

LONDON, Nov. 23--Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, announced today that next Wednesday and Thursday would be devoted to a general debate on foreign affairs in the House of Commons. This will provide an opportunity for left-wing and other supporters of the Labor Government to voice their fears and anxieties regarding this country's close alliance with the United States.

Ways of winding up the Thanksgiving turkey are offered here today; there apparently is no end to the dishes that may be created from cooked poultry. Only four are suggested--turkey in baker's hard rolls, in crisp little turnovers, en casserole with pimento biscuits atop and with eggs and crumbs in a souffle-like "puff."
Residential hotel occupancy here "is at its lowest point since 1942," James A. McCarthy, executive secretary of the Hotel Association of New York City, declared yesterday.

In 1945, a year before Damon Runyon passed on, he confided to an inquisitive colleague that a musical dubbed "Guys and Dolls" was "pretty much in the gab stage" and that "something may come of it some day." Broadway's Boswell should have been around to see his prediction come true.

The Rocket Welding and Manufacturing Corporation, tenant in the two-story industrial building at 672 Grand Concourse, opposite Cardinal Hayes High School, in the Bronx, has purchased the property from the Brent Realty Corporation ...
The new French freighter Loulea arrived here yesterday on her maiden voyage from Havre.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP)--An operation that opens the heart like a drawstring purse, permitting surgeons to probe inside leisurely and without danger of hemorrhage, was described today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 23 (AP)-- The Brown Hotel Stable's Tidy Sum won the Thanksgiving Handicap by a half-length for the second successive year today as the Fair Grounds opened its seventy-fiveday meeting.
Although less publicity is now being given to the subject than a year ago, pension planning in 1950 has been on a large scale, a survey indicates.

The youngest student who attended City College in 1900 is the oldest attending the institution in 1950. Louis Bertcher, now enrolled as an accounting student in the Evening and Extension Division of the college's School of Business, was 12 years old when he became a freshman at the college. He is now 62.

FOOTBALL'S gigantic roulette wheel takes its last full spin this week-end and then clamps down with as much finality as though a reform administration had just been swept into office. The flicking ball will take a few more bounces a week hence but not enough to call for Grand Jury action.

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 23 --The Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly, after a confused and often bitter debate, tonight adopted the British method of the "functional" approach to united European action, abandoning at least for the present the idea of a European federation with supra-national authority.
LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP)--Sir Frederick Bain, deputy chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., died today in Westminster Hospital. He was 61 years old.

With a victory in 65 moves over Dr. S.T. Tartakower in an adjourned game from the ninth round, followed by a brief 21-move draw with Herman Pilnik of Argentina in the tenth, Samuel Reshevsky of New York took second...

PARIS, Nov. 23 (Reuters)-- Prof. Jean-Hyacinthe Vincent, who saved thousands of soldiers from dying of typhoid in the first World War, died here today at Val de Grace Military Hospital. His age was 87.
There will be no increase in prices on the 1951 Ford line of cars that go on display today in dealer showrooms here and throughout the country, the Ford Motor Company announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Russell J. Maguire of Greenwich, Conn., gave a supper dance last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society Miss Natasha Boissevain, daughter of Mrs. Maguire, and Miss Betty Maguire, daughter of Mr. Maguire.

New shoes to complete holiday wardrobes cover all social occasions. Many are as gay and festive as the season, with sparkle and glitter adorning vamps and heels, multicolor ribbons in pinwheel sprays, pastel iridescent kids and heavy laces in many colors studded with brilliants.

AMONG big game hunters there has been one debate that has never been settled: the matter of the identity of America's outstanding big-game trophy, and Jim Bond's new book, "America's Number One Trophy," will provide new fuel for the heat of this argument.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 23 --Minister of the Interior Alexander Rankovitch today assured United States Ambassador George V. Allen that prompt consideration would be given to the settlement of 300 cases of dual nationals claimed by the United States and Yugoslav Governments.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 23--The nation's schools and colleges must teach about controversial issues to protect their students from becoming easy prey for the Communist and fascist lines, delegates warned today at the thirtieth annual convention of the National Council for the Social Studies.

Mayor Impellitteri returned here last night from a vacation in Cuba that was interrupted by news of the tragic wreck on the Long Island Rail Road. He will assume personal direction of the municipal inquiry into the disaster that starts today.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 23 --A new spirit in British industry --leading instead of driving employes--has jumped national production by one-third and individual factory output as high as 800 per cent, executives at the annual employer-employe relations conference were told here recently.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 23 (AP)-- The Missouri Tigers and frigid weather numbed the favored Kansas Jayhawks with a 20-to-6 upset today in their traditional Big Seven Conference football battle.

LONDON, Nov. 23--On its own initiative the British Government has sent a message to the Chinese Communist authorities assuring the Peiping regime that the United Nations forces in Korea have no designs on China or Chinese interests.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23--The State Department expects to begin soon to put into effect its longawaited merger of its semi-autonomous Foreign Service, consisting of "career" diplomats, with its high-ranking Civil Service personnel.

Near-freezing temperatures accompanied by snow and rain brought a raw, wintry Thanksgiving Day to the city yesterday. The weather was part of a cold wave that is moving across the nation and is expected to reach this area today.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Nov. 23-- Payday at the mammoth Lakehurst Naval Air Station is a lot more colorful for the 1,800 officers and enlisted personnel and the 1,200 civilian workers than at most installations of the armed forces.

WARSAW, Nov. 23--O. John Rogge, former assistant United States attorney general, again today ran into a stone wall of Cominform indifference in seeking Yugoslavia's readmission into another international organization.
HANOI, Indo-China, Nov. 23-- The strange war being fought in the Red River Delta here in Tongking is like something out of the pages of "Beau Geste."

TWO weeks ago yesterday nearly 2,000 school teachers from the Eastern hill counties of Kentucky held their annual convention in Ashland, which is the easternmost city of any size in Kentucky. Not only were most of them hill-county teachers; most of them were hillbillies themselves. They were educated men and women who had not acquired their education easily.

YONKERS, Nov. 23--William Harvey Webster, president of the Webster Fuel Corporation, 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, died of a heart attack today at his home at 41 Dellwood Avenue in the Bronxville section of this city. Mr. Webster was 67 years old.
JACKSON, Wyo., Nov. 23 (UP)-- The wreckage of a California DC-3 that crashed on Mount Moran with twenty-one persons aboard was located by a search plane today at the 11,500-foot level.

LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 23 (AP) --Franklin and Marshall College completed its first undefeated and untied football season today by a surprisingly easy victory over Gettysburg, 59 to 20, before a crowd of 13,000.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 23-- President Truman's order neutralizing Formosa should be changed to permit the Chinese Nationalists to smash Communist preparations for an invasion and help guerrillas opposing the Chinese Reds, Senator William F. Knowland, California Republican, said today.
Two lively Danish career girls, fresh from a long and loving look at the wide expanses of America, confessed yesterday that their country would seem "so tame compared to many of your places."
All sorts of exhilarating events transpired at the concert given by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

The chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Patricia Alice Hayden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl William Hayden of New York and London, to Edward Melville Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lincoln Parker of South Orange, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William J. Chase. A reception in the Hayden home at 655 Park Avenue.
A stunned and saddened city saw the death toll in the Thanksgiving eve Long Island Rail Road wreck rise to seventy-seven last night as plans were laid for a four-way investigation into the disaster.

An 18-month-old baby slipped from his father's arms and fell into the Hudson River yesterday morning as the ferryboat, on which both were passengers, neared the West 125th Street slip. The father dived through a cabin window and rescued the infant.
The shocking Thanksgiving Eve tragedy on the Long Island Rail Road leaves the public with a sense of mingled sympathy for the bereaved families and angry indignation at the railroad.
The United Nations massive compression envelopment in North Korea against the new Red armies operating there is now approaching its decisive effort.

Thanksgiving services in the city's churches were attended by thousands yesterday morning. A number of services were conducted under the joint auspices of Protestants and Jews. Prayers of gratitude and hymns of praise were sung.
Jack E. Koppel, president of Steiner-Koppel, Inc., pajama manufacturer, has taken over the interest of Harold A. Steiner and will continue the business under the name of Koppel Co., Inc.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 23-- Mr. and Mrs. Norman Leeds Jr. have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Elizabeth Butler, to Samuel Bowne Haines, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Bowne Haines of Englewood, N.J. The wedding will take place on Feb. 3.

Tammany leader Carmine G. DeSapio lashed back yesterday at the spearheads of his political opposition. He issued a formal statement attacking Robert B. Blaikie and Frank J. Sampson, Mayor Impellitteri's principal representatives in Tammany Hall, and also former ...

All the wonderful things that the small fry love--Indians, helium-filled wonders, floats ablaze with color, bands, Mother Goose characters--roared down Central Park West and Broadway yesterday in Macy's twenty-fourth annual Thanksgiving Day parade.

Realizing perhaps that "Ring Round the Moon" is not a conventional comedy, they refer to it in the program as "a charade with music." "They" are Jean Anouilh, who wrote it in French, and Christopher Fry, who has made the translation.

American couples who go to Eu-- rope in the hope of adopting children will find, for the most part, that their quests are fruitless, Mrs. J.M. Small, deputy secretary general of the International Union for Child Welfare, warned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23-- Skeleton fragments of a ground sloth, an extinct bear-like mammal that lived 100,000 years ago in southern New Jersey, have been found by a high school freshman who would rather search for fossils than play ball.
Fellowships of $5,000 each for travel and study abroad in 1951 have been awarded to five American newspaper men by the Reid Foundation.

As part of the French program for defending Indo-China against Communist-directed conquest, Jean Letourneau, Minister for Associated States, has declared that the largest possible measure of independence will be given to Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos.

PARIS, Nov. 23--A series of proposals for the control of world raw material prices by methods ranging from international consultation to allocation has been prepared by experts for submission to the European Marshall Plan council at its meeting Dec. 1. The council is expected then to name a committee to visit Washington to discuss joint action by the Europeans and the United States.

CAIRO, Nov. 23--The discovery that seditious elements have been using the mass student demonstrations for the British evacuation of the Suez Canal Zone and unity of the Nile Valley to serve other purposes has brought sharp Government action. The Ministry of Interior has issued orders to the students to disperse, expressing its regret that the situation required such a measure.

LONDON, Nov. 23--The stock markets closed on a rising note today after drifting rather aimlessly. British Government securities were more generally supported. Provincial buying helped to impart a stronger tone to industrials in which coal shares were outstanding.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP)--Toronto's Maple Leafs smashed Detroit Red Wings' streak of ten games without a defeat as they fought their way to a 2-1 decision in a freehitting National Hockey League game here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23--Dr. James Llewellyn Crenshaw, Professor of Physical Chemistry at near-by Bryn Mawr College for the last quarter century, died today in Rowan Memorial Hospital, Salisbury, N.C. He was 63 years old.

Provision for basement parking has been incorporated by Emery Roth Sons, architects, in the design of a sixteen-story office building to be constructed in Syracuse, N.Y. Ground is expected to be broken about April 1 for the building, which will be tenanted principadly by insurance companies.

PARIS, Nov. 23--For the second time in a decade relations between Britain and Egypt are dangerously strained. Not since the early winter of 1942 when, under a curtain of wartime censorship, British tanks surrounded Abdin Palace in Cairo, and Ambassador ...

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 23--A 31year-old ex-convict, brandishing two revolvers, was in custody here today after admittedly having abducted a New York City cab driver, keeping him captive in the hack for seven hours while they cruised about New Jersey looking for persons he could rob to "build a bankroll."

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP)--The Pittsburgh Steelers operated efficiently on a snow-blanketed field at a touchdown-per-period pace for a 28-17 National Football League victory over the Chicago Cardinals before 11,622 fans today.
A growing awareness among high school students of the cancer problem was found yesterday in the result of a quiz prepared by the American Cancer Society and the New York City Cancer Committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP)--A research company sued the Government for $1,500,000 today for allegedly violating patent rights on units used to distill fresh water from sea water.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 9-- Once Tibet is invested by the Chinese Communists, and the Russians nail down their hold on the strategic western area for air bases near the Indian border, the next move of the world Communist expansionists, according to intelligence reports, will be to take in ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23--Recent developments suggest that to become prominently engaged in any aspect of the process of identifying Communists and fellow-travelers in this country is to risk office or reputation or both, except when, as in the recent Senatorial election in California, an active participant can persuade the public that he has exposed disloyalty without abrogating the Bill of Rights to anyone.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23--The way was cleared today for the election tomorrow of Michael J. Quill, tempestuous leader of New York's Transit Workers, as a national vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations at its convention here.
Jersey Joe Walcott will endeavor to give a boxing lesson to Rex Layne, heavyweight aspirant from Lewiston, Utah, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 23--Dickinson High School upset a highly favored St. Peter's Prep eleven, 25--6, today before 10,000 fans at Roosevelt Stadium.

TORONTO, Nov. 23 (AP)--Ontario Premier Leslie Frost said today provincial authorities have received little cooperation from United States law enforcement agencies in efforts to combat vice conditions in Windsor, Ont., opposite Detroit.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 23 (AP)--Marshal Tito said today Yugoslavia never would be conquered "except over the dead bodies of her people." He asserted that "if our independence is threatened even more" by the Soviet-led Cominform countries, "we shall buy arms from the West."
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 23-- Alva Johnston, the writer, died tonight at the Lawrence Hospital. His age was 62. He lived at 169 Bobolink Road, Yonkers.

ALBANY, Nov. 23--Legislation to tighten safety regulations on the Long Island and other railroads in New York state fared adversely at the hands of the Legislature or Governor Dewey in the last legislative session.

Joe Lapchick, the Knickerbockers' veteran coach, spent plenty of uneasy moments on the bench as he saw his club drop several tough decisions this season. Last night, however, Lapchick had a rare opportunity to relax when the Knicks swept to a 109-78 victory over the Washington Capitols in a National Basketball Association test.
War clouds in Korea and the immediate memory of a railroad disaster here cast their shadows yesterday over the city as its people observed a bountiful Thanksgiving Day.

LONDON, Nov. 23--The ashes of George Bernard Shaw, who died Nov. 2, were scattered in the garden of his home at Ayot St. Lawrence today after an interpretation of his will had ruled out a burial in Westminster Abbey or any similar memorial.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23 --White Plains High, kingpin of Westchester schoolboy football, completed the third undefeated and untied season in its history by beating Rome (N.Y.) Free Academy, 20--14, before 8,500 fans today.
With no active opposition from shippers to ocean freight-rate increase feelers, a general upward revision of transportation costs will probably be completed in the next two months.

Twenty--five debutantes were presented to society last night in the St. Regis Roof at the Gotham Ball, from which the New York Foundling Hospital will benefit. The ball was preceded by a dinner in the penthouse of the hotel for the debutantes and their escorts. It was opened formally by the young women, all attired in white bouffant gowns, dancing with their fathers.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 (AP)--Your Host, the pride of California Colts, got the seasoned Ponder and Hill Prince, the nation's champion 3-year-old, on his home grounds today and scored a close victdry in the $35,000 added Thanksgiving Day Handicap.

For prospective home builder unable to afford the full-time assistance of an architect a new service that will offer professional advice on a part-time basis has been announced by, Harry M. Prince, president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

BOWIE, Md., Nov, 23 (AP)--Joe Culmone rode five winners today to raise his year's total to 341, as the track received notice that Willie Shoemaker had changed his mind again and would fly East to ride against Culmone here Monday.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 23--Reo Motors, Inc., pioneer motor truck manufacturer, is on the threshold of one of the brightest periods in its forty-six-year history--under the guidance of a man whose background is not trucks, but lawn mowers.

Highlighted by four disqualifications including that of Henry Laskau, the first finisher, the fortieth annual City Hall to Coney Island handicap walking race yesterday was captured by Eugene Chichura of the Polish Falcons A.C., Elizabeth, N.J. The Staten Island Harriers retained team honors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)-- The Commissioner of Internal Revenue, George J. Schoeneman, said tonight an "intensive investigation" was already in progress into charges of an alleged pay-off link between racketeers and Federal agents.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 24--Gen. Douglas MacArthur, who flew today to the Korean front, announced the launching of a "general assault" by the United Nations forces in the Western sector of the Korean front in a movement to close a vise on enemy positions south of the Yalu River.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23--Judge Nelson McVicar, terror of rum runners during the Prohibition era and the last Republican member of the Federal District Court of Western Pennsylvania, announced today that he would retire soon after his eightieth birthday in January.

The National Health Service Act in Britain is "a first-class act being interpreted and administered by second-rate bureaucrats," Victor H. Pinkham, house governor of the Royal Cancer Hospital in London, declared yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 23 --Fourteen German war criminals, nine of whom were serving life sentences, have received grants of clemency from Gen. Thomas T. Handy, commander of the United States forces in Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23-- Warner Brothers has shelved "Front Man," a projected remake of Maxwell Anderson's "Winterset," because of "casting problems and the studio's belief that the picture could not be properly exploited at this time," it was learned from Henry Blanke, who was to have produced the picture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23--The Chamber of Commerce of the United States asserted in a special report on foreign aid today that "there is an urgent need for a single unified foreign assistance program applicable on a flexible basis to any part of the world as circumstances may require."

Scoring in every period, Cardinal Hayes upset its arch Bronx rival, Mount St. Michael, 25--13, in their annual football game at Randalls Island yesterday before 16,500 spectators, the largest local scholastic crowd of the season.
Impish Charlie McCarthy, the nation's most famous splinter, and his alter ego, Edgar Bergen, made a successful and amusing transition to television yesterday afternoon.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 23-- Columbia closed its football season on a high note today, rolling up a 33-0 score on Brown in a morning contest witnessed by 8,000 spectators. The triumph gave Lou Little's team a record of four victories and five defeats on a difficult schedule.

Tin, one of the most strategic commodities imported by the United States, continues to play an important international role as the price of the white metal hovers at or near the highest levels in history.

A campaign to promote the Hawaiian Islands as a year-round vacation spot is being planned by Northwest Airlines, Inc., which operates a service to the islands. "Hawaiian Express," a color film, will be shown throughout the country and abroad starting in the next few weeks.

All Queens hospitals caring for the injured in Wednesday night's wreck on the Long Island Rail Road reported yesterday that their facilities were adequate and that a public appeal for blood was not necessary. The institutions expressed unanimous gratitude for the voluntary public response and told of turning away hundreds of offers of assistance.
CLIDITON, N.J., Nov. 23 (AP)-- Johnny Giantonio, Netcong High School back, scored 54 points today to raise his season's total to 246, an unofficial New Jersey football record.

Doctors, reporters and the police at the Long Island Rail Road wreck in Richmond Hill commended yesterday employes of the New York Telephone Company, declaring that they had "never seen such efficient service in such a short time."

A carefully garnered collection of some of the finest early American furniture produced will be on exhibition tomorrow at the ParkePernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, and will be auctioned through four days next week, beginning Wednesday.
St. John's Prep captured the traditional Thanksgiving Day game at Ebbets Field yesterday, rallying to defeat Brooklyn Prep, 7--6, with a touchdown in the final quarter.
Director Otto Preminger and Michael Rennie, who is featured in Twentieth Century-Fox's "The Scarlet Pen," are slated to leave for Montreal over the week-end to film a climactic scene for the drama.

HONG KONG, Nov. 22--Top figures in the Chinese Communist purchasing network here were reliably reported today to have departed for Peiping. Their departure was taken as another indication that Red China's foreign trade policy is now undergoing high ...
The first report cards of the year now are making a furtive appearance in the American home. Furtive is a word chosen not ...
GENEVA, Nov. 23--Europe's principal coal producing and im porting countries met here today in an effort to find at least a partial solution to the rapidly worsening European coal shortage.

Correcting what he calls misinterpretations of some previous remarks of his, in which he seemed to reject Congressional "re-examination" of our foreign policy and programs as "isolationism," Secretary Acheson says that he will continue in the future as he has done in the past to take leaders of both parties into the confidence of Administration policy-makers and to explain and justify American policy before Congress.

Fifty hardwood mills in New York State and Pennsylvania now have more than enough orders from industrial users to offset a serious drop in volume from the home-building market in the last two months. This is reported by R.E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, who has just returned from a tour of mills in the two states.

HONG KONG, Nov. 23--Communist China charged officially tonight that French ground and air forces in Indo-China had carried out numerous "provocative invasions" of Chinese territory in the southern border provinces of Yunnan, Kwangsi and Kwangtung.

Three hundred gourmets who would rather sink their teeth into some nuttose washed down with yogurt instead of a T-bone steak with imported wine, munched and chewed through a Thanksgiving dinner yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--Restrictions on installment credit imposed by the Federal Reserve Board through its Regulation "W" in September and October have had a substantial effect in slowing dawn consumer demand for durable goods, the board reported today in the November issue of its bulletin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23--The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that the United States, Great Britain and Canada, in a major revision of policy on atomic energy secrets, had agreed to release data relating to "lowpower" nuclear reactors.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 23 (UP)--Thousands of California flood refugees spent their Thanksgiving in makeshift Red Cross shelters today with little hope of returning to their silt-filled homes for another week.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 23--Nationalist China saw its charges against the Soviet Union sidetracked today and accused Britain and France of following a road of appeasement.

The flower-bulb import season is nearing its end, and with delivery of the last case from the fertile beds of the Netherlands this month a colorful and somewhat fabulous character will disappear from the Holland-America Line's Hoboken terminal not to be seen again until late next summer.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Nov. 23 (AP)--Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler's hunch that Thanksgiving turkey might lure home some missing Bergen County gambling witnesses paid off today.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 23 (AP)--John Morgan of Alfred University won the five-mile event of the annual Poughkeepsie Y.M. C.A. road races today, defeating seven rivals in 26 minutes 23 seconds.
Attorney General McGrath's description of the Communist party of the United States, presented in the form of a petition to the Subversive Activities Control Board, contains few or no surprises.
DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP)--The Detroit Lions stuffed themselves with seven touchdowns today as they whipped the New York Yanks, 49--14, before a Thanksgiving Day turnout of 30,206 fans.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 24(AP)--The University of Miami Hurricanes turned back a stubborn University of Iowa eleven, 14--6, before 44,999 in the Orange Bowl tonight to remain undefeated but with one tie in nine games.

TENAFLY, N.J., Nov. 24-- Harry F. Bush of 232 River Edge Road, former assistant deputy surveyor in the United States Customs Service, died yesterday after an illness of several months at the age of 78.

The curtain falls for the season on the gridirons of all but a handful of colleges in the East and Middle West today. By nightfall, whatever sectional champions remain to be established will have been crowned and the pairings for the big bowl games will be pretty much in order.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 24--Two Soviet-bloc proposals to grant independence to the former Italian colony of Eritrea were rejected today by the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

NEWARK, Nov. 24--The killing of twenty-one deer by automobiles on Essex County highways since the first of November has focused attention on the problem of protecting an increasing herd of the Virginia white-tailed variety in this area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today scheduled a hearing on Dec. 5 on the application of Penn Fuel Gas, Inc., of Oxford, Pa., to acquire the common stock of seven Pennsylvania gas utility companies.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Nov. 24 --A House subcommittee investigating the May 19 munitions blast in this city heard the United States Coast Guard charged today with negligence in assuring the safe movement of explosives through this port.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24--Earl F. Reed, counsel for Washington and Jefferson College, said today he would demand a jury trial in the suit filed by Dr. Julius Kraft of New York for seventeen years' pay amounting to $90,000 for his dismissal by the school last June.
By far the nation's best-selling cut flower, fifty million roses are purchased each year. Generally speaking, they are sold by the dozen and arranged by the dozen.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24-- Princeton's single-wing powerhouse will encounter the Big Green of Dartmouth tomorrow in an attempt to bring Old Nassau its first perfect season since 1935. More than 35,000 fans are expected in Palmer Stadium for the kick-off at 1:30 P.M.

Retail sales here went ahead of figures established last year, according to estimates made yesterday by trade observers. Department store sales were estimated to be between 5 and 10 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 3 per cent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 24 --The Yugoslav Government announced this morning that it had reached an agreement with the United States Government last Tuesday to receive food for the ... Yugoslav Army from funds allocated to the Mutual Defense Assistance Program.
F. Cliffe Johnston of 927 Fifth Avenue, retired banker and real estate broker, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 68.

BARNEGAT CITY, N.J., Nov. 24--New Jersey duck hunt ers have been getting an excellent break in the weather since the opening of the season and although there have been a few "bluebird" periods the Barnegat ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP)-- President Truman, much to his displeasure, probably is one of the most closely protected men in the world these days as a result of the recent attempt on his life.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 24--Representative W. Kingsland Macy, Suffolk County Republican leader who was defeated in the Nov. 7 election by Ernest Greenwood, Democrat-Liberal candidate, by 138 votes, today challenged the validity of 520 ballots.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)-- Eleven persons aroused of contempt of Congress for refusing to answer questions of the House Committee on un-American Activities pleaded not guilty today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--President Truman appointed Nelson A. Rockefeller today as chairman of the Advisory Board on International Development and requested him to plan aid for undeveloped areas of the world as soon as possible.

The United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers, A.F.L., announced yesterday its intention to seek a general wage increase for 40,000 members throughout the country to meet higher living costs precipitated by the Korean war.

CAIRO, Nov. 26--An assembly here of economists and experts from throughout the Arab world meeting under the auspices of the United Nations to study the condition of 75 per cent of the Arab population that works on the land has described the situation as disastrous.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 26 (AP) --Green Bay snow-plowed to a pair of last-quarter touchdowns and a 25-21 victory over San Francisco today before 13,196 fans in windswept City Stadium.

A survey by the Custom Brokers and Forwarders Association of America blames current "deplorable" delays in the delivery of import goods on a shortage of customs personnel in nearly all districts of the country.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP)-- Johnny Pasco, a substitute quarterback, paced the Santa Clara Broncos to a 28-to-26 upset victory today over Loyola University of Los Angeles. Loyola had been unbeaten and untied this season.

A Lazy Susan, which is anything but lazy, might be a useful piece of equipment for the homemaker during the holidays. A turntable with or without dishes, it stands on the dining table and can serve silently at parties as well as at family meals.

Leaders of three juvenile gangs in Brooklyn's Park Slope section agreed at a meeting yesterday in the borough's Fifth Avenue police station to persuade their members to turn in their weapons, ranging from knives to guns, on a no-question basis some time this week.

The return of the United States to its original ideals was urged by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church. He condemned low-mindedness in the theatre, in popular fiction and in the personal character of citizens.

The full extent of damage to small coastal and harbor craft and to waterfront property in Saturday's storm will not be known perhaps until tomorrow, a spokesman for the Third District Coast Guard headquarters, 80 Lafayette Street, said yesterday.

This week's program in New York art galleries is varied and crowded. It features one large museum show, that of "Italy at Work," an exhibition of 2,500 objects, which will open on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Museum.
