LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26-- Warren R. Austin, United States representative on the United Nations Security Council, has prepared twenty questions to be put to the Chinese Communists on their policy in Korea and Formosa when they make their first appearance before the Council tomorrow afternoon.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 26-- A regional program to correlate the South's graduate training facilities and material resources to provide more effective support to the national defense needs was presented today at the opening session of the Southern Governors Conference.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 26--A fundamentalist church leader charged today that the formation on Wednesday of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. would be a "sad and dark occasion" for American Protestantism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)-- The lucky East Texan who paid $6.89 for some surplus Air Force equipment and then sold it to Air Force officers for $63,000 has found some more at bargain prices, it was reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 (AP) --Sharp-passing Quarterback Ed Brown had a field day in leading the University of San Francisco to a surprisingly easy 35-13 victory over the Detroit University team at muddy Kezar Stadium today.
The angry weather over a wide area of the country has enabled footwear retailers to dispose of a considerable quantity of rubbers, galoshes, heavy shoes and similar items, it was learned yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26-- The most costly single film yet undertaken for television will go before the cameras tomorrow under the title "The Pharmacist's Mate," with Brian Donlevy and Gene Raymond heading the cast and Irving Pichel directing.

Members of the Masonic order attended Protestant and Jewish services throughout the state yesterday on the annual "Go-toChurch Sunday" of the organization. The principal services here included two held on an interfaith basis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)-- Sammy Baugh, still frisky at 36, scored a touchdown himself and passed for three more to lead the Washington Redskins to a 38-28 victory over the Baltimore Colts today before 21,275.
BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP)--New England's worst storm since the 1938 hurricane petered out today, but not before the rain-laden gale caused millions of dollars in damage.

Residents of the New York suburban area shivered in lightless, heatless, sometimes roofless homes, or picked their way through broken glass and fallen trees in the aftermath of the most damaging storm here since the 1944 hurricane.
Although the PhilharmonicSymphony lacked ten players Saturday night because of the hurricane, the show went on and the audience left vacant only a quarter of the seats in Carnegie Hall.
The prediction for New York City for Saturday morning was: "Occasional rain and windy today; rain, snow tonight; fair tomorrow."

The Department of Commerce has announced a meeting tomorrow with traders, bankers and shippers at its regional office here in New York to discuss closer control of shipments of strategic materials to Communist China through United States ports.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 26--Cornell University prepared to reopen classes tomorrow in the face of a strike of 800 maintenance workers who could deprive the campus of all services, including heat.

Order M-6, issued by the National Production Authority, will have little effect on the volume of steel shipments to warehouses, with two or three execptions, according to a report by Walter S. Doxsey, president of the American Steel Warehouse Association, Cleveland. The report was released to the 700 members of the association.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that he was investigating the background and stock-selling operations of a company in which Paul V. McNutt, former Governor of Indiana and ex-Ambassador to the Philippines, and Josiah Marvel Jr., former Ambassador to Denmark, are officers.

NEW MILFORD, N.J., Nov. 26 --The New Jersey Audubon Society began operating today from its new state headquarters here at 796 River Road on the banks of the Hackensack River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The Eighty-first Congress takes up tomorrow a self-imposed assignment to try to enact an excess profits tax in its final session. Bitter controversy was in prospect from the very outset.

Some excellent values were available in the wholesale markets here last week as sellers went after business. Stores were concentrating on reducing inventories, according to reports prepared especially fOr THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Holiday business set in with a rush, but stocks were ample and reorders were small.

The Rockefeller Foundation has withdrawn further grants to cover the expenses of operating the National Theatre Conference, a nonprofit organization aiding directors of community and university theatres. This became known after a three-day convention of the N.T.C. that ended yesterday at the Piccadilly Hotel. Still on hand, though, is a subsidy of $15,000 earmarked for fellowships until the end of next Year.

Raymond E. Benson, 56 years old, executive secretary of Ducks, Unlimited, a national organization of duck hunters, died yesterday afternoon in Jamaica Hospital, Queens, of a fractured skull received in Saturday's gale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP)-- Senate investigators have "verified" that a Philadelphia "flophouse" housing three persons produced 105 registered voters in the recent election, Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, reported today.

DURHAM, England, Nov. 26-- This little cathedral town, occasionally in the news because of its celebrated coal mines, has suddenly found itself pilloried in headlines throughout Britain because three part-time Durham charwomen have refused to join a union.

Asserting that cotton prices at both raw and piece-goods levels are becoming alarmingly high, Sidney Rosenblum, president of the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers, has called for Government action to halt the upsurge.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Nov. 26-- The Lighter-than-air Pilot Training Center at this largest naval air station in the world has the distinction of having more applicants for the course than can be handled, which may be something of a record in the armed forces' widespread training program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--Jockey William Lee Shoemaker, who rode in sunny California yesterday, arrived by plane in chilly Washington today and met Joe Culmone, the lad from Sicily who is three up on Shoemaker in the fight for the national riding title. They'll go at it boot-to-boot at Bowie tomorrow in a nine-race program that will be headed by a two-horse contest that has been named the Bowie Special.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Monday, Nov. 27--The rearmament of Western Germany appeared farther away than ever early this morning as returns from Bavaria's state elections showed the... Socialists, who seek a slowdown on arms plans, had made marked gains over their former position.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 26 (AP)--Hungarian hoarders were warned today to stop hoarding or face the music.

All New York stations that suffered from the storm were back on the air yesterday with the exception of WNEW. Other stations were either sharing time on auxiliary sending equipment kept for just such emergencies or were broadcasting on greatly reduced power from auxiliary electric generators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The United States has appealed to Britain not to press any conversations with the Chinese Communists too far until the outcome of the current offensive in Korea is a little clearer.
ALBANY, Nov. 26 (AP)--Spreading snowstorms brought new discomfort tonight to wind-battered and rain-drenched upstate New York as the death list mounted to 21.

Brother Abban Philip F.S.C., Assistant Superior General of the Brothers of the Christian Schools, died early yesterday morning as he knelt by his bed to pray at St. Joseph's Normal Institute in Barrytown, N.Y. His body was discovered when a search was made after he failed to appear at Mass. He was 79 years old.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 26--Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck said this week that the gap in the Dutch balance of payments would reach the abnormally high figure of 1,000,000,000 guilders this year against the abnormally low total of 240,000,000 last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP)-- Tighe E. Woods, Housing Expedieter, said today that there would be a "sharp" increase in rents if Congress failed to continue Federal rent controls beyond Dec. 31.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 27-- Strong enemy counter-attacks led by soldiers of the Chinese Communist armies stalled yesterday the United Nations general offensive driving toward the Manchurian frontier on the Yalu River.

A newcomer from France, Gerard Souzay, made his American debut last night in Town Hall. Mr. Souzay is a baritone who exemplifies the best tradition of French style in the vocal art. He is a considerable stylist, a singer of intelligence, one inclined to understate rather than push his points, and at all times a performer of taste.

In all conscience, no one should ever ask to see tragedy acted more magnificently than Judith Anderson plays it in "The Tower Beyond Tragedy." This is the Robinson Jeffers poem on the Electra theme with which ANTA opened its series at the ANTA Playhouse last evening. Call it a masterpiece and you cannot be wrong.

The instant deaths that resulted from Saturday's storm and from hte Long Island Rail Road wreck should cause believers to meditate on the "reality of the Last Judgment" and to realize that for any individual it "may be even at the door," the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 26 --Miss Miriam Hilda Goldstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan E. Goldstein, was married to Dr. Leonard Samuel Sommer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sommer, at noon today in Kodimoh Synagogue. The Rev. Dr. Isaac Klein performed the ceremony.

Lily Pons will make her first appearance of the season in a revival of "The Barber of Seville" during the Metropolitan Opera's fifth week, which begins Dec. 4. Giuseppe Di Stefano will sing his first Count and Cesare Siepi his first Don Basilio in the production.
On Nov. 16 Mayor Impellitteri sent out an order to all city department heads to forbid employer under their jurisdiction to solicit or encourage "in any manner or form" gratuities from taxpayers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 26-- Connecticut counted two dead, scores injured and millions of dollars of damage today in the wake of a near-hurricane that lashed the state until a late hour last night.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP)--Illinois landed four players and Ohio State and Michigan three apiece to monopolize the 1950 All-Big Ten football team selected for The Associated Press by conference coaches.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market last week moved over a wide trading range, but closed the period at a net loss as a result of a sharp drop on Friday. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed declines of 22 to 105 points for the week.
ATLANTA, Nov. 26 (UP)--A car-record November cold wave that killed at least six persons in the South relented for a few hours today before handing the region a third night of subfreezing weather.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 25--Although for nearly two years it has served as an effective bogey man frightening West Germany, the army of the Communist Republic of the east appears to be deteriorating in quality at a remarkable rate.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 26--Buffeted by freakish snow storms, this industrial city of 1,000,000 inhabitants virtually was cut off tonight from the rest of the state by mountainous snowbanks that crippled all transportation facilities.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 26-- Prevented from holding two-thirds of its scheduled program yesterday due to a power failure, officials of the Boulder Brook Club's indoor two-day horse show rearranged its schedule today and by nightfall had classes running according to original plans. Sacrificed were the noon and dinner recesses.

While Christmas shoppers are expected to have little difficulty in finding kitchenware items this year, a shortage, coupled with higher prices, is anticipated some time after the holidays, according to local stores checked by this department.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 26 (AP)--Promoter Sam Becker announced tonight that the fifteen-round title match between heavyweight champion Ezzard Charles and Nick Barone of Syracuse, N.Y., will go on Tuesday night, as originally scheduled.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 26-- Superior Court Judge Alberic A. Archambault died here today at the age of 63.

Six manufacturers and one association of manufacturers of quality goods in the home furnishings field in Great Britain have joined in a cooperative group to promote the sale of their products in the United States, according to the British Information Service. The group will be known as "Great Names from Great Britain," an announcement released by the manufacturers stated.

The three-man commission named by Governor Dewey to conduct a "sweeping study" of the wreckridden and bankrupt Long Island Rail Road will hold its first fullscale meeting tomorrow at its headquarters in the State Building, 270 Broadway.

Thomas Pyle, who has sung here frequently as a member of the Collegiate Chorale, gave his first New York recital last night at Times Hall. The young baritone proved himself a man of exceptional taste in the program he selected and an artist in the way he sang it.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y. Nov. 26--Palisades Interstate Park police and rangers, aided this afternoon by two Air Force planes from Stewart Field, sought last night, today and tonight for Emanuel Hittleman of 77-10 Utopia Parkway, Flushing, Queens, 17 years old, a high school student, missing in Bear Mountain State Park since Saturday at 5:30 P.M.

The United States has reached a condition where inflation is so great a danger that "we are running the risk of being led involuntarily into increasing regimentation and control bordering on socialistic authoritarianism," J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, asserted yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

The present allowances to relief recipients in New York are 5 per cent below the minimum required to meet the Welfare Department's standards, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday in his October report to Mayor Impellitteri.

Mr. and Mrs. Armand Jaggi of Geneva, Switzerland, have announced here the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Mrs. Jacqueline Jaggi Cross, to Louis G.V. Hyde, son of Mrs. Harris Fahnestock of 730 Park Avenue and Fletcher Sprague Hyde of Boston.
New York City headquarters of the State Department of Labor's Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance are to be established at 1440 Broadway.

The promotion of Van Courtlandt Short to purchasing agent of the United States Lines was made known yesterday by John M. Franklin, the president. Mr. Short, who had been assistant purchasing agent since February, 1947, succeeded the late Albert De Smedt.

Big Steve Brklacich was the big gun with two goals as the New York Rovers put on a fine exhibition of hockey yesterday afternoon in beating the Johnstown (Pa.) Jets, 3--2, in a rugged Eastern League game at Madison Square Garden.

New York and most of the northeastern states emerged yesterday from the great storm that had battered them on Saturday to count 205 dead and property damage estimated at more than 100,000,000. Five of the deaths were in New York City and thirty-three others in the metropolitan area.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 26--The United Nations Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea arrived here late today. The seven-nation body was greeted at Kimpo Airfield by ranking Korean Government leaders and entered the city through cheering lines of Koreans, who crowded the curbstones leading to the Chosun Hotel, in which the commission members will live.
DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP)--The auto industry faces more uncertanty right now than it has at any time in nearly a decade.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP)--The ferocious Chicago Bears, playing their best game of the season, scored in every period to halt the Los Angeles Rams, 24--14, today and replace their West Coast rivals atop the National Football League's National Division.

VOLUME IV of Winston Churchill's magnificent and monumental "The Second World War" is published today. It is called "The Hinge of Fate" and concerns the events between January, 1942, and June, 1943. ALBANY, Nov. 26--Ch. Prince Alexander, a sound and stylish golden retriever belonging to 12year-old Miss Elisabeth Tuttle of Rutland, Vt., became best in show today in the seventh and biggest all-breed event of the Albany Kennel Club.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 26 (AP)--Tony Bettenhausen of Tinley Park, Ill., was officially declared winner of the A.A.A. national 150-mile auto racing championship today at Bay Meadows, nearly two hours after he roared across the finish line a good lap ahead of the field.

PARIS, Nov. 26--France proposes to follow the United States and Britain in granting economic and financial aid to Yugoslavia by means of a trade agreement. Talks are now taking place between representatives of Marshall Tito and French experts from the Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Economic Affairs, Finance and Industrial Production.

One sparkling offensive sally that covered eighty yards in four plays and three subsequent defensive stands in the shadow of their goalposts gave the New York Giants a 7-to-3 decision over the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP)--After taking the ice 90 minutes late, the Canadiens stormed from behind for a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Bruins tonight before an 8,239 crowd at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Nov. 26--An unexpected although not an unnatural pause has occurred in the stock markets in the past few days. There is no suggestion in the current modest recession of any real change in sentiment. It is merely that activity, which had been vigorous and sustained over a considerable period, has somewhat abruptly and probably temporarily collapsed. The reasons, however, are not far to seek.

SALONIKA, Greece, Nov. 26-- Greek children who returned yesterday from enforced exile in Yugoslavia worshiped God today for the first time in two or three years in the manner of their fathers. They said that in the areas they had come from religion was neither observed nor mentioned.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 26-- Export and Import License Board has lifted restrictions for the importation of automobiles and electric refrigerators, provided these two items are traded for surplus Brazilian products.

Fashion's latest gift to the girl who makes her own clothes is the apron overskirt, an easy way to make a plain dress look important. For the holidays, an apron can transform a simple sheath or basic dress into a glamorous evening or festive cocktail fashion. And, incidentally, these suggestions might help you with your Christmas gifts for others.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26--Steel production this month seems slated for a new record. Output last week was down a point to 102 per cent of rated capacity, reflecting the storm conditions at the weekend in this district.

HONG KONG, Nov. 26--Economic security measures have been tightened in state-operated industrial enterpries throughput Manchuria with the double aim of improving fire prevention controls and checking "sabotage activities of counter-revolutionaries," according to Communist China's official news service.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26--This area began today digging out from under a snowstorm that had business prostrate and thousands of families marooned in isolated communities, many of them at the mercy of flooding streams.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 26--Miss Louise Probst, said to be the oldest graduate of Hunter College and the oldest retired New York City school teacher, quietly celebrated her ninety-fifth birthday today by entertaining a host of well-wishers who visited her home here.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 26-- Willem Willeke, noted 'cellist, who was a member of the Kneisel Quartet during the last ten years of its existence, died early today of a heart attack in the Pittsfield General Hospital after an illness of five days. He was 71 years old.

In its first change of ownership in fifty years, the five-story building at 126 East Fifty-seventh Street has been sold by the Bank of New York-Fifth Avenue Bank, executors of the estate of Amelia R. Worrall, to Hugh K. McGovern, operator.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26--Yugoslav leaders are re-examining the fundamental question of whether Yugoslavia could remain neutral in a general European war in which an aggressor's army would by-pass this country in an effort to obtain its temporary neutrality.

LONDON, Nov. 26--A further rise in the cost of living--a factor that is becoming a predominant political issue in this country--was predicted today by Hugh Gaitskell, Chancellor of the Exchequer and the nation's economic boss.

Insurance companies will do everything possible to expedite the payment of claims resulting from Saturday's storm, which caused damage in varying degrees to thousands of homes in the metropolitan area and New Jersey, a spokesman for the National Board of Fire Underwriters said last night.

An emergency Government shipping agency to handle the national merchant marine in the event of war is now being organized.

REPUBLIC OF KOREA ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 29--Collapse of the Republic of Korea (R.O.K.) Army's Second Army Corps holding the vital right flank of the United Nations defensive positions on the northwest front was attributed here today to previous loss through heavy casualties of trained officers and experienced troops. In addition, a general lack of will to fight Chinese troops contributed to the flagging morale that preceded the R.O.K.'s disintegration.
PARAMUS, N.J., Nov. 29--On a back road in this community, fifteen miles from New York, the Hevea or rubber-producing tree is being grown successfully.

LONDON, Nov. 29--Millions of pounds were knocked off the market value of shares on the stock markets here today, reflecting the grave view taken of events, in Korea. In some sections the slump was about the biggest since the financial crisis of 1947.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--A Senate elections subcommittee unanimously decided today to end its investigation of the "Hanley letter" episode in the New York Senatorial campaign, but withheld making public any conclusions drawn from the inquiry.

During the day yesterday and throughout the preceding night the heavy cruiser St. Paul, flying the flag of Rear Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, continued to provide pin-point bombardment support of the R.O.K. Capital. Division advancing north of Chongjin.

Joe Adonis, so-called czar of gambling in the eastern half of the United States, argued, by means of a demurrer filed in Special Sessions yesterday that a criminal information brought against him and four lieutenants, did not constitute a crime in New York County.

Lenox Hill Industries introduced at a dealer preview yesterday in the Vanderbilt Hotel its new furniture and lamp lines almost six weeks in advance of the official winter furniture markets and lamp shows. The company is one of the first, if not the first, non-Southern furniture producer to hold a premarket showing of new lines.
A further gain by Miguel Najdorf of Argentina marked the play in last night's fourteenth round of the international chess masters tournament, according to a report from Amsterdam.

DETROIT, Nov. 29--More than 600,000 automobile industry workers got a 3-cent-an-hour wage increase today, effective Dec. 1, un der agreements tying wages to the cost of living. The rise came after the Federal consumer price index climbed to a record high of 174.8 from the 172.5 on July 15.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29--The United States Steel Corporation and Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., reached a tentative wage agreement today, setting a pattern for most of the 1,000,000 workers in the nation's steel industry.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 30-- The United Nations forces fell back yesterday under a heavy Communist attack to seek defensive positions in the western sector of Korea.

Violinists of the Auer school are commonly supposed to have a monopoly on tonal splendor; but Ruggiero Ricci, who gave a Carnegie Hall recital last night, although not an Auer descendant, can match tones with any living violinist. The chances are that it is not he who will suffer in contrast.

Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy conferred for an hour and a half yesterday with eighteen representatives of tavern and package store owners' associations on reports that the police submitted "Christmas lists" to business men.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)-- Senator John W. Brisker, Republican of Ohio, introduced a resolution in the Senate today proposing that at least one television frequency in each state be set aside for educational purposes.
Schoharie, the smaller of the two Catskill reservoirs, continued to overflow yesterday as New York City water storage gained another 1,908,000,000 gallons.

The Federal Trade Commission will reassess its position on two important business monopoly theories, Lowell B. Mason, member of the F.T.C., told more than 500 industrialists and trade association executives yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Standards Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The commission is faced with a Congress hostile to the F.T.C.'s former views on "conscious parallel action" and "freight absorption," Mr. Mason said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Official Army spokesmen, while admitting the gravity of the Korean military situation, cautioned today against "overpessimism" and said that United States troops had successfully gotten out of tighter spots in the east.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29--H. H. Levonian, chief engineer of the Kuljian Corporation, a power plant engineering company here, announced today that the Government of India has awarded the Kuljian organization a contract to design, engineer and construct the first super-power plant in the Far...
Two deportation hearings were held yesterday at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Retail prices have reached a record high and there is no end in sight. Wages are ascending with them.
YONKERS, Nov. 29--"Roosevelt curve" on the Saw Mill River Parkway, where Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and four other persons were injured in a collision in 1946, is being eliminated.
The news was color in the resort fashion show staged by Russeks at a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)-- President Truman today nominated William F. Riley to be United States District Judge for southern Iowa and Alfred E. Modarelli to be a District Judge for New Jersey.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29--A new era in American Protestantism began here this morning when 600 church leaders representing twenty-five denominations and four Eastern Orthodox bodies brought into existence the new National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Following is the text of the address by Secretary of State Dean Acheson on "The Strategy of Freedom," delivered in Washington to the National Council of Churches of Christ, meeting in Cleveland:

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 29-- The State Board of Canvassers today disclosed official Connecticut election figures showing that Senator Wiliam Benton, Democrat, defeated Prescott S. Bush, Republican, for the two-year Senate term by 1,102 votes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--The Senate Banking and Currency Committee reported a resolution today extending present Federal rent control for an additional two months.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 29-- Working outdoors briefly for the first time since the week of the Pennsylvania game, Army completed its more rugged chores today in preparation for Navy as a light snowfall drove the squad inside after a half-hour's practice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--President Truman stressed the importance of the Point Four program in dealing with the "Communist menace" in the Far East as he held his first meeting today with the new Advisory Board on International Development.
Eleven young women who today will become regular members of the Women's Army Corps spent yesterday having a fine, final civilian fling.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 29--The texts of several broadcasts from Mukden during the past week, which were received here today, indicate that the Chinese Communists have about 900,000 men under arms in Manchuria and North Korea.
Two distinguished works had their first presentations of the season at the City Center last night by the New York City Ballet. They are William Dollar's "The Duel" and George Balanchine's "Orpheus."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--President Truman asked Congress today for $80,525,000 of supplemental cash and the release of $126,000,000 of obligational authority, mostly for prompt execution of defense and security programs. Reaching the Capitol in advance of estimates of defense expenditures expected to be submitted later this week, today's call dealt with projects in eight departments and agencies and included $38,000,000 of additional emergency aid to Yugoslavia.

Ernest Stauffen Jr. of 40 Lincoln Street, Englewood, N.J., a director and chairman of the finance committee of the Manufacturers Trust Company, this city, died yesterday afternoon in the Englewood Hospital after a brief illness. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said today it was not necessary or wise to relax the maximum hours law now. If the need arises, a national policy on hours for the greatest possible production will be worked out in cooperation with all Federal agencies, he said.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Civilian uses of copper will be cut 15 per cent in January and February and 20 per cent in March under an order issued today by the National Production Authority.

The stock market on the New York Stock Exchange snapped back a bit yesterday despite the fact that the news from Korea showed no improvement. Although the list encountered a wave of new selling in the morning, quotations managed to pull out of the new slump in the afternoon and repair some of the damage.

Janice Mitchell, New York soprano, made her local debut last night at Town Hall. Accompanied by Gibner King, she sang a program that included Lieder by Schubert and Strauss, new songs by Richard Malaby, Marcello's cantata, "Didone" and "Dis-moi que je suis belle" from Massenet's "Thais."

The Port of New York Authority yesterday sold $13,000,000 of Air Terminal bonds and $3,000,000 of Marine Terminal bonds to Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and associates, at a price of 96.3599 per cent of par at an average annual interest cost to the authority of 2.3213366 per cent.

New York's hospitals could provide 67,690 beds for persons wounded and burned in an atomic attack on the city. This would be about half the number required for the 150,000 seriously wounded expected from such an attack by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Hospitals Commissioner. The bed figure does not take into account his other estimate that half of New York's hospitals themselves would be destroyed.

Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania and a Republican Presidential aspirant for 1952, last night pledged Republican support for the rearming of America and also of Europe if the European nations would help.

All the Rangers could get out of their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night was a tie. A goal in the first period by New York's Eddie Kullman was matched by a thirdchapter tally by Jimmy Conacher.

Two issues of securities aggregating $12,200,000 will be offered for sale today. One is $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of Central Power and Light Company and the other an offering by Chemical Corporation to its common stockholders of 128,533 of its common shares, at $25 a share, on the basis of one new share for each four held.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The Senate droned through a second day--a short one--of debate today on President Truman's "must" bill to give statehood to Alaska. When recess came at 4 P.M. no attempt had been made to force a vote on whether the measure should even receive formal consideration.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP)--The Tropical Park race course tomorrow will inaugurate South Florida's 142-day 1950-51 winter thoroughbred racing season optimistic that its forty-one-day meeting will bring new stature and more money to the Coral Gables oval.

This week's Senate debate--if one can call it that--over statehood for Alaska and Hawaii has brought to the fore some of the seamier reasons for depriving these two territories of their democratic right to join the Union as equal partners.

The Aluminum Company of America has agreed to expand its production facilities to provide an additional 120,000 tons, or 240,000,000 pounds, of new primary aluminum capacity annually, according to announcements yesterday by the General Services Administration and the company. The program will be completed in 1952 and 1953.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh said he would ask for an inquiry into circumstances leading to a Traffic Court hearing yesterday in which a city employe testified a political club captain assured him that $5 would cover a restricted parking summons usually carrying a $15 fine.

United Nations forces in Korea continued to fall back "to a designated line" in the face of unremitting assaults by the Chinese Communists. Two United States divisions were said to have retired behind the Chongchon River to hold a fifteen-mile corridor to the Yellow Sea.

When the House Ways and Means Committee was holding hearings on the Administration's excess profits tax, the Democratic members presented a solid front against all proposals to substitute some alternative type of corporation tax. But with the voting by the committee on the separate provisions of the plan that solid front has now been broken.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 29--An emergency meeting of the Korean Cabinet was held today.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, newsprint manufacturers controlling the largest papermaking capacity on the Pacific Coast, increased its consolidated net income in the six months ended on Oct. 31 to $12,411,785, from $8,656,013 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The House Ways and Means Committee tried and failed today to agree on a formula for taxing excess profits, but members expected to compromise tomorrow on some modification of the plan proposed by the Truman Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--President Truman asked Congress today to provide, during its current short session, $38,000,000 to pay for famine relief in Yugoslavia. He described such a step as "clearly in our national interest."

TOKYO, Nov. 29--United Nations commanders continued today to debate what happened when the "general assault" personally launched by Gen. Douglas MacArthur Friday in the hope of ending the war, turned into a massive, Communist counter-offensive.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 29-- Warren R. Austin, the United States representative, today called on the United Nations Security Council to shelve Communist China's "fantastic" charge that the United States had committed an aggression in Formosa. He urged that the Council instead expedite a vote on a resolution calling for the withdrawal of the Peiping Government's troops from Korea.
Acapulco blue, Mayan gold, Popocatepetl pink, Toreador red and Matador black were some of the names given the colors of dresses shown at Saks 34th Street yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--A Ways and Means subcommittee agreed today to ask the House of Representatives for subpoena powers in an investigation of alleged protection pay-offs to Internal Revenue agents in California.

Fear of deeper economic controls in this country if the military situation in the Far East gets worse encouraged heavy liquidation in the near months of the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 76 points lower to 3 points higher than on Tuesday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 29 (UP)--A Roman Catholic clergyman charged today that Pope Pius was the leader of a network of spies and director of "subversive activity," against the governments of Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared tonight that the Chinese Communist aggression in Korea had created "a situation of unparalleled danger."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP)-- The Senate Armed Services Committee unanimously approved today the nomination of Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg of New York to be Assistant Secretary of Defense in charge of manpower problems.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 29--Suspicion that the Russians, emboldened by the Chinese successes in Korea, may act in Germany is beginning to worry both the Government and the people of Western Germany.

Among actions on dividends announced yesterday were the yearend declarations of $1.25 on the common stock of the Studebaker Corporation and the increased quarterly dividend of 75 cents voted by the Wheeling Steel Corporation on the larger number of common shares resulting from a 25 per cent stock dividend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (U.P.)-- Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, reported today that bank loans had soared to a record high last month and cautioned bank officers to tighten up on "inflationary" credit policies.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 29 --In an 8,500-word decision here today Frederick P. WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--An approach to industrial peace that would stress public participation and diminish government's role in labor-management relations is being undertaken by a new organization called Industry Council Association, Inc.

Buried under stacks of congratulatory telegrams from all over the country, Charlie (Chuck) Dressen, newly appointed manager of the Dodgers, put in his first day at Ebbets Field yesterday and lost no time making it clear a "new look" was taking over.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that for the ten months to Oct. 31, operations resulted in a net income of $6,525,281, contrasted with a loss of $4,743,992 in the same period a near ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29--The grain markets developed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade here today, closing at about the bottom, with soybeans off 5 to 6 cents a bushel. Wheat was 5/8 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel lower; corn was off 5/8 to 1 cents a bushel, and oats lost 3/8 to 1 cents. Rye was down 2 to 2 cents. Lard finished at losses of 10 to 22 cents for 100 pounds.

The Kips Bay Boys' Club will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Golden State" on Monday night at the Fulton Theatre. Miss Helen G. Wylly heads the committee that is in charge of the sale of boxes and seats for the performance.

PARIS, Nov. 29--Premier Rene Pleven asked the French National Assembly today to accord his Cabinet, and notably Defense Minister Jules Moch, a vote of confidence, on which a ballot will be taken Friday.

The country's twenty-five leading advertisers spent $2,596,343,904 for national advertising in six major media during the fourteen years 1936 to 1949. This is disclosed in the latest issue of Printer's Ink, out tomorrow.

Dr. Robert Latou Dickinson of 360 East Fiftieth Street, noted gynecologist and educator, died yesterday in the Amherst (Mass.) home of his daughter, Mrs. Truman S. Potter, after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 29-- Thailand will feel more secure against subversive activities across its northern and northeastern borders when the first phase of the United States military assistance program for this country is completed soon.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 29-- About 500,000 immigrants have entered Israel since the state was formed two and one-half years ago. This brings the Jewish population to 1,184,000 and total population, including Arabs, to 1,354,000.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday morning of a heart attack in the Stanford Hospital, San Francisco, of Dr. Franklin F. Hopper, who was director of the New York Public Library from October, 1941, until his retirement in October, 1946. Since then he had not been active. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board today authorized American Airlines to provide non-stop service between New York-Newark and Toronto. It denied the application of Colonial Airlines for a similar route.

Production of many grades of paper has increased substantially since July 1, Harold E. Holman, of the forest products division of the National Production Authority, told 100 members of the Wallpaper Industry Management Conference at their annual convention in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

Gimbels was host to nearly 2,000 guests last evening in celebration of the opening of the store's new street floor. Among those invited to inspect the re-designed and newly decorated departments were many of the city's top merchandising and manufacturing executives. They were taken on tours through five brightly lighted floors, all of which are part of the recent modernization program.
ALBANY, Nov. 30--The Court of Appeals upheld unanimously today the constitutionality of the Feinberg law barring members of subversive organizations from employment in the state's public schools.
URBANA, Ohio, Nov. 30 (AP)-- Dr. H.M. Parshall, one of the nation's best-known harness racing figures, died in his home here last night in his fifty-second year.

Most commodity futures on the local exchanges displayed a nervous undertone yesterday as traders tried to evaluate the war news from the Korean front.

With the purchase yesterday of the five-story store and apartment building at 134 Seventh Avenue and 201 West Eighteenth Street, the Chadir Realty Company now controls the entire blockfront on the avenue from Eighteenth to Nineteenth Streets, a plot of about 20,000 square feet.

The forty-eight-year career of the old American-flag passenger liner Ancon, a troopship in two world wars and a transport medium for much of the material that went into construction of the Panama Canal, is nearing an end in a Genoa scrapyard, it became known yesterday.

The blockfront property at 9891007 East 163d Street, the Bronx, consisting of three buildings containing fifteen stores and seventyeight apartments, has been purchased for investment by the Falhart Realty Corporation. The 43 Essex Street Corporation, of which Sanford Chobol is president, was the seller.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 30--Miss Dorothy Holmes Halsey, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Wetmore Halsey and the late Mr. Halsey, has completed plans for her marriage on Dec. 19 to David Histed Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hilliard Withers Hughes of Kansas City.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 30--Ben Tompkins and a massive Texas line whipped Texas A. and M., 17--0, today, completing the Southwest Conference schedule without defeat for the first time under the present membership.

NEW HOLLAND, N.C., Nov. 30--This section, with an un successful agricultural past and an unparalleled success as a waterfowl center, undoubtedly attracts more geese and goose shooters than any spot on the Atlantic Coast.
A new, sophisticated version of Santa Claus was introduced yesterday when McCreery opened it's Wise Men's Shop on the third floor.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 30-- John A. Kervick, director of the New York field office of the Public Housing Administration, warned here today against complacency in allowing stop-gap temporary housing for veterans to remain beyond their limited life span as a source of municipal revenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--President Truman named Mayor Michael V. DiSalle of Toledo, Ohio, today to be Director of Price Stabilization.

In three minutes yesterday morning, three thugs invaded a Brooklyn concern that manufactures aviation and testing equipment for the Government, covered eleven employer and a civilian Navy inspector with their pistols and escaped with a $12,400 payroll.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 30--The Western powers should revise their German policy to give this country greater equality if they wish the West German republic to "take part in West European defense shoulder to shoulder with them," Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared today.
Growing scarcities of nickel for use in making cast alloy steel parts may cut back output during December, foundry spokesmen said here yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 30--The United States faces two wars today, one against an external tyranny and the other against an internal socialism, William Loeb, publisher of The New Hampshire

The retirement of Cornelis M. de Jong, passenger traffic manager of the Holland-America Line and a senior executive in the passenger travel business in this country, was announced yesterday by Frederic R. Wierdsma, general manager of the company in North America.
The resignation of David E. Smucker and Hunter L. Delatour as trustees of the Long Island Rail Road was probably inevitable.
WASHINGTON; Nov. 30 (AP)-- The text of President Truman's statement today on the Korean situation:

General Electric Company will cut back appliance production at least 25 per cent across the board on Jan. 1 and may increase prices 3 to 4 per cent, H.L. Andrews, vice president of the appliance and ...

Five world-record performances in track and field, twenty-two in swimming and three in weight-lifting are among the 210 marks that will be submitted for approval to the Amateur Athletic Union at its sixty-second annual national convention at Washington, D.C., Deo. 7-10.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--President Truman declared today that the United Nations forces in Korea were determined to fight to the bitter end for justice and world peace and warned we would use the atomic bomb, if necessary, to assure victory.
The uniform is a warm, rusty red, and the shoulder patch marks the women who wear it as "substitute mothers" at Bellevue Hospital.

Although the line rate for advertising in daily newspapers has increased 50 per cent in the period 1940-1950, the milline rate, or the cost of reaching a reader, has risen only slightly, according to a study released yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 30--Delegates to the United Nations did some deep thinking and hard worrying today about the possible user of the atomic bomb in Korea and most of them came up with the conclusion that although it would be legally permissible it also would be politically disastrous.
Elimination of a potential death trap for pedestrians and motorists on Eleventh Avenue between Twenty-first and Twenty-second Streets was announced yesterday by Traffic Commisioner Lloyd B. Reid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Complaints against the National Production Authority's order cutting back civilian uses of aluminum by 35 per cent were registered in advance of the regulation's effective date today by the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 30--Andres Martinet Trueba, President-elect of Uruguay, said in an interview today that this country feared that all the efforts of the democratic nations to find a peaceful solution to the present world crisis would be insufficient.

Gaining victories in the fourteenth and fifteenth rounds, Samuel Reshevsky of New York passed Gideon Stahlberg of Stockholm to take second place in the international chess masters tournament last night, according to a report from Amsterdam.
The nation's gold holdings dropped $60,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, bringing the total decline since Jan. 1 to $1,390,000,000, the largest reduction in a year ever recorded.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30--There will be no mass evacuation from cities in case of atomic attack because Americans will have to stay on their jobs as members of the production line, James J. Wadsworth, Acting Director of the Civil Defense Office, declared today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)-- Industrial production set a new post-war high in October and maintained the pace through November's first half, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.)-- Max Lowenthal, New York lawyer and author of a recent book critical of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was attacked on the floor of the House of Representatives today as a Communist whose work was a "booby trap" designed to undermine the F.B.I.
George Balanchine has created a spirited and delightful little divertissement set to Glinka's "Mazurka" from "A Life from the Czar"
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Congress was asked today to put full direction of the nation's civil defense into the hands of an administrator, named by and responsible only to the President.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--An official who arrived from Belgrade by airplane only last night advised the House Foreign Affairs Committee today against attaching any political or military strings to the proposed grant-in-aid of foodstuffs to Yugoslavia until the next harvest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives agreed today on an excess profits tax, retroactive to July 1, that would yield $3,300,000,000 annually. President Truman had asked for $4,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Six members of the Senate Judiciary Committee sponsored a resolution today urging the establishment in the Senate of a counterpart of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, at least on a one-year trial basis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Henry C. Iler of Arlington, Va., president of the American Federation of Government Employes and a Labor Department official, died yesterday in the Marine Hospital, Baltimore, after an illness of several months. He was 45 years old.

A 250-pound brass ship's bell that has tolled tune since 1870 in all parts of the world and for many different people, among them United States-bound immigrants, Alaskan Sourdoughs and Australian longshoremen, is due here tomorrow aboard the Cunard liner Parthia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Government officials today were putting the finishing touches upon a new type of export license covering the movement of foreign goods passing through the United States en route to foreign consignees.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP)--The Midwest Stock Exchange reported today that its first year in business had resulted in an increase of 137 per cent in share volume and 154 per cent in dollar volume.
A grave responsibility rests on those able to help wounded veterans obtain employment, Elmer E. Myers, commander of the Crossroads of the World Post, Veterans of Foreign Wars, declared last night.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30--Steel wages and prices went up today as the nation's two largest steel producers--United States Steel and Bethlehem--signed new pay agreements with Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Statehood for Alaska and Hawaii appeared to move closer toward the vale of lost causes, at least for the foreseeable future, as new complications developed in the Senate today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 30--A sit-down demonstration of 150 teen-age pacifists led by Paul Robeson Jr. here late today provided the United Nations with its first protest meeting inside the headquarters building.

The next decade will see the rise of a new basic industry in the production of synthetic liquid fuels, first from natural gas and then from oil shales and coal, Dr. James Boyd, director of the Bureau of Mines, declared here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Senate Republican leaders said today they had no plans at present to seek alliances with enough Southern Democrats to block President Truman's patronage appointments ...

Loans to business by New York City banks rose again last week, advancing $32,000,000 to pass the $6,000,000,000 mark. The increase in such borrowings from the reporting member institutions during the week ended on Wednesday brought the total outstanding to $6,007,000,000, the highest level ever recorded.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30-- Because of the persistence of "an unsound national transportation policy" the pace of railroad modernization is being geared largely to prospective earnings rather than to the need for improvements, a convention report to the Investment Bankers Association asserted here today.

For reasons of health Fred Allen will take an extended vacation from his television show on the National Broadcasting Company after the performance of Sunday, Dec. 17. Whether he will return to the program this season is in doubt.

HONG KONG, Nov. 30--In the midst of the world crisis generated by the all-out Chinese Communist intervention in Korea, the Peiping People's Daily, official party organ, published an editorial today reiterating three demands as Communist China's conditions for peace in the Far East.
Mayor Impellitteri announced last night the following appointments in his administration:
Scrap copper market prices dropped sharply here yesterday because of the copper limitation order just issued by the National Production Authority.

The Department of Health has completed a study of food vending machines in subways, theatres, office buildings and schools to ascertain whether specific regulations should be drawn up to insure sanitary maintenance of the coin-operated devices.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Eastern railroads plan to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission next Monday for a new general 4 per cent increase in their freight rates. Although no announce

When the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, led by Dimitri Mitropoulos, performed Cherubini's overture to "The Water-Carrier" last night in Carnegie Hall we heard the famous piece through the pathos of distance.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec., 1--The Chinese Communist armies yesterday hurled new attacks at the United States Marines encircled near, the Changjin Reservoir, in the mountains of northeast Korea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.)-- The District of Columbia Court of Appeals was asked today to set aside the espionage conviction of Judith Coplon, former Government of employe, on the ground that the Federal Bureau of Investigation illegally eavesdropped on her telephone conversations.

The 5 per cent average increase in the price of its products announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation is expected to become the pattern for the fifth post-war round of steel price advances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Thirty of the Democratic and Republican leaders of Congress were summoned today to a White House conference tomorrow at which President Truman will lay out a great expansion in this country's war program.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30--The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church since 1947, was nominated today to head the newly formed National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America.

With the acquiescence of the Interstate Commerce Commission, red cap porters here and in the other stations of twelve Eastern railroads, will begin today to charge a quarter for each piece of luggage they handle.
A Jewish tribunal cleared Major Mittelman yesterday of a charge of murdering a fellow-inmate of a Nazi concentration camp in 1945.
Despite the intervention of Communist China in the Korean war United States imports from that country are continuing at the same high level of the last year, it was learned yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 30-- It is seven long years--almost two undergraduate generations--since Navy last defeated Army at football, and the midshipmen who will leave here tomorrow for their fifty-first meeting with the cadets at Philadelphia Saturday are in the mood to return with their shields or on them.

The reason Prime Minister Attlee is coming here to talk to President Truman is, in general, the desire of all Britons and for that matter all Europeans, to see to it that any policy now followed is a joint one.

The third and last of the novelties on the schedule of the New York City Ballet's current season at the City Center was presented last night in the form of a new pas de deux created by George Balanchine for Maria Tallchief to music selected from Delibes' ballet, "Sylvia."

Notice of intention to terminate the existing agreement, which expires Jan. 31, was served upon towboat owners yesterday by Local 333, United Marine Division, International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L.

Maj. Gen. William H. Draper Jr., former Under Secretary of the Army and a vice president of the investment banking concern of Dillon Read Co., was recommended unanimously by the Long Island Rail Road Commission yesterday to be trustee of the bankrupt road.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Three Congressional committees acted today to bring enactment of an excess profits tax before Christmas.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were up 10 to 56 points net with far months relatively stronger than near months.

ROME, Dec. 1--The question of the use of atomic weapons in the Korean war was seized upon by the Communists today as a means for fomenting feeling against the United States under the guise of promoting peace.

I am today transmitting to the Congress a request for additional funds to strengthen our defenses. The gravity of the world situation requires that these funds be made available with the utmost speed.

Air-pollution specialists at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers declared here yesterday that widespread efforts to keep city air pure would never succeed until the medical profession produced "facts" that would convince the public of the hazards of breathing contaminated air.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Millard F. Caldwell Jr., 53-year-old former Governor of Florida, was appointed Civilian Defense Administrator today, charged with planning programs to protect more than 150,000,000 people in the event of war reaching the boundaries of the United States.
Rubber and tin prices in the futures markets dropped sharply yesterday as war jitters continued to dominate price movements in these essential import commodities.

The recent severe Weather conditions throughout the country have caused sharp reductions in railroad freight carloadings. Last week, carloadings were down because of the observance of Thanksgiving and at the end of the week by the storms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--An increase in railroad freight on items of furniture, estimated as averaging between 58.7 and 76.3 per cent, will go into effect after Dec. 11, under a decision issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 1--A proposed blueprint for a national organization to substitute for the United Jewish Appeal in the event the appeal ceased functioning will not be presented for implementation, officials of the Council for Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds asserted today in a report to 700 delegates at the council's nineteenth annual general assembly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The National Conference on Labor Legislation proposed today that Congress provide workmen's compensation to apply in case of an atomic attack.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today that orders forbidding him to strike across the Korean border at the Chinese Communists were putting the United Nations forces under "an enormous handicap, without precedent in military history."

The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, which has handled $152,000,000 for aid programs in sixty lands since its establishment four years ago, received a new three-year lease on life from the General Assembly meeting at Flushing Meadow yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 1 --There is sufficient raw stock available to meet the needs of the paint and wall paper industry for the next six to twelve months, providing the international situation does not become more tense, calling for an increase in defense requirements, according to Max Yospin of Elizabeth, N.J., vice president of the Wall Paper Wholesale Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party of the United States, was put in jail today, following his inability to raise $1,500 bond after he was arraigned in the Federal district court on charges of contempt of Congress.

LONDON, Dec. ,1--In an atmosphere of urgency, the North Atlantic Council of Deputies started drafting today a compromise between France and other North Atlantic Treaty powers on the question of a European army. The essence of the compromise was that the creation of integrated Atlantic forces and negotiations to form a continental army should proceed simultaneously.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 1-- Walter G. Winne, Bergen County Prosecutor, was stripped of virtually all his powers today by Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons, who assigned his deputy, Nelson F. Stamler, to take charge temporarily of the county's "criminal business."

Georgetown University Law School won last night the Samuel Seabury Award in the first national interlaw school "moot court" competition sponsored by the Bar Association of New York in its headquarters at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

The New York Bible Society, which since early in the fall has been celebrating its 141st anniversary at a number of regional and racial rallies, as well as meetings for foreign-language groups, will hold an all-Manhattan anniversary service tomorrow at 5 P.M. at Christ Church (Methodist), Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The host pastor, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, will give the address.

As the reservoirs gained another 1,441,000,000 gallons yesterday, the Water Department reported that November watershed rainfall, bolstered by last Saturday's storm, had been 1.82 inches above normal. Since the storm storage has increased 40,097,000,000 gallons.

CHICAGO, Dec, 1--While there is increasingly apparent need for strong and progressive public welfare services for the country's "less fortunate citizens," there will be diminishing funds for welfare programs because of the struggle for survival in the world scene, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois declared today.

LONDON, Dec. 1--The stock markets here ended a depressing week on a quiet but steady note today. With investors holding off to see how the political and military situations developed, business dropped sharply.
The magnificent response of the public to the appeal for blood that went out over the radio immediately after the Long Island Rail Road wreck should not obscure the realities of the matter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The sharp impact of recent consumer credit controls upon installment buying was disclosed here today by the Federal Reserve Board in a report showing that consumer credit gained only $42,000,000 in October. The figure compares with an average monthly advance of $300,000,000 in the preceding five months.
Alfred Bergdoll, eldest son of Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, America's most notorious draft dodger of World War I, was arrested yesterday for refusing induction into the Army.

Earnings of Geo. A. Hormel Co., meat packers, specializing in pork products, for the year ended Oct. 28, 1950, were 34 per cent higher than those of the previous fiscal year, according to the report released yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1--Feed grains and soybeans showed strong undertones on the Board of Trade here today. Corn was active and closed 1 1/8 to 1 cents a bushel higher, with the cash article gaining to 1 cent on the December position, and old No. 2 yellow selling at $1.65 , or 5 cents over the December and a new high for that cereal since October, 1948.
Rijstafel is that interesting Dutch East Indian dish presented at only a few restaurants in the city, among the most surprising of which is perhaps the Copain, 891 First Avenue.
LONDON, Dec. 1--A mood of grave disquiet and distrust of United States policy is rising in Britain.

Shoppers will welcome the vast array of holiday accessories now cramming the stores. Unusual designs range from the country casual mood to the elaborat in jewelry, gloves, umbrellas, handbags, belts, blouses and little headpieces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Tire and other rubber goods producers may actually have more rubber for civilian uses in January and February than they did last month, according to advices given today to members of the Rubber Industry Advisory Committee of the National Production Authority.

In giving the reason for increased military appropriations President Truman yesterday declared that "the present aggression" in Korea had been revealed "as a long-calculated move to defy the United Nations and to destroy the Republic of Korea, which was giving a demonstration to the peoples of Asia of the advantages of life in an independent, national, non-Communist state."

St. John's and Long Island University will give followers of college basketball an opportunity to gain an early line on their chances tonight at Madison Square Garden. The local Redmen and Blackbirds will engage William and Mary and Kansas State, respectively, in a double-header, with the curtainraiser listed for 8 P.M.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP)--The University of Miami Hurricanes proved their right to meet Clemson in the Orange Bowl when they thrashed a stubborn University of Missouri eleven tonight, 27--9, to end the season with a record of nine victories and a tie.

IN recent years there has been considerable discussion among wildfowlers concerning the real conservation value of some of the waterfowl regulations, and many shooters are convinced that the purpose of some of the "shall note" is to discourage gunners rather than protect the ducks and geese.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--President Truman asked Congress today to provide $1,050,000,000 of additional funds for the Atomic Energy Commission to enable it to increase its productive capacity "substantially." He also called for an extra $84,000,000 for the Tennessee Valley Authority for transmission of power to atomic installations.

In spite of the unfavorable war news and the indicated demand for larger quantities of military goods, the wool textile market has remained steady. Consumer demand for clothing has not been stimulated, wool goods suppliers said yesterday, and production schedules in the women's wear trade are on spring apparel for future delivery.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent in the week ended Nov. 28, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The Metropolitan Opera was at the top of its form for the season's first performance of "Trisian und Isolde" last night. The new management has won kudos for its new productions, but it deserves even more for the pains it has taken with a repertory work.
Albert M. Fiala has been named manager of government sales in the industrial products sales department of the B.F. Goodrich Company. For ten years he was manager of latex foam product sales.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--One hundred and seventy-nine eastern railroads today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a 4 per cent increase in freight rates and charges, and indicated they hoped it might be done by Jan. 1.

Nasrollah Entezam, president of the United Nations General Assembly, appealed yesterday to the people of the world and their leaders to face with clear minds, free of passion, a crisis which he described as "extremely grave."
Both the police and motorists are demonstrating an increasing disregard for parking regulations, a check showed yesterday.

Ray Famechon, European featherweight champion from France came back to Madison Square Garden last night for his fourth American ring engagement and fought his way right back into world-title contention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The President's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Forces reported tonight that the present service by chaplains was good but urged establishment of a unified chaplain school to prepare men for the Army, Navy and Air Force.
Helen Hayes, who aims to put on Barrie's "Mary Rose" to develop young players in need oP a chance in a first-rate production, sent word yesterday that she had cast Bethel Leslie in the title role.

PARIS, Dec. 1--At a meeting today of the European Marshall Plan council at the ministerial level, an effort was made to reconcile United States stock-piling of strategic matertals with the European desire to allocate them to insure adequate supplies for all consumers and to prevent further price increases.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1--Army and Navy will meet here tomorrow in the Municipal Stadium for the fifty-first time before the record football crowd of the year, 101,000 persons, including President Truman and many Cabinet members and top military figures.

Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader and National Committeeman, announced yesterday that he had asked Frank S. Hogan, District Attorney of New York County, to have a grand jury investigation of campaign charges by Governor Dewey that he was a political associate of Frank Costello.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)-- Following is the copyrighted text of questions addressed to Gen. Douglas MacArthur by editors of the magazine U.S. News World Report, together with the General's answeers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec, 1--Sir Benegal N. Rau, Indian representative in the United Nations, had a fifty-minute talk this morning with Wu Hsiu-chuan, spokesman for Communist China, over the possibility of a peaceful settlement of Peiping's intervention in Korea.

The Board of Estimate has decided tentatively to include $350,000 in the 1951 capital budget to enable the city to make a start toward taking over the Rockaway division of the Long Island Rail Road. The budget is to be adopted Monday.
After an interval of nine years Dolly Haas is repeating her performance in "The Circle of Chalk." Under the auspices of the Dramatic Workshop, she appeared at the President Theatre last evening.

The Government expects to prove that seventeen of the nation's leading investment banking houses, which are accused of violating the Sherman Anti-trust Law, actively discouraged insurance companies and other institutional buyers from bidding for new security issues Federal Judge Harold R. Medina was informed yesterday.

Some of the losses caused by the adverse Korean war news earlier this week were reduced yesterday on the stock market. While there was a high degree of selectivity in in day's trading, gains were slightly above those of Thursday, the composite rate rising 1.44 points.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 2--The Chinese Communist armies rolled forward behind a screen of fleeing refugees yesterday toward the new United Nations defense line in Western Korea. Meanwhile Marines and troops of the United States Seventh Infantry Division fought to break out of encirclement by 80,000 of the enemy in the frozen northeast.
